<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Turkey</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Transcontinental country straddling Western Asia and Southeastern Europe</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the country. For the bird, see <a href="/wiki/Turkey_(bird)" title="Turkey (bird)">Turkey (bird)</a>. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Turkey_(disambiguation)" title="Turkey (disambiguation)">Turkey (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"TÃ¼rkiye" and "Turkiye" redirect here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Turkiye_(disambiguation)" title="Turkiye (disambiguation)">Turkiye (disambiguation)</a>.</div>

<p><b>Turkey</b> (<a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>: <i lang="tr">TÃ¼rkiye</i> <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="tr-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Turkish" title="Help:IPA/Turkish">[ËtyÉ¾cije]</a></span>), officially the <b>Republic of Turkey </b> (Turkish: <i lang="tr">TÃ¼rkiye Cumhuriyeti</i> <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="tr-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Turkish" title="Help:IPA/Turkish">[ËtyÉ¾cije dÊumËhuËÉ¾ijeti]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tur-T%C3%BCrkiye_Cumhuriyeti.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/37/Tur-T%C3%BCrkiye_Cumhuriyeti.ogg" title="Tur-TÃ¼rkiye Cumhuriyeti.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), is a <a href="/wiki/List_of_transcontinental_countries" title="List of transcontinental countries">transcontinental country</a> located mainly on the <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolian Peninsula</a> in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">small portion</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkan Peninsula</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">Southeast Europe</a>. It shares borders with the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> to the north; <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a> to the northeast; <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a> to the east; <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> to the southeast; <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> to the south; the <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">Aegean Sea</a> to the west; and <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> to the northwest. <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> is located off the south coast. <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turks</a> form the vast majority of the nation's population and <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a> are the largest minority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-cia-4">[4]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a> is Turkey's capital, while <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> is its <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_and_towns_in_Turkey" title="List of largest cities and towns in Turkey">largest city</a> and <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial centre</a>.
</p><p>One of the world's earliest permanently <a href="/wiki/Settler" title="Settler">settled</a> regions, present-day Turkey was home to important <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> sites like <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="GÃ¶bekli Tepe">GÃ¶bekli Tepe</a>, and was inhabited by <a href="/wiki/Civilization" title="Civilization">ancient civilisations</a> including the <a href="/wiki/Hattians" title="Hattians">Hattians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">Hittites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_peoples" title="Anatolian peoples">Anatolian peoples</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mycenaean_Greece" title="Mycenaean Greece">Mycenaean Greeks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persians" title="Persians">Persians</a> and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Howard2_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-Howard2-11">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon20112_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon20112-12">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MET_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-MET-13">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Following the conquests of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> which started the <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic period</a>, most of the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_regions_of_Anatolia" title="Ancient regions of Anatolia">ancient regions</a> in modern Turkey were culturally <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">Hellenised</a>, which continued during the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine era</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon20112_12-1"><a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon20112-12">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FreedmanMyers20002_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FreedmanMyers20002-15">[15]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Seljuk Turks</a> began migrating in the 11th century, and the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">Sultanate of Rum</a> ruled <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> until the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Anatolia" title="Mongol invasions of Anatolia">Mongol invasion</a> in 1243, when it disintegrated into small <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">Turkish principalities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mfk&amp;gl2_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-mfk&amp;gl2-16">[16]</a></sup> Beginning in the late 13th century, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_dynasty" title="Ottoman dynasty">Ottomans</a> <a href="/wiki/Rise_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Rise of the Ottoman Empire">united the principalities and conquered the Balkans</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">Turkification</a> of Anatolia increased during the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman period</a>. After <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_II" title="Mehmed II">Mehmed II</a> <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">conquered</a> <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> (<a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>) in 1453, Ottoman expansion continued under <a href="/wiki/Selim_I" title="Selim I">Selim I</a>. During the reign of <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> became a <a href="/wiki/Transformation_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Transformation of the Ottoman Empire">global power</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Howard2_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-Howard2-11">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-masters_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-masters-17">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> From the late 18th century onwards, the <a href="/wiki/Decline_and_modernization_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Decline and modernization of the Ottoman Empire">empire's power declined</a> with a gradual loss of territories.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_II" title="Mahmud II">Mahmud II</a> started a <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">period of modernisation</a> in the early 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Young_Turk_Revolution" title="Young Turk Revolution">Young Turk Revolution</a> of 1908 restricted the authority of the Sultan and <a href="/wiki/Second_Constitutional_Era" title="Second Constitutional Era">restored</a> the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_Parliament" title="Ottoman Parliament">Ottoman Parliament</a> after a 30-year suspension, ushering the empire into a <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="List of political parties in the Ottoman Empire">multi-party period</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1913_Ottoman_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1913 Ottoman coup d'Ã©tat">1913 coup d'Ã©tat</a> put the country under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Pashas" title="Three Pashas">Three Pashas</a>, who facilitated the Empire's <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_entry_into_World_War_I" title="Ottoman entry into World War I">entry</a> into <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> in 1914. During the war, the Ottoman government committed <a href="/wiki/Late_Ottoman_genocides" title="Late Ottoman genocides">genocides</a> against its <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide" title="Armenian genocide">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">Greek</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" title="Assyrian genocide">Assyrian</a> subjects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-two_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-two-25">[a]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SchallerZimmerer_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-SchallerZimmerer-26">[25]</a></sup> After its defeat in the war, the Ottoman Empire was <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Partition of the Ottoman Empire">partitioned</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">Turkish War of Independence</a> against the occupying <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied Powers</a> resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_Ottoman_sultanate" title="Abolition of the Ottoman sultanate">abolition of the Sultanate</a> on 1 November 1922, the signing of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a> (which superseded the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of SÃ¨vres">Treaty of SÃ¨vres</a>) on 24 July 1923 and the proclamation of the Republic on 29 October 1923. With the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="AtatÃ¼rk's Reforms">reforms</a> initiated by the country's first president, <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk">Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk</a>, Turkey became a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular</a>, <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a>. Turkey played a prominent role in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a> and joined <a href="/wiki/Turkey_in_NATO" title="Turkey in NATO">NATO</a> in 1952. The country endured several military <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coup" title="Coup">coups</a> in the latter half of the 20th century. The economy was liberalised in the 1980s, leading to stronger economic growth and political stability. The <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a> was replaced with a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a> by <a href="/wiki/2017_Turkish_constitutional_referendum" title="2017 Turkish constitutional referendum">referendum in 2017</a>.
</p><p>Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[27]</a></sup> with a geopolitically strategic location.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-giga-hamburg.de1_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-giga-hamburg.de1-29">[28]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Turkey" title="Economy of Turkey">economy</a>, which is classified among the <a href="/wiki/Emerging_and_growth-leading_economies" title="Emerging and growth-leading economies">emerging and growth-leading economies</a>, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">twenty third-largest in the world</a> by nominal GDP, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">eleventh-largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>. In addition to being an early member of NATO, Turkey is a charter member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">IMF</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, and a founding member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_the_Black_Sea_Economic_Cooperation" title="Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation">BSEC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Turkic_States" title="Organization of Turkic States">OTS</a> and <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>. After becoming <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Member states of the Council of Europe">one of the early members</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> in 1950, Turkey became an <a href="/wiki/Ankara_Agreement" title="Ankara Agreement">associate member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">EEC</a> in 1963, joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">EU Customs Union</a> in 1995, and started <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">accession negotiations</a> with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 2005. Turkey has a rich cultural legacy shaped by centuries of history and the influence of the various peoples that have inhabited its territory over several millennia; it is home to <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">19 UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a> and is <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings" title="World Tourism rankings">among the most visited</a> countries in the world.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name">Name</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Turkey" title="Name of Turkey">Name of Turkey</a></div>
<p>The English name of Turkey (from <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">Medieval Latin</a> <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Turchia</i></span>/<span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Turquia</i></span><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arlen_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-arlen-30">[29]</a></sup>) means "land of the Turks". <a href="/wiki/Middle_English" title="Middle English">Middle English</a> usage of <i>Turkye</i> is evidenced in an early work by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chaucer" title="Chaucer">Chaucer</a> called <i><a href="/wiki/The_Book_of_the_Duchess" title="The Book of the Duchess">The Book of the Duchess</a></i> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â1369</span>). The phrase <i>land of Torke</i> is used in the 15th-century <a href="/wiki/The_Digby_Conversion_of_Saint_Paul" title="The Digby Conversion of Saint Paul">Digby Mysteries</a>. Later usages can be found in the <a href="/wiki/William_Dunbar" title="William Dunbar">Dunbar poems</a>, the 16th century <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la"><a href="/wiki/Manipulus_Vocabulorum" title="Manipulus Vocabulorum">Manipulus Vocabulorum</a></i></span> (<i>Turkie</i>) and <a href="/wiki/Francis_Bacon" title="Francis Bacon">Francis Bacon</a>'s <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Sylva Sylvarum</i></span> (<i>Turky</i>). The modern spelling Turkey dates back to at least 1719.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>The name of Turkey appeared in the Western sources after the <a href="/wiki/Crusades" title="Crusades">crusades</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cevdet_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-cevdet-32">[31]</a></sup> In the 14th-century Arab sources, <i>turkiyya</i> is usually contrasted with <i>turkmaniyya</i> (<a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Turkomania_(disambiguation)" title="Turkomania (disambiguation)">Turkomania</a>), probably to be understood as <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Turks" title="Oghuz Turks">Oghuz</a> in a broad sense.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[32]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Battuta" title="Ibn Battuta">Ibn Battuta</a>, in the 1330s introduces the region as <i>barr al-Turkiyya al-ma'ruf bi-bilad al-Rum</i> ("the Turkish land known as the lands of Rum").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[33]</a></sup> The disintegration of the country after <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> revived <a href="/wiki/Turkish_nationalism" title="Turkish nationalism">Turkish nationalism</a>, and the <i>TÃ¼rkler iÃ§in TÃ¼rkiye</i> ("Turkey for the Turks") sentiment rose up. With the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Alexandropol" title="Treaty of Alexandropol">Treaty of Alexandropol</a> signed by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_Grand_National_Assembly" title="Government of the Grand National Assembly">Government of the Grand National Assembly</a> with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Armenian_Republic" title="First Armenian Republic">Armenia</a>, the name of <i>TÃ¼rkiye</i> entered international documents for the first time. In the treaty signed with <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Afghanistan" title="Kingdom of Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, the expression <i>Devlet-i Aliyye-i TÃ¼rkiyye</i> ("Sublime Turkish State") was used, likened to the Ottoman Empire's name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cevdet_32-1"><a href="#cite_note-cevdet-32">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Official_name_change">Official name change</span></h3>
<p>In January 2020, the Turkish Exporters' Assembly (TÄ°M) â the umbrella organisation of Turkish exports â announced that it would use "Made in Turkiye" on all its labels in a bid to standardise branding and the identity of Turkish businesses on the international stage, using the term 'Turkiye' across all languages around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-:5-35">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2021, President Recep Tayyip ErdoÄan issued a circular calling for exports to be labelled "Made in TÃ¼rkiye". The circular also stated that in relation to other governmental communications "necessary sensitivity will be shown on the use of the phrase 'TÃ¼rkiye' instead of phrases such as 'Turkey', 'TÃ¼rkei', 'Turquie' etc."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[36]</a></sup> The reason given in the circular for preferring <i>TÃ¼rkiye</i> was that it "represents and expresses the culture, civilisation, and values of the Turkish nation in the best way". According to Turkish state broadcaster <a href="/wiki/TRT_World" title="TRT World">TRT World</a>, it was also to avoid a pejorative association with <a href="/wiki/Turkey_(bird)" title="Turkey (bird)">turkey, the bird</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-:5-35">[34]</a></sup> It was reported in January 2022 that the government planned to register <i>TÃ¼rkiye</i> with the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[37]</a></sup> Minister of Foreign Affairs <a href="/wiki/Mevl%C3%BCt_%C3%87avu%C5%9Fo%C4%9Flu" title="MevlÃ¼t ÃavuÅoÄlu">MevlÃ¼t ÃavuÅoÄlu</a> sent letters to the UN and other international organisations on 31 May 2022 requesting that they use <i>TÃ¼rkiye</i>. The UN agreed and implemented the request immediately.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[38]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Turkey" title="History of Turkey">History of Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Anatolia" title="History of Anatolia">History of Anatolia</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Thrace" title="History of Thrace">History of Thrace</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_of_Anatolia_and_Eastern_Thrace">Prehistory of Anatolia and Eastern Thrace</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Anatolia" title="Prehistory of Anatolia">Prehistory of Anatolia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Southeastern_Europe" title="Prehistory of Southeastern Europe">Prehistory of Southeastern Europe</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe,_Urfa.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg/220px-G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg/330px-G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg/440px-G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe%2C_Urfa.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe,_Urfa.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Some <a href="/wiki/Henge" title="Henge">henges</a> at <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="GÃ¶bekli Tepe">GÃ¶bekli Tepe</a> were erected as far back as <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe#Layer_III" title="GÃ¶bekli Tepe">9600 BC</a>, predating those of <a href="/wiki/Stonehenge" title="Stonehenge">Stonehenge</a>, England, by over seven millennia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArchMag_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-ArchMag-41">[40]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolian peninsula</a>, comprising most of modern Turkey, is one of the oldest permanently settled regions in the world. Various <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_Anatolians" title="Ancient Anatolians">ancient Anatolian</a> populations have lived in <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>, from at least the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> until the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization" title="Hellenistic civilization">Hellenistic period</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon20112_12-2"><a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon20112-12">[12]</a></sup> Many of these peoples spoke the <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_languages" title="Anatolian languages">Anatolian languages</a>, a branch of the larger <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-European_language_family" title="Indo-European language family">Indo-European language family</a>:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UCLA_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-UCLA-42">[41]</a></sup> and, given the antiquity of the Indo-European <a href="/wiki/Hittite_language" title="Hittite language">Hittite</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luwian_language" title="Luwian language">Luwian</a> languages, some scholars have proposed <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_hypothesis" title="Anatolian hypothesis">Anatolia as the hypothetical centre from which the Indo-European languages radiated</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnatoliaIndoEuropean_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-AnatoliaIndoEuropean-43">[42]</a></sup> The European part of Turkey, called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Thrace" title="Eastern Thrace">Eastern Thrace</a>, has also been inhabited since at least forty thousand years ago, and is known to have been in the Neolithic era by about 6000 BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MET_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-MET-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sphinx_Gate,_Hattusa_01.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg/220px-Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg/330px-Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg/440px-Sphinx_Gate%2C_Hattusa_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The Sphinx Gate of <a href="/wiki/Hattusa" title="Hattusa">Hattusa</a>, the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">Hittites</a>.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aizanoi_Zeus_temple_2120.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1065" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Aizanoi_Zeus_temple_2120.jpg/220px-Aizanoi_Zeus_temple_2120.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Aizanoi_Zeus_temple_2120.jpg/330px-Aizanoi_Zeus_temple_2120.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Aizanoi_Zeus_temple_2120.jpg/440px-Aizanoi_Zeus_temple_2120.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Zeus Temple in ancient city of <a href="/wiki/Aizanoi" title="Aizanoi">Aizanoi</a> belongs to <a href="/wiki/Phrygia" title="Phrygia">Phrygia</a>.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="GÃ¶bekli Tepe">GÃ¶bekli Tepe</a> is the site of the oldest known man-made religious structure, a temple dating to circa 10,000 BC,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ArchMag_41-1"><a href="#cite_note-ArchMag-41">[40]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/%C3%87atalh%C3%B6y%C3%BCk" title="ÃatalhÃ¶yÃ¼k">ÃatalhÃ¶yÃ¼k</a> is a very large Neolithic and <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a> settlement in southern Anatolia, which existed from approximately 7500 BC to 5700 BC. It is the largest and best-preserved Neolithic site found to date and is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[43]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Neval%C4%B1_%C3%87ori" title="NevalÄ± Ãori">NevalÄ± Ãori</a> was an early <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> settlement on the middle Euphrates, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C5%9Eanl%C4%B1urfa" title="ÅanlÄ±urfa">ÅanlÄ±urfa</a>. <a href="/wiki/Urfa_Man" title="Urfa Man">Urfa Man</a> statue is dated <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">â9000 BC</span> to the period of the <a href="/wiki/Pre-Pottery_Neolithic" title="Pre-Pottery Neolithic">Pre-Pottery Neolithic</a>, and is considered as "the oldest naturalistic life-sized sculpture of a human".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RJC_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-RJC-45">[44]</a></sup> It is considered as contemporaneous with the sites of <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe" title="GÃ¶bekli Tepe">GÃ¶bekli Tepe</a>. The settlement of <a href="/wiki/Troy" title="Troy">Troy</a> started in the Neolithic Age and continued into the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest recorded inhabitants of Anatolia were the <a href="/wiki/Hattians" title="Hattians">Hattians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hurrians" title="Hurrians">Hurrians</a>, non-Indo-European peoples who inhabited central and eastern Anatolia, respectively, as early as c. 2300 BC. Indo-European <a href="/wiki/Hittites" title="Hittites">Hittites</a> came to Anatolia and gradually absorbed the Hattians and Hurrians c. 2000â1700 BC. The first major empire in the area was founded by the Hittites, from the 18th through the 13th century BC. The <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyrians</a> conquered and settled parts of southeastern Turkey as early as 1950 BC until the year 612 BC,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[46]</a></sup> although they <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_continuity" title="Assyrian continuity">have remained a minority</a> in the region, namely in <a href="/wiki/Hakk%C3%A2ri_Province" title="HakkÃ¢ri Province">Hakkari</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%9E%C4%B1rnak_Province" title="ÅÄ±rnak Province">ÅÄ±rnak</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mardin_province" title="Mardin province">Mardin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Urartu" title="Urartu">Urartu</a> re-emerged in Assyrian inscriptions in the 9th century BC as a powerful northern rival of Assyria.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[48]</a></sup> Following the collapse of the Hittite empire c. 1180 BC, the <a href="/wiki/Phrygia" title="Phrygia">Phrygians</a>, an Indo-European people, achieved ascendancy in Anatolia until their kingdom was destroyed by the <a href="/wiki/Cimmerians" title="Cimmerians">Cimmerians</a> in the 7th century BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TroyHittiteEmpirePhrygians_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-TroyHittiteEmpirePhrygians-50">[49]</a></sup> Starting from 714 BC, Urartu shared the same fate and dissolved in 590 BC,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[50]</a></sup> when it was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Medes</a>. The most powerful of Phrygia's successor states were <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">Lydia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caria" title="Caria">Caria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lycia" title="Lycia">Lycia</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Sardis" title="Sardis">Sardis</a> was an ancient city at the location of modern Sart in Western Turkey. The city served as the capital of the ancient kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">Lydia</a>. As one of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_churches_of_Asia" title="Seven churches of Asia">seven churches of Asia</a>, it was addressed in the <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Revelation" title="Book of Revelation">Book of Revelation</a> in the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[51]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">Lydian Lion</a> coins were made of <a href="/wiki/Electrum" title="Electrum">electrum</a>, a naturally occurring alloy of gold and silver but of variable precious metal value. During the reign of King <a href="/wiki/Croesus" title="Croesus">Croesus</a> that the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metallurgist" title="Metallurgist">metallurgists</a> of Sardis discovered the secret of separating <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a> from <a href="/wiki/Silver" title="Silver">silver</a>, thereby producing both metals of a purity never known before.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[52]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity">Antiquity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Classical_Anatolia" title="Classical Anatolia">Classical Anatolia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic period</a></div>
<p>Starting around 1200 BC, the coast of Anatolia was heavily settled by <a href="/wiki/Aeolians" title="Aeolians">Aeolian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ionians" title="Ionians">Ionian</a> <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greeks</a>. Numerous important <a href="/wiki/Polis" title="Polis">cities</a> were founded by these colonists, such as <a href="/wiki/Didyma" title="Didyma">Didyma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miletus" title="Miletus">Miletus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">Ephesus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smyrna" title="Smyrna">Smyrna</a> (now <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0zmir" title="Ä°zmir">Ä°zmir</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">Byzantium</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>), the latter founded by <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greek</a> colonists from <a href="/wiki/Megara" title="Megara">Megara</a> in 657 BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[53]</a></sup> Some of the most prominent pre-Socratic philosophers lived in the city of <a href="/wiki/Miletus" title="Miletus">Miletus</a>. <a href="/wiki/Thales_of_Miletus" title="Thales of Miletus">Thales of Miletus</a> (c. 624 BC â c. 546 BC) considered as first philosopher in the Greek tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[54]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPM_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-CPM-56">[55]</a></sup> and he is otherwise historically recognized as the first individual known to have entertained and engaged in <a href="/wiki/History_of_science#Greco-Roman_world" title="History of science">scientific philosophy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.com_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com-58">[57]</a></sup> In Miletus, he is followed by two other significant <a href="/wiki/Pre-Socratic_philosophy" title="Pre-Socratic philosophy">pre-Socratic philosophers</a> <a href="/wiki/Anaximander" title="Anaximander">Anaximander</a> (c. 610 BC â c. 546 BC) and <a href="/wiki/Anaximenes_of_Miletus" title="Anaximenes of Miletus">Anaximenes</a> (c. 585 BC â c. 525 BC) (known collectively, to modern scholars, as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Milesian_school" title="Milesian school">Milesian school</a>).
</p><p>For several centuries prior to the great <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">Persian invasion of Greece</a>, perhaps the very greatest and wealthiest city of the Greek world was Miletus, which founded more colonies than any other Greek city,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[58]</a></sup> particularly in the Black Sea region. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diogenes_the_Cynic" title="Diogenes the Cynic">Diogenes the Cynic</a> was one of the founders of <a href="/wiki/Cynicism_(philosophy)" title="Cynicism (philosophy)">Cynic</a> philosophy born in one of the <a href="/wiki/Ionians" title="Ionians">Ionian</a> colonies <a href="/wiki/Sinop,_Turkey" title="Sinop, Turkey">Sinope</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> coast of Anatolia in 412.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VoiceWilder_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-VoiceWilder-60">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:234px;max-width:234px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:232px;max-width:232px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Afrodisias_-_Sebasti%C3%B3n_-_Sebasteion.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2432" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Afrodisias_-_Sebasti%C3%B3n_-_Sebasteion.jpg/230px-Afrodisias_-_Sebasti%C3%B3n_-_Sebasteion.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Afrodisias_-_Sebasti%C3%B3n_-_Sebasteion.jpg/345px-Afrodisias_-_Sebasti%C3%B3n_-_Sebasteion.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Afrodisias_-_Sebasti%C3%B3n_-_Sebasteion.jpg/460px-Afrodisias_-_Sebasti%C3%B3n_-_Sebasteion.jpg 2x" width="230"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The Sebastian of the city <a href="/wiki/Aphrodisias" title="Aphrodisias">Aphrodisias</a>. The city was named after <a href="/wiki/Aphrodite" title="Aphrodite">Aphrodite</a>, the Greek goddess of beauty. In 2017, it was inscribed on the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">World Heritage Site</a> list.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[60]</a></sup></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:232px;max-width:232px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="7100" data-file-width="9163" decoding="async" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/230px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/345px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg/460px-Ephesus_Celsus_Library_Fa%C3%A7ade.jpg 2x" width="230"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Celsus" title="Library of Celsus">Library of Celsus</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">Ephesus</a> was built by the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Romans</a> in 114â117.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[61]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Artemis" title="Temple of Artemis">Temple of Artemis</a> in Ephesus, built by king <a href="/wiki/Croesus" title="Croesus">Croesus</a> of <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">Lydia</a> in the 6th century BC, was one of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World" title="Seven Wonders of the Ancient World">Seven Wonders of the Ancient World</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[62]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Trojan_War" title="Trojan War">Trojan War</a> took place in the ancient city of <a href="/wiki/Troy" title="Troy">Troy</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Achaeans_(Homer)" title="Achaeans (Homer)">Achaeans</a> (<a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greeks</a>) after <a href="/wiki/Paris_(mythology)" title="Paris (mythology)">Paris</a> of Troy took <a href="/wiki/Helen_of_Troy" title="Helen of Troy">Helen</a> from her husband <a href="/wiki/Menelaus" title="Menelaus">Menelaus</a>, king of <a href="/wiki/Sparta" title="Sparta">Sparta</a>. The war is one of the most important events in Greek mythology and has been narrated through many works of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_literature" title="Ancient Greek literature">Greek literature</a>, most notably <a href="/wiki/Homer" title="Homer">Homer</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Iliad" title="Iliad">Iliad</a></i>. Whether there is any historical reality behind the Trojan War remains an open question. Those who believe that the stories of the Trojan War are derived from a specific historical conflict usually date it to the 12th or 11th century BC, often preferring the dates given by <a href="/wiki/Eratosthenes" title="Eratosthenes">Eratosthenes</a>, 1194â1184 BC, which roughly correspond to archaeological evidence of a catastrophic burning of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Troy_VII" title="Troy VII">Troy VII</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[63]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Late_Bronze_Age_collapse" title="Late Bronze Age collapse">Late Bronze Age collapse</a>.
</p><p>The first state that was called <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a> by neighbouring peoples was the state of the <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">Armenian</a> <a href="/wiki/Orontid_dynasty" title="Orontid dynasty">Orontid dynasty</a>, which included parts of what is now eastern Turkey beginning in the 6th century BC. In Northwest Turkey, the most significant tribal group in Thrace was the <a href="/wiki/Odrysian_kingdom" title="Odrysian kingdom">Odyrisians</a>, founded by <a href="/wiki/Teres_I" title="Teres I">Teres I</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LewisBoardman1994_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-LewisBoardman1994-65">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>All of modern-day Turkey was conquered by the Persian <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a> during the 6th century BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A_companion_to_Ancient_Macedonia_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-A_companion_to_Ancient_Macedonia-66">[65]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">Greco-Persian Wars</a> started when the Greek city states on the coast of Anatolia rebelled against Persian rule in 499 BC.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Artemisia_I_of_Caria" title="Artemisia I of Caria">Artemisia I of Caria</a> was a queen of the ancient Greek city-state of <a href="/wiki/Halicarnassus" title="Halicarnassus">Halicarnassus</a> and she fought as an ally of <a href="/wiki/Xerxes_I" title="Xerxes I">Xerxes I</a>, King of Persia against the independent Greek city states during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Persian_invasion_of_Greece" title="Second Persian invasion of Greece">second Persian invasion of Greece</a> in 480 BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>The territory of Turkey later fell to <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> in 334 BC,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PersiansInAsiaMinor_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-PersiansInAsiaMinor-69">[68]</a></sup> which led to increasing cultural homogeneity and <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">Hellenization</a> in the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SteadmanMcMahon20112_12-3"><a href="#cite_note-SteadmanMcMahon20112-12">[12]</a></sup> Following Alexander's death in 323 BC, Anatolia was subsequently divided into a number of small Hellenistic kingdoms, all of which became part of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a> by the mid-1st century BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AlexanderToRome_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-AlexanderToRome-70">[69]</a></sup> The process of Hellenization that began with Alexander's conquest accelerated under Roman rule, and by the early centuries of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_Era" title="Christian Era">Christian Era</a>, the local Anatolian languages and cultures had become extinct, being largely replaced by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language" title="Ancient Greek language">ancient Greek language</a> and culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FreedmanMyers20002_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-FreedmanMyers20002-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hout2011_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hout2011-71">[70]</a></sup> From the 1st century BC up to the 3rd century AD, large parts of modern-day Turkey were contested between the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Romans</a> and neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthians</a> through the frequent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman-Parthian_Wars" title="Roman-Parthian Wars">Roman-Parthian Wars</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Galatia" title="Galatia">Galatia</a> was an ancient area in the highlands of central Anatolia inhabited by the <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a>. The terms "Galatians" came to be used by the Greeks for the three Celtic peoples of Anatolia: the <a href="/wiki/Tectosages" title="Tectosages">Tectosages</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trocmii" title="Trocmii">Trocmii</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Tolistobogii" title="Tolistobogii">Tolistobogii</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OUP_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-OUP-72">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[72]</a></sup> By the 1st century BC the Celts had become so <a href="/wiki/Hellenization" title="Hellenization">Hellenized</a> that some Greek writers called them <i>Hellenogalatai</i> (á¼Î»Î»Î·Î½Î¿Î³Î±Î»Î¬ÏÎ±Î¹).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[73]</a></sup> Galatia was named after the <a href="/wiki/Gauls" title="Gauls">Gauls</a> from <a href="/wiki/Thrace" title="Thrace">Thrace</a> (cf. <a href="/wiki/Tylis" title="Tylis">Tylis</a>), who settled here and became a small transient foreign tribe in the 3rd century BC, following the supposed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallic_invasion_of_the_Balkans" title="Gallic invasion of the Balkans">Gallic invasion of the Balkans</a> in 279 BC.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Pontus" title="Kingdom of Pontus">Kingdom of Pontus</a> was a <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic</a> kingdom, centered in the historical region of <a href="/wiki/Pontus_(region)" title="Pontus (region)">Pontus</a> and ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Mithridatic_dynasty" title="Mithridatic dynasty">Mithridatic dynasty</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_people" title="Persian people">Persian</a> origin,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[76]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-78">[77]</a></sup> which may have been directly related to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Darius_I" title="Darius I">Darius the Great</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_dynasty" title="Achaemenid dynasty">Achaemenid dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_78-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-78">[77]</a></sup> The kingdom was proclaimed by <a href="/wiki/Mithridates_I_of_Pontus" title="Mithridates I of Pontus">Mithridates I</a> in 281 BC and lasted until its conquest by the Roman Republic in 63 BC. The Kingdom of Pontus reached its largest extent under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mithridates_VI" title="Mithridates VI">Mithridates VI</a> the Great, who conquered Colchis, Cappadocia, Bithynia, the Greek colonies of the Tauric Chersonesos. After a long struggle with <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Rome</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Mithridatic_Wars" title="Mithridatic Wars">Mithridatic Wars</a>, Pontus was defeated.
</p><p>All territories corresponding to modern Turkey eventually fell into <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>âs control.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Christian_and_Roman_period">Early Christian and Roman period</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Turkey" title="Christianity in Turkey">Christianity in Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:256px;max-width:256px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:254px;max-width:254px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Justinian555AD.png"><img alt="" data-file-height="1144" data-file-width="2111" decoding="async" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Justinian555AD.png/252px-Justinian555AD.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Justinian555AD.png/378px-Justinian555AD.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Justinian555AD.png/504px-Justinian555AD.png 2x" width="252"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a> in 555 under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Justinian_the_Great" title="Justinian the Great">Justinian the Great</a>, at its greatest extent since the fall of the Western Roman Empire.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:254px;max-width:254px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aya_Sophia_(7144824757).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1225" data-file-width="2449" decoding="async" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Aya_Sophia_%287144824757%29.jpg/252px-Aya_Sophia_%287144824757%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Aya_Sophia_%287144824757%29.jpg/378px-Aya_Sophia_%287144824757%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Aya_Sophia_%287144824757%29.jpg/504px-Aya_Sophia_%287144824757%29.jpg 2x" width="252"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Originally a church, then a mosque, later a museum, and now a mosque again, the <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia" title="Hagia Sophia">Hagia Sophia</a> in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> was built by the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine</a> emperor <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">Justinian I</a> in 532â537 AD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[79]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>According to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acts_of_Apostles" title="Acts of Apostles">Acts of Apostles</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[80]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Antioch" title="Antioch">Antioch</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Antakya" title="Antakya">Antakya</a>), a city in southern Turkey, is where followers of Jesus were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" title="Early Christianity">first called</a> "<a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a>" and became very quickly an important <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_centers_of_Christianity" title="Early centers of Christianity">center of Christianity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[82]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Paul_the_Apostle" title="Paul the Apostle">Paul the Apostle</a> traveled to <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">Ephesus</a> and stayed there for almost three years, probably working there as a tentmaker,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[83]</a></sup> as he had done when he stayed in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Corinth" title="Ancient Corinth">Corinth</a>. He is claimed to have performed numerous <a href="/wiki/Miracle" title="Miracle">miracles</a>, healing people and casting out demons, and he apparently organized missionary activity in other regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005St_Paul_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005St_Paul-85">[84]</a></sup> Paul left <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">Ephesus</a> after an attack from a local silversmith resulted in a pro-<a href="/wiki/Artemis" title="Artemis">Artemis</a> riot involving most of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005St_Paul_85-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone2005St_Paul-85">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the year 123, Emperor <a href="/wiki/Hadrian" title="Hadrian">Hadrian</a> traveled to <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>. Numerous monuments were erected for his arrival and he met his lover <a href="/wiki/Antinous" title="Antinous">Antinous</a> from <a href="/wiki/Bithynia" title="Bithynia">Bithynia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ahb_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-ahb-86">[85]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hadrian" title="Hadrian">Hadrian</a> focused on the Greek revival and built several temples and improved the cities. <a href="/wiki/Cyzicus" title="Cyzicus">Cyzicus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pergamon" title="Pergamon">Pergamon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smyrna" title="Smyrna">Smyrna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ephesus" title="Ephesus">Ephesus</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sardes" title="Sardes">Sardes</a> were promoted as regional centres for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Imperial_cult_(ancient_Rome)" title="Imperial cult (ancient Rome)">Imperial cult</a> (<a href="/wiki/Neocorate" title="Neocorate"><i>neocoros</i></a>) during this period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[86]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Byzantine_period">Byzantine period</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Anatolia" title="Byzantine Anatolia">Byzantine Anatolia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a></div>
<p>In 324 AD, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constantine_I" title="Constantine I">Constantine I</a> chose Byzantium to be the new capital of the Roman Empire, renaming it <a href="/wiki/New_Rome" title="New Rome">New Rome</a>. Under Constantine, Christianity did not become the exclusive religion of the state, but enjoyed imperial preference since <a href="/wiki/Constantine_the_Great_and_Christianity" title="Constantine the Great and Christianity">he supported it with generous privileges</a>. Following the death of <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">Theodosius I</a> in 395 and the permanent division of the Roman Empire between his two sons, the city, which would popularly come to be known as <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>, became the capital of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" title="Eastern Roman Empire">Eastern Roman Empire</a>. This empire, which would later be branded by historians as the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>, ruled most of the territory of present-day Turkey until the <a href="/wiki/Late_Middle_Ages" title="Late Middle Ages">Late Middle Ages</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[87]</a></sup> although the eastern regions remained firmly in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sasanian" title="Sasanian">Sasanian</a> hands until the first half of the 7th century. The frequent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine-Sassanid_Wars" title="Byzantine-Sassanid Wars">Byzantine-Sassanid Wars</a>, a continuation of the centuries-long <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman-Persian_Wars" title="Roman-Persian Wars">Roman-Persian Wars</a>, took place in various parts of present-day Turkey between the 4th and 7th centuries. Several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ecumenical_councils" title="Ecumenical councils">ecumenical councils</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Church" title="Early Church">early Church</a> were held in cities located in present-day Turkey, including the <a href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Nicaea" title="First Council of Nicaea">First Council of Nicaea</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iznik" title="Iznik">Iznik</a>) in 325, the <a href="/wiki/First_Council_of_Constantinople" title="First Council of Constantinople">First Council of Constantinople</a> (Istanbul) in 381, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ephesus" title="Council of Ephesus">Council of Ephesus</a> in 431, and the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">Council of Chalcedon</a> (<a href="/wiki/Kad%C4%B1k%C3%B6y" title="KadÄ±kÃ¶y">KadÄ±kÃ¶y</a>) in 451.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[88]</a></sup> During most of its existence, the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a> was one of the most powerful economic, cultural, and military forces in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Seljuks_and_the_Ottoman_Empire">Seljuks and the Ottoman Empire</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Turkic_migration" title="Turkic migration">Turkic migration</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Seljuk Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">Sultanate of Rum</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seljuq_dynasty" title="Seljuq dynasty">House of Seljuk</a> originated from the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/K%C4%B1n%C4%B1k_(tribe)" title="KÄ±nÄ±k (tribe)">KÄ±nÄ±k</a></i> branch of the <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Turks" title="Oghuz Turks">Oghuz Turks</a> who resided on the periphery of the <a class="mw-redirect" href='/wiki/Muslim_history#Abbasids_-_"Islamic_Golden_Age"' title="Muslim history">Muslim world</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Oghuz_Yabgu_State" title="Oghuz Yabgu State">Yabgu Khaganate</a> of the OÄuz confederacy, to the north of the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aral_Sea" title="Aral Sea">Aral Seas</a>, in the 9th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[90]</a></sup> In the 10th century, the Seljuks started migrating from their ancestral homeland into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persia" title="Persia">Persia</a>, which became the administrative core of the <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Great Seljuk Empire</a>, after its foundation by <a href="/wiki/Tughril" title="Tughril">Tughril</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-peter.mackenzie.org_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-peter.mackenzie.org-92">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seljuk_Empire_locator_map.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="488" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Seljuk_Empire_locator_map.svg/220px-Seljuk_Empire_locator_map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Seljuk_Empire_locator_map.svg/330px-Seljuk_Empire_locator_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Seljuk_Empire_locator_map.svg/440px-Seljuk_Empire_locator_map.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Seljuk_Empire_locator_map.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Seljuk_Empire" title="Great Seljuk Empire">Great Seljuk Empire</a> in 1092, upon the death of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Malik_Shah_I" title="Malik Shah I">Malik Shah I</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[92]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In the latter half of the 11th century, the Seljuk Turks began penetrating into <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Armenia" title="Medieval Armenia">medieval Armenia</a> and the eastern regions of Anatolia. In 1071, the Seljuks defeated the Byzantines at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Manzikert" title="Battle of Manzikert">Battle of Manzikert</a>, starting the <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">Turkification</a> process in the area; the Turkish language and <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> were introduced to Anatolia, gradually spreading throughout the region. The slow transition from a predominantly <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>-speaking Anatolia to a predominantly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> and Turkish-speaking one was underway. The <a href="/wiki/Mevlevi_Order" title="Mevlevi Order">Mevlevi Order</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dervishes" title="Dervishes">dervishes</a>, which was established in <a href="/wiki/Konya" title="Konya">Konya</a> during the 13th century by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sufi" title="Sufi">Sufi</a> poet <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Celaleddin_Rumi" title="Celaleddin Rumi">Celaleddin Rumi</a>, played a significant role in the <a href="/wiki/Islamization" title="Islamization">Islamization</a> of the diverse people of Anatolia who had previously been <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenized" title="Hellenized">Hellenized</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[94]</a></sup> Thus, alongside the Turkification of the territory, the <a href="/wiki/Persianate_society" title="Persianate society">culturally Persianized</a> Seljuks set the basis for a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turko-Persian_tradition" title="Turko-Persian tradition">Turko-Persian principal culture</a> in Anatolia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[95]</a></sup> which their eventual successors, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Culture of the Ottoman Empire">the Ottomans</a>, would take over.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[96]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[97]</a></sup>
In 1243, the Seljuk armies were defeated by the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">Mongols</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_K%C3%B6se_Da%C4%9F" title="Battle of KÃ¶se DaÄ">Battle of KÃ¶se DaÄ</a>, causing the Seljuk Empire's power to slowly disintegrate. In its wake, one of the <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_beyliks" title="Anatolian beyliks">Turkish principalities</a> governed by <a href="/wiki/Osman_I" title="Osman I">Osman I</a> would evolve over the next 200 years into the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. The Ottomans completed their conquest of the Byzantine Empire by <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">capturing its capital, Constantinople</a>, in 1453: their commander thenceforth being known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mehmed_the_Conqueror" title="Mehmed the Conqueror">Mehmed the Conqueror</a>.
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1817" data-file-width="3635" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/200px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/300px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/400px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace,_Istanbul_cropped.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2484" data-file-width="4740" decoding="async" height="105" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg/200px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg/300px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg/400px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="TopkapÄ± Palace">TopkapÄ±</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="DolmabahÃ§e Palace">DolmabahÃ§e</a> palaces were the primary residences of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_sultans_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="List of sultans of the Ottoman Empire">Sultans</a> in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> between 1465 to 1856<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-99">[98]</a></sup> and 1856 to 1922,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dolmabahcepalace_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-dolmabahcepalace-100">[99]</a></sup> respectively.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>In 1514, Sultan <a href="/wiki/Selim_I" title="Selim I">Selim I</a> (1512â1520) successfully expanded the empire's southern and eastern borders by defeating Shah <a href="/wiki/Ismail_I" title="Ismail I">Ismail I</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">Safavid dynasty</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Chaldiran" title="Battle of Chaldiran">Battle of Chaldiran</a>. In 1517, Selim I expanded Ottoman rule into <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Algeria" title="Ottoman Algeria">Algeria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Mamluk_War_(1516%E2%80%931517)" title="OttomanâMamluk War (1516â1517)">Egypt</a>, and created a naval presence in the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a>. Subsequently, a contest started between the Ottoman and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> empires to become the dominant sea power in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_naval_expeditions_in_the_Indian_Ocean" title="Ottoman naval expeditions in the Indian Ocean">a number of naval battles</a> in the Red Sea, the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a>. The Portuguese presence in the Indian Ocean was perceived as a threat to the Ottoman monopoly over the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">ancient trade routes</a> between <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>. Despite the increasingly prominent European presence, the Ottoman Empire's trade with the east continued to flourish until the second half of the 18th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Ottoman Empire's power and prestige peaked in the 16th and 17th centuries, particularly during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a>, who personally instituted major legislative changes relating to society, education, taxation and criminal law.
</p><p>The empire was often at odds with the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> in its steady advance towards <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> and the southern part of the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth">PolishâLithuanian Commonwealth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-102">[101]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:OttomanEmpireIn1683.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1850" data-file-width="1966" decoding="async" height="292" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/OttomanEmpireIn1683.png/310px-OttomanEmpireIn1683.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/OttomanEmpireIn1683.png/465px-OttomanEmpireIn1683.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/OttomanEmpireIn1683.png/620px-OttomanEmpireIn1683.png 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:OttomanEmpireIn1683.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vienna" title="Battle of Vienna">second Ottoman siege of Vienna</a> in 1683 (the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Vienna_(1529)" title="Siege of Vienna (1529)">first siege</a> was in 1529) initiated the <a href="/wiki/Great_Turkish_War" title="Great Turkish War">Great Turkish War</a> (1683â1699) between the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottomans</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1684)" title="Holy League (1684)">Holy League</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Navy" title="Ottoman Navy">Ottoman Navy</a> contended with several Holy Leagues, such as those in <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1538)" title="Holy League (1538)">1538</a>, <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1571)" title="Holy League (1571)">1571</a>, <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1684)" title="Holy League (1684)">1684</a> and <a href="/wiki/Holy_League_(1717)" title="Holy League (1717)">1717</a> (composed primarily of <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Spain" title="Habsburg Spain">Habsburg Spain</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">Republic of Genoa</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Republic of Venice</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Knights_Hospitaller" title="Knights Hospitaller">Knights of St. John</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Tuscany" title="Grand Duchy of Tuscany">Grand Duchy of Tuscany</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Savoy" title="Duchy of Savoy">Duchy of Savoy</a>), for the control of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>.
</p><p>In the east, the Ottomans were often at war with Safavid Persia over conflicts stemming from territorial disputes or religious differences between the 16th and 18th centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[102]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman-Persian_Wars" title="Ottoman-Persian Wars">Ottoman wars with Persia</a> continued as the <a href="/wiki/Zand_dynasty" title="Zand dynasty">Zand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afsharid_dynasty" title="Afsharid dynasty">Afsharid</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">Qajar</a> dynasties succeeded the Safavids in Iran, until the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Persian_War_(1821%E2%80%931823)" title="OttomanâPersian War (1821â1823)">first half of the 19th century</a>.
</p><p>Even further east, there was an extension of the Habsburg-Ottoman conflict, in that the Ottomans also had to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_expedition_to_Aceh" title="Ottoman expedition to Aceh">send soldiers</a> to their farthest and easternmost vassal and territory, the <a href="/wiki/Aceh_Sultanate" title="Aceh Sultanate">Aceh Sultanate</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[104]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, to defend it from European colonizers as well as the <a href="/wiki/Juan_de_Salcedo" title="Juan de Salcedo">Latino invaders</a> who had crossed from <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> and had Christianized the formerly Muslim-dominated <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_the_Philippines" title="Islam in the Philippines">Philippines</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the 16th to the early 20th centuries, the Ottoman Empire also <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_Wars" title="Russo-Turkish Wars">fought twelve wars</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Russian Tsardom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Empire</a>. These were initially about Ottoman territorial expansion and consolidation in southeastern and eastern Europe; but starting from the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1768%E2%80%931774)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1768â1774)">Russo-Turkish War (1768â1774)</a>, they became more about the survival of the Ottoman Empire, which had begun to lose its strategic territories on the northern <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> coast to the advancing Russians.
</p><p>From the second half of the 18th century onwards, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Decline of the Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire began to decline</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a> reforms, initiated by <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_II" title="Mahmud II">Mahmud II</a> just before his death in 1839, aimed to modernise the Ottoman state in line with the progress that had been made in Western Europe. The efforts of <a href="/wiki/Midhat_Pasha" title="Midhat Pasha">Midhat Pasha</a> during the late Tanzimat era led the Ottoman <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_constitution_of_1876" title="Ottoman constitution of 1876">constitutional movement of 1876</a>, which introduced the <a href="/wiki/First_Constitutional_Era" title="First Constitutional Era">First Constitutional Era</a>, but these efforts proved to be inadequate in most fields, and failed to stop the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Dissolution of the Ottoman Empire">dissolution of the empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OttoTurkVis_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-OttoTurkVis-107">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>As the empire gradually shrank in size, military power and wealth; especially after the <a href="/wiki/Great_Eastern_Crisis" title="Great Eastern Crisis">Ottoman economic crisis and default</a> in 1875<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NiallFergusonFT_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-NiallFergusonFT-108">[107]</a></sup> which led to uprisings in the Balkan provinces that culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%931878)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877â1878)">Russo-Turkish War (1877â1878)</a>; many Balkan Muslims migrated to the Empire's heartland in Anatolia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Illinois2009_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-Illinois2009-109">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[109]</a></sup> along with the <a href="/wiki/Circassians" title="Circassians">Circassians</a> fleeing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian%E2%80%93Circassian_War" title="RussianâCircassian War">Russian conquest</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_conquest_of_the_Caucasus" title="Russian conquest of the Caucasus">Caucasus</a>.
