According to some estimates, up to 1.5 million Muslim <a href="/wiki/Circassians" title="Circassians">Circassians</a> died during the <a href="/wiki/Circassian_genocide" title="Circassian genocide">Circassian genocide</a>, the survivors seek refugee in <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. The decline of the Ottoman Empire led to a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rise_of_nationalism_under_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Rise of nationalism under the Ottoman Empire">rise in nationalist sentiment among its various subject peoples</a>, leading to increased ethnic tensions which occasionally burst into violence, such as the <a href="/wiki/Hamidian_massacres" title="Hamidian massacres">Hamidian massacres</a> of <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Armenians in the Ottoman Empire">Armenians</a>, which claimed up to 300,000 lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nzhistory.net.nz_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-nzhistory.net.nz-111">[110]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Central_Powers_monarchs_postcard.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1060" data-file-width="1640" decoding="async" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Central_Powers_monarchs_postcard.jpg/290px-Central_Powers_monarchs_postcard.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Central_Powers_monarchs_postcard.jpg/435px-Central_Powers_monarchs_postcard.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Central_Powers_monarchs_postcard.jpg/580px-Central_Powers_monarchs_postcard.jpg 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Central_Powers_monarchs_postcard.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><div class="plainlist nowrap"><ul><li>Central Power Monarchs on a WWI Postcard:</li><li>Kaiser <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor" title="Wilhelm II, German Emperor">Wilhelm II</a> of Germany;</li><li>Kaiser and King <a href="/wiki/Franz_Joseph_I_of_Austria" title="Franz Joseph I of Austria">Franz Joseph</a> of Austria-Hungary;</li><li>Sultan <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_V" title="Mehmed V">Mehmed V</a> of the Ottoman Empire;</li><li>Tsar <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_I_of_Bulgaria" title="Ferdinand I of Bulgaria">Ferdinand I</a> of Bulgaria</li></ul></div></div></div></div>
<p>The loss of <a href="/wiki/Rumelia" title="Rumelia">Rumelia</a> (Ottoman territories in Europe) with the <a href="/wiki/First_Balkan_War" title="First Balkan War">First Balkan War</a> (1912â1913) was followed by the arrival of millions of Muslim refugees (<i><a href="/wiki/Muhacir" title="Muhacir">muhacir</a></i>) to Istanbul and Anatolia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[111]</a></sup> Historically, the <a href="/wiki/Rumelia_Eyalet" title="Rumelia Eyalet">Rumelia Eyalet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anatolia_Eyalet" title="Anatolia Eyalet">Anatolia Eyalet</a> had formed the <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Administrative divisions of the Ottoman Empire">administrative</a> core of the Ottoman Empire, with their governors titled <a href="/wiki/Beylerbey" title="Beylerbey">Beylerbeyi</a> participating in the Sultan's <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Council_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Imperial Council (Ottoman Empire)">Divan</a>, so the loss of all Balkan provinces beyond the <a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1y%C4%B1k%C3%B6y" title="KÄ±yÄ±kÃ¶y">Midye</a>-<a href="/wiki/Enez" title="Enez">Enez</a> border line according to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Conference_of_1912%E2%80%9313" title="London Conference of 1912â13">London Conference of 1912â13</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1913)" title="Treaty of London (1913)">Treaty of London (1913)</a> was a major shock for the Ottoman society and led to the <a href="/wiki/1913_Ottoman_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1913 Ottoman coup d'Ã©tat">1913 Ottoman coup d'Ã©tat</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/Second_Balkan_War" title="Second Balkan War">Second Balkan War</a> (1913) the Ottomans managed to recover their former capital <a href="/wiki/Edirne" title="Edirne">Edirne</a> (Adrianople) and its surrounding areas in <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">East Thrace</a>, which was formalised with the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Constantinople_(1913)" title="Treaty of Constantinople (1913)">Treaty of Constantinople (1913)</a>. The 1913 coup d'Ã©tat effectively put the country under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Pashas" title="Three Pashas">Three Pashas</a>, making sultans <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_V" title="Mehmed V">Mehmed V</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_VI" title="Mehmed VI">Mehmed VI</a> largely symbolic figureheads with no real political power.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marcharmenians.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1439" data-file-width="2193" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Marcharmenians.jpg/220px-Marcharmenians.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Marcharmenians.jpg/330px-Marcharmenians.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Marcharmenians.jpg/440px-Marcharmenians.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Marcharmenians.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Armenian civilians being deported during the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide" title="Armenian genocide">Armenian genocide</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Ottoman Empire entered <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> on the side of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> and was ultimately defeated. The Ottomans successfully defended the <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">Dardanelles</a> strait during the <a href="/wiki/Gallipoli_campaign" title="Gallipoli campaign">Gallipoli campaign</a> (1915â1916) and achieved initial victories against British forces in the first two years of the <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamian_campaign" title="Mesopotamian campaign">Mesopotamian campaign</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Kut" title="Siege of Kut">Siege of Kut</a> (1915â1916); but the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Revolt" title="Arab Revolt">Arab Revolt</a> (1916â1918) turned the tide against the Ottomans in the Middle East. In the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_campaign" title="Caucasus campaign">Caucasus campaign</a>, however, the Russian forces had the upper hand from the beginning, especially after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sarikamish" title="Battle of Sarikamish">Battle of Sarikamish</a> (1914â1915). Russian forces advanced into northeastern Anatolia and controlled the major cities there until retreating from World War I with the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk" title="Treaty of Brest-Litovsk">Treaty of Brest-Litovsk</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> (1917). During the war, the empire's Armenian subjects were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tehcir_Law" title="Tehcir Law">deported</a> to <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide" title="Armenian genocide">Armenian genocide</a>. As a result, an estimated 600,000<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica-ag_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-ag-113">[112]</a></sup> to more than 1 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica-ag_113-1"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-ag-113">[112]</a></sup> or up to 1.5 million<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-umichigan_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-umichigan-114">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jfreedman_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-jfreedman-115">[114]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-totten-et-al_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-totten-et-al-116">[115]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Armenians in the Ottoman Empire">Armenians</a> were killed. The Turkish government has <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide_denial" title="Armenian genocide denial">refused to acknowledge</a> the events as <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a> and states that Armenians were only <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer" title="Population transfer">"relocated</a>" from the eastern war zone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[116]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Late_Ottoman_genocides" title="Late Ottoman genocides">Genocidal campaigns</a> were also committed against the empire's other minority groups such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assyrian_genocide" title="Assyrian genocide">Assyrians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_genocide" title="Greek genocide">Greeks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloxham2005_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bloxham2005-118">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Levene_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-Levene-119">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ferguson_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ferguson-120">[119]</a></sup> 
Following the <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Mudros" title="Armistice of Mudros">Armistice of Mudros</a> on 30 October 1918, the victorious <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied Powers</a> sought to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Partitioning_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Partitioning of the Ottoman Empire">partition the Ottoman state</a> through the 1920 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of SÃ¨vres">Treaty of SÃ¨vres</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Treaty_of_SÃ¨vres_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-Treaty_of_SÃ¨vres-121">[120]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Republic_of_Turkey">Republic of Turkey</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="History of the Republic of Turkey">History of the Republic of Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="540" data-file-width="780" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg/220px-Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg/330px-Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg/440px-Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ataturk_and_Fethi_Okyar.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk">Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk</a>, founder and first President of the Turkish Republic, with the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Republican_Party_(Turkey)" title="Liberal Republican Party (Turkey)">Liberal Republican Party</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Fethi_Okyar" title="Fethi Okyar">Fethi Okyar</a> (right) and Okyar's daughter in <a href="/wiki/Yalova" title="Yalova">Yalova</a>, 13 August 1930.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Constantinople" title="Occupation of Constantinople">occupation of Istanbul</a> (1918) and <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Smyrna" title="Occupation of Smyrna">Ä°zmir</a> (1919) by the Allies in the aftermath of World War I prompted the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_National_Movement" title="Turkish National Movement">Turkish National Movement</a>. Under the leadership of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Pasha" title="Mustafa Kemal Pasha">Mustafa Kemal Pasha</a>, a military commander who had distinguished himself during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gallipoli" title="Battle of Gallipoli">Battle of Gallipoli</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">Turkish War of Independence</a> (1919â1923) was waged with the aim of revoking the terms of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of SÃ¨vres">Treaty of SÃ¨vres</a> (1920).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AtatÃ¼rk_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-AtatÃ¼rk-122">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>By 18 September 1922 the Greek, Armenian and French armies had been expelled,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18sep1922_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-18sep1922-123">[122]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Provisional_Government" title="Turkish Provisional Government">Turkish Provisional Government</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a>, which had declared itself the legitimate government of the country on <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">23 April 1920</a>, started to formalise the legal transition from the old Ottoman into the new Republican political system. On 1 November 1922, the Turkish Parliament in Ankara formally <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_Ottoman_Sultanate" title="Abolition of the Ottoman Sultanate">abolished the Sultanate</a>, thus ending 623 years of monarchical Ottoman rule. The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a> of 24 July 1923, which superseded the Treaty of SÃ¨vres,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Treaty_of_SÃ¨vres_121-1"><a href="#cite_note-Treaty_of_SÃ¨vres-121">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AtatÃ¼rk_122-1"><a href="#cite_note-AtatÃ¼rk-122">[121]</a></sup> led to the international recognition of the sovereignty of the newly formed "Republic of Turkey" as the successor state of the Ottoman Empire, and the republic was officially proclaimed on 29 October 1923 in Ankara, the country's new capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[123]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Convention_Concerning_the_Exchange_of_Greek_and_Turkish_Populations" title="Convention Concerning the Exchange of Greek and Turkish Populations">Lausanne Convention</a> stipulated a <a href="/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey" title="Population exchange between Greece and Turkey">population exchange between Greece and Turkey</a>, whereby 1.1Â million Greeks left Turkey for Greece in exchange for 380,000 Muslims transferred from Greece to Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Clogg_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-Clogg-125">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_(1935).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="815" data-file-width="1067" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg/220px-First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg/330px-First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg/440px-First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_%281935%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:First_female_MPs_of_the_Turkish_Parliament_(1935).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Eighteen female <a href="/wiki/Member_of_parliament" title="Member of parliament">deputies</a> joined the <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">Turkish Parliament</a> with the <a href="/wiki/1935_Turkish_general_election" title="1935 Turkish general election">1935 general elections</a>. Turkish women gained the <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_women%27s_suffrage" title="Timeline of women's suffrage">right to vote and to hold elected office</a> as a mark of the far-reaching <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="AtatÃ¼rk's Reforms">social changes</a> initiated by <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk">AtatÃ¼rk</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[125]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Mustafa Kemal became the republic's first <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">President</a> and subsequently introduced <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="AtatÃ¼rk's Reforms">many reforms</a>. The reforms aimed to transform the old <a href="/wiki/Millet_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Millet (Ottoman Empire)">religion-based and multi-communal</a> Ottoman <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> into a Turkish <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a> that would be governed as a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a> under a <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution_of_1924" title="Turkish Constitution of 1924">secular constitution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BoweringCrone2012_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-BoweringCrone2012-127">[126]</a></sup> With the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Surname_Law" title="Surname Law">Surname Law</a> of 1934, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Parliament" title="Turkish Parliament">Turkish Parliament</a> bestowed upon Mustafa Kemal the honorific surname "AtatÃ¼rk" (<i>Father Turk</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AtatÃ¼rk_122-2"><a href="#cite_note-AtatÃ¼rk-122">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Montreux_Convention_Regarding_the_Regime_of_the_Straits" title="Montreux Convention Regarding the Regime of the Straits">Montreux Convention</a> (1936) restored Turkey's control over the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Straits" title="Turkish Straits">Turkish Straits</a>, including the right to militarise the coastlines of the <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">Dardanelles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bosporus" title="Bosporus">Bosporus</a> straits and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara" title="Sea of Marmara">Sea of Marmara</a>, and to block maritime traffic in wartime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the establishment of the Republic of Turkey in 1923, some <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurdish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zazas" title="Zazas">Zaza</a> tribes, which were <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudal</a> (<a href="/wiki/Manorialism" title="Manorialism">manorial</a>) communities led by <a href="/wiki/Tribal_chief" title="Tribal chief">chieftains</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Agha_(title)" title="Agha (title)">agha</a></i>) during the Ottoman period, became discontent about certain aspects of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk%27s_Reforms" title="AtatÃ¼rk's Reforms">AtatÃ¼rk's reforms</a> aiming to modernise the country, such as <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secularism</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Sheikh_Said_rebellion" title="Sheikh Said rebellion">Sheikh Said rebellion</a>, 1925)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[128]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Land_reform" title="Land reform">land reform</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Dersim_rebellion" title="Dersim rebellion">Dersim rebellion</a>, 1937â1938),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[129]</a></sup> and staged armed revolts that were put down with military operations.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/%C4%B0smet_%C4%B0n%C3%B6n%C3%BC" title="Ä°smet Ä°nÃ¶nÃ¼">Ä°smet Ä°nÃ¶nÃ¼</a> became Turkey's second President following AtatÃ¼rk's death on 10 November 1938. On 29 June 1939, the <a href="/wiki/Hatay_State" title="Hatay State">Republic of Hatay</a> voted in favour of joining Turkey with a referendum. Turkey <a href="/wiki/Second_Cairo_Conference" title="Second Cairo Conference">remained neutral</a> during most of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, but entered the closing stages of the war on the side of the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> on 23 February 1945. On 26 June 1945, Turkey became a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Charter" title="United Nations Charter">charter member</a> of the United Nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turkey_UN_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-Turkey_UN-131">[130]</a></sup> In the following year, the <a href="/wiki/One-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="One-party period of the Republic of Turkey">one-party period</a> in Turkey came to an end, with the <a href="/wiki/1946_Turkish_general_election" title="1946 Turkish general election">first multi-party elections in 1946</a>. In 1950 Turkey became a member of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1209" data-file-width="1512" decoding="async" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg/220px-Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg/330px-Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg/440px-Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Roosevelt_In%C3%B6n%C3%BC_and_Churchill_in_Cairo_cph.3b15312.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Roosevelt</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0smet_%C4%B0n%C3%B6n%C3%BC" title="Ä°smet Ä°nÃ¶nÃ¼">Ä°nÃ¶nÃ¼</a> and <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Churchill</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Second_Cairo_Conference" title="Second Cairo Conference">Second Cairo Conference</a>, 1943.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Democrat_Party_(Turkey,_1946%E2%80%931961)" title="Democrat Party (Turkey, 1946â1961)">Democrat Party</a> established by <a href="/wiki/Cel%C3%A2l_Bayar" title="CelÃ¢l Bayar">CelÃ¢l Bayar</a> won the <a href="/wiki/1950_Turkish_general_election" title="1950 Turkish general election">1950</a>, <a href="/wiki/1954_Turkish_general_election" title="1954 Turkish general election">1954</a> and <a href="/wiki/1957_Turkish_general_election" title="1957 Turkish general election">1957</a> general elections and stayed in power for a decade, with <a href="/wiki/Adnan_Menderes" title="Adnan Menderes">Adnan Menderes</a> as the Prime Minister and Bayar as the President. After fighting as part of the United Nations forces in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>, Turkey joined <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> in 1952, becoming a bulwark against Soviet expansion into the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" title="Mediterranean Basin">Mediterranean</a>. Turkey subsequently became a founding member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a> in 1961, and an <a href="/wiki/Ankara_Agreement" title="Ankara Agreement">associate member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">EEC</a> in 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd.org_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-oecd.org-132">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>The country's tumultuous transition to <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Multi-party period of the Republic of Turkey">multi-party democracy</a> was interrupted by military <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'Ã©tat">coups d'Ã©tat</a> in <a href="/wiki/1960_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1960 Turkish coup d'Ã©tat">1960</a> and <a href="/wiki/1980_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1980 Turkish coup d'Ã©tat">1980</a>, as well as by military memorandums in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1971_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1971 Turkish coup d'Ã©tat">1971</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1997_military_memorandum_(Turkey)" title="1997 military memorandum (Turkey)">1997</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TRPoliticsandMilitary_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-TRPoliticsandMilitary-133">[132]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[133]</a></sup> Between 1960 and the end of the 20th century, the prominent leaders in Turkish politics who achieved multiple election victories were <a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCleyman_Demirel" title="SÃ¼leyman Demirel">SÃ¼leyman Demirel</a>, <a href="/wiki/B%C3%BClent_Ecevit" title="BÃ¼lent Ecevit">BÃ¼lent Ecevit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turgut_%C3%96zal" title="Turgut Ãzal">Turgut Ãzal</a>. <a href="/wiki/Tansu_%C3%87iller" title="Tansu Ãiller">Tansu Ãiller</a> became the first female prime minister of Turkey in 1993.
</p><p>Following a decade of <a href="/wiki/Cypriot_intercommunal_violence" title="Cypriot intercommunal violence">Cypriot intercommunal violence</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1974_Cypriot_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1974 Cypriot coup d'Ã©tat">coup in Cyprus on 15 July 1974</a> staged by the <a href="/wiki/EOKA_B" title="EOKA B">EOKA B</a> paramilitary organisation, which overthrew President <a href="/wiki/Makarios_III" title="Makarios III">Makarios</a> and installed the pro-<a href="/wiki/Enosis" title="Enosis">Enosis</a> (union with Greece) <a href="/wiki/Nikos_Sampson" title="Nikos Sampson">Nikos Sampson</a> as dictator, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_invasion_of_Cyprus" title="Turkish invasion of Cyprus">Turkey invaded Cyprus</a> on 20 July 1974 by unilaterally exercising Article IV in the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Guarantee_(1960)" title="Treaty of Guarantee (1960)">Treaty of Guarantee (1960)</a>, but without restoring the <a href="/wiki/Status_quo_ante_bellum" title="Status quo ante bellum">status quo ante</a> at the end of the military operation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Uslu2003_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-Uslu2003-135">[134]</a></sup> In 1983 the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Republic_of_Northern_Cyprus" title="Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus">Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus</a>, which is recognised only by Turkey, was established.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-trnc_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-trnc-136">[135]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Annan_Plan_for_Cyprus" title="Annan Plan for Cyprus">Annan Plan</a> for reunifying the island was supported by the majority of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Cypriots" title="Turkish Cypriots">Turkish Cypriots</a>, but rejected by the majority of <a href="/wiki/Greek_Cypriots" title="Greek Cypriots">Greek Cypriots</a>, in separate <a href="/wiki/2004_Cypriot_Annan_Plan_referendums" title="2004 Cypriot Annan Plan referendums">referendums in 2004</a>. However, negotiations for solving the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyprus_dispute" title="Cyprus dispute">Cyprus dispute</a> are still ongoing between Turkish Cypriot and Greek Cypriot political leaders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Kurdish%E2%80%93Turkish_conflict_(1978%E2%80%93present)" title="KurdishâTurkish conflict (1978âpresent)">conflict</a> between Turkey and the <a href="/wiki/Kurdistan_Workers%27_Party" title="Kurdistan Workers' Party">Kurdistan Workers' Party</a> (PKK) (designated a <a href="/wiki/List_of_designated_terrorist_groups" title="List of designated terrorist groups">terrorist organisation</a> by Turkey, the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-department-of-state-list_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-department-of-state-list-138">[137]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-european-council-list_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-european-council-list-139">[138]</a></sup>) has been active since 1984, primarily in the southeast of the country. More than 40,000 people have died as a result of the conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[141]</a></sup> In 1999 PKK's founder <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_%C3%96calan" title="Abdullah Ãcalan">Abdullah Ãcalan</a> was arrested and sentenced for <a href="/wiki/Terrorism" title="Terrorism">terrorism</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-department-of-state-list_138-1"><a href="#cite_note-department-of-state-list-138">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-european-council-list_139-1"><a href="#cite_note-european-council-list-139">[138]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Treason" title="Treason">treason</a> charges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc-29-06-1999_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-29-06-1999-143">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc-03-10-2002_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-03-10-2002-144">[143]</a></sup> In the past, various <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kurdish_people" title="Kurdish people">Kurdish</a> groups have unsuccessfully sought <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_separatism" title="Ethnic separatism">separation</a> from Turkey to create an independent <a href="/wiki/Kurdistan" title="Kurdistan">Kurdish state</a>, while others have more recently pursued provincial <a href="/wiki/Autonomy" title="Autonomy">autonomy</a> and greater <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_of_Kurdish_people_in_Turkey" title="Human rights of Kurdish people in Turkey">political and cultural rights</a> for Kurds in Turkey. In the 21st century some reforms have taken place to improve the cultural rights of ethnic minorities in Turkey, such as the establishment of <a href="/wiki/TRT_Kurd%C3%AE" title="TRT KurdÃ®">TRT KurdÃ®</a>, <a href="/wiki/TRT_Arabi" title="TRT Arabi">TRT Arabi</a> and <a href="/wiki/TRT_Avaz" title="TRT Avaz">TRT Avaz</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Radio_and_Television_Corporation" title="Turkish Radio and Television Corporation">TRT</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:257px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ankara_asv2021-10_img04_An%C4%B1tkabir.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3797" data-file-width="7594" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Ankara_asv2021-10_img04_An%C4%B1tkabir.jpg/255px-Ankara_asv2021-10_img04_An%C4%B1tkabir.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Ankara_asv2021-10_img04_An%C4%B1tkabir.jpg/383px-Ankara_asv2021-10_img04_An%C4%B1tkabir.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Ankara_asv2021-10_img04_An%C4%B1tkabir.jpg/510px-Ankara_asv2021-10_img04_An%C4%B1tkabir.jpg 2x" width="255"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ankara_asv2021-10_img04_An%C4%B1tkabir.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/An%C4%B1tkabir" title="AnÄ±tkabir">AnÄ±tkabir</a>, the mausoleum of <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk">Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a>, is visited by large crowds every year during national holidays, such as Republic Day on 29 October.</div></div></div>
<p>Since the liberalisation of the Turkish economy in the 1980s, the country has enjoyed stronger economic growth and greater political stability.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80sLiberalization_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-80sLiberalization-145">[144]</a></sup> Turkey applied for full membership of the EEC in 1987, joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">EU Customs Union</a> in 1995 and started <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">accession negotiations</a> with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_EUChrono_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-TR_EUChrono-146">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-barroso_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-barroso-147">[146]</a></sup> In a non-binding vote on 13 March 2019, the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> called on the EU governments to suspend EU accession talks with Turkey, citing violations of human rights and the rule of law; but the negotiations, effectively on hold since 2018, remain active as of 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dw-13-03-2019_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-dw-13-03-2019-148">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2013_protests_in_Turkey" title="2013 protests in Turkey">widespread protests</a> erupted in many Turkish provinces, sparked by a plan to demolish <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gezi_Park" title="Gezi Park">Gezi Park</a> but soon growing into general anti-government dissent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[148]</a></sup> On 15 July 2016, an <a href="/wiki/2016_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2016 Turkish coup d'Ã©tat attempt">unsuccessful coup attempt</a> tried to oust the government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[149]</a></sup> As a reaction to the failed coup d'Ã©tat, the government carried out <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Turkish_purges" title="2016â17 Turkish purges">mass purges</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes.comxx_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.comxx-151">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkeypurge.com_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-turkeypurge.com-152">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Between 9 October and 25 November 2019, Turkey <a href="/wiki/2019_Turkish_offensive_into_north-eastern_Syria" title="2019 Turkish offensive into north-eastern Syria">invaded north-eastern Syria</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[153]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[154]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Turkey" title="Administrative divisions of Turkey">Administrative divisions of Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regions_of_Turkey" title="Regions of Turkey">Regions of Turkey</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NUTS_of_Turkey" title="NUTS of Turkey">NUTS of Turkey</a></div>
<p>Turkey has a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> structure in terms of administration and this aspect is one of the most important factors shaping the Turkish public administration. When three powers (executive, legislative and judiciary) are taken into account as the main functions of the state, local administrations have little power. Turkey does not have a <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federal</a> system, and the provinces are subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Central_government" title="Central government">central government</a> in Ankara. Local administrations were established to provide services in place and the government is represented by the province governors (<i>vali</i>) and town governors (<i>kaymakam</i>). Other senior public officials are also appointed by the central government instead of the mayors (<i>belediye baÅkanÄ±</i>) or elected by constituents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-justice.gov.tr_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-justice.gov.tr-156">[155]</a></sup> Turkish municipalities have local legislative bodies (<i>belediye meclisi</i>) for decision-making on municipal issues.
</p><p>Within this unitary framework, Turkey is subdivided into 81 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Turkey" title="Provinces of Turkey">provinces</a> (<i>il</i> or <i>vilayet</i>) for administrative purposes. Each province is divided into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Districts_of_Turkey" title="Districts of Turkey">districts</a> (<i>ilÃ§e</i>), for a total of 973 districts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[156]</a></sup> Turkey is also subdivided into 7 <a href="/wiki/Geographical_regions_of_Turkey" title="Geographical regions of Turkey">regions</a> (<i>bÃ¶lge</i>) and 21 subregions for geographic, demographic and economic purposes; this does not refer to an administrative division.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Turkey" title="Government of Turkey">Government of Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Turkey" title="Politics of Turkey">Politics of Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">Constitution of Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" href="/wiki/Presidential_Complex_(Turkey)" title="Presidential Complex (Turkey)">Presidential Complex</a>, residence and workplace of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">President of Turkey</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg"><img alt="The Court of Cassation" data-file-height="2268" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg/200px-Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg/300px-Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg/400px-Court_of_Cassation_in_Ankara2.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Cassation_(Turkey)" title="Court of Cassation (Turkey)">Court of Cassation</a> is Turkey's <a href="/wiki/Supreme_court" title="Supreme court">supreme court</a> for reviewing verdicts given by courts of criminal and civil justice.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a> within a <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Multi-party period of the Republic of Turkey">multi-party system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAFactbookTurkey_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIAFactbookTurkey-158">[157]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">current constitution</a> was approved by <a href="/wiki/1982_Turkish_constitutional_referendum" title="1982 Turkish constitutional referendum">referendum in 1982</a>, which determines the government's structure, lays forth the ideals and standards of the state's conduct, andÂ setsÂ out the state's responsibility to its citizens. Furthermore, the constitution specifies the people's rights and obligations, as well as principles for the delegation and exercise of sovereignty that belongs to the people of Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Turkish <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary system</a>, citizens are subject to <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Turkey" title="Administrative divisions of Turkey">three levels of government</a>: national, provincial, and local. The <a href="/wiki/Local_government" title="Local government">local government</a>'s duties are commonly split between <a href="/wiki/Municipal_corporation" title="Municipal corporation">municipal governments</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Districts_of_Turkey" title="Districts of Turkey">districts</a>, in which executive and legislative officials are elected by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" title="Plurality voting system">plurality vote</a> of citizens by district. Turkey is subdivided into <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Turkey" title="Provinces of Turkey">81 provinces</a> for administrative purposes. Each province is divided into districts, for a total of <a href="/wiki/List_of_districts_in_Turkey" title="List of districts in Turkey">973 districts</a>.
</p><p>The government, regulated by a system of <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">separation of powers</a> as defined by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">constitution of Turkey</a>, comprises three branches:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">Legislative</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">Parliament</a> makes <a href="/wiki/Law" title="Law">law</a>, debates and adopts the budget bills, <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_war" title="Declaration of war">declares war</a>, approves treaties, proclaims <a href="/wiki/Amnesty" title="Amnesty">amnesty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pardon" title="Pardon">pardon</a>, and has the power of <a href="/wiki/Impeachment" title="Impeachment">impeachment</a>, by which it can remove sitting members of the government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[159]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">Executive</a>: <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">The president</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the military, can veto <a href="/wiki/Bill_(law)" title="Bill (law)">legislative bills</a> before they become law (subject to parliamentary override), can issue <a href="/wiki/Decree" title="Decree">presidential decrees</a> on matters regarding executive power with exception of fundamental rights, individual rights and certain political rights (parliamentary laws prevail presidential decrees), and appoints the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Turkey" title="Cabinet of Turkey">members of the Cabinet</a> and other officers, who administer and enforce national laws and policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[160]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">Judicial</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Turkey" title="Constitutional Court of Turkey">Constitutional Court</a> (for <a href="/wiki/Constitutionality" title="Constitutionality">constitutional adjudication</a> and review of individual applications concerning human rights), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Court_of_Cassation_of_Turkey" title="Court of Cassation of Turkey">Court of Cassation</a> (final decision maker in ordinary judiciary), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Council_of_State" title="Turkish Council of State">Council of State</a> (final decision maker in administrative judiciary) and the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Jurisdictional_Disputes" title="Court of Jurisdictional Disputes">Court of Jurisdictional Disputes</a> (for resolving the disputes between courts for constitutional jurisdiction) are the four organizations that are described by the Constitution as supreme courts. The judges of the Constitutional Court are appointed by the president and the parliament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitution2019_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution2019-5">[5]</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>The Parliament has 600 voting members, each representing a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constituency" title="Constituency">constituency</a> for a five-year term. Parliamentary seats are distributed among the provinces by population, conform with the census apportionment. The president is <a href="/wiki/Turkish_presidential_elections" title="Turkish presidential elections">elected</a> by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct_vote" title="Direct vote">direct vote</a> and serves a five-year term. The president can't run for re-elections after two terms of five-years, unless parliament prematurely renews the presidential elections during the second term of the President. Elections for the Parliament and presidential elections are held on the same day. The Constitutional Court is composed of fifteen members. A member is elected for a term of twelve years and can't be reelected. The members of the Constitutional Court are obliged to retire when they are over the age of sixty-five.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[161]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parties_and_elections">Parties and elections</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Turkey" title="Elections in Turkey">Elections in Turkey</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_parties_in_Turkey" title="Political parties in Turkey">Political parties in Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Electoral_cycle_of_Turkey" title="Electoral cycle of Turkey">Electoral cycle of Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright" style=""><div class="thumbinner" style="width:162px"><div class="thumbimage noresize" style="width:160px;">
<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG"><img alt="Recep Tayyip Erdogan.PNG" data-file-height="488" data-file-width="370" decoding="async" height="211" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG/160px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG/240px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG/320px-Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan.PNG 2x" width="160"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip ErdoÄan">Recep Tayyip ErdoÄan</a><br/><small><a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">President</a></small></div></div></div></div>
<p>Elections in Turkey are held for six functions of <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Turkey" title="Government of Turkey">government</a>: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_presidential_elections" title="Turkish presidential elections">presidential elections</a> (national), <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">parliamentary elections</a> (national), <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_municipalities_in_Turkey" title="Metropolitan municipalities in Turkey">municipality mayors</a> (local), <a href="/wiki/List_of_districts_in_Turkey" title="List of districts in Turkey">district mayors</a> (local), <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Turkey" title="Provinces of Turkey">provincial</a> or <a href="/wiki/List_of_municipalities_in_Turkey" title="List of municipalities in Turkey">municipal council members</a> (local) and <a href="/wiki/Muhtar_(title)" title="Muhtar (title)">muhtars</a> (local). Apart from elections, <a href="/wiki/Referendum" title="Referendum">referenda</a> are also held occasionally.
</p><p>Every Turkish citizen who has turned 18 has the <a href="/wiki/Suffrage" title="Suffrage">right to vote</a> and stand as a candidate at elections. <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">Universal suffrage</a> for both sexes has been applied throughout Turkey since 1934 and before most countries. In Turkey, <a href="/wiki/Voter_turnout" title="Voter turnout">turnout rates</a> of both local and general elections are high compared to many other countries, which usually stands higher than 80 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[162]</a></sup> There are 600 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament" title="Member of Parliament">members of parliament</a> who are elected for a five-year term by a <a href="/wiki/Party-list_proportional_representation" title="Party-list proportional representation">party-list proportional representation</a> system from 88 electoral districts. 
The Constitutional Court can strip the public financing of <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Turkey" title="List of political parties in Turkey">political parties</a> that it deems <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Turkey" title="Secularism in Turkey">anti-secular</a> or having ties to <a href="/wiki/Terrorism_in_Turkey" title="Terrorism in Turkey">terrorism</a>, or ban their existence altogether.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[163]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[164]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Electoral_threshold" title="Electoral threshold">electoral threshold</a> for political parties at national level is seven percent of the votes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[165]</a></sup> Smaller parties can avoid the electoral threshold by forming an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_alliance" title="Political alliance">alliance</a> with other parties, in which it is sufficient that the total votes of the alliance passes 7%. <a href="/wiki/Independent_politician" title="Independent politician">Independent candidates</a> are not subject to an electoral threshold.
</p><p>After World War II, Turkey operated under a <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_period_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Multi-party period of the Republic of Turkey">multi-party system</a>. On the right side of the Turkish <a href="/wiki/Political_spectrum" title="Political spectrum">political spectrum</a>, parties like <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Turkey,_historical)" title="Democratic Party (Turkey, historical)">Democrat Party</a> (DP), <a href="/wiki/Justice_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice Party (Turkey)">Justice Party</a> (AP), <a href="/wiki/Motherland_Party_(Turkey)" title="Motherland Party (Turkey)">Motherland Party</a> (ANAP) and <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">Justice and Development Party</a> (AKP) once became the largest political party in Turkey. Turkish <a href="/wiki/Right-wing_politics" title="Right-wing politics">right-wing</a> parties are more likely to embrace principles of political ideologies such as <a href="/wiki/Conservatism" title="Conservatism">conservatism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nationalism" title="Nationalism">nationalism</a> or <a href="/wiki/Islamism" title="Islamism">Islamism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[166]</a></sup> On the left side of the spectrum, parties like <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republican_People%27s_Party_(Turkey)" title="Republican People's Party (Turkey)">Republican People's Party</a> (CHP), <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Populist_Party_(Turkey)" title="Social Democratic Populist Party (Turkey)">Social Democratic Populist Party</a> (SHP) and <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Left_Party_(Turkey)" title="Democratic Left Party (Turkey)">Democratic Left Party</a> (DSP) once enjoyed the largest electoral success. <a href="/wiki/Left-wing_politics" title="Left-wing politics">Left-wing</a> parties are more likely to embrace principles of <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kemalism" title="Kemalism">Kemalism</a> or <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secularism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FleetFaroqhi2008p357_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-FleetFaroqhi2008p357-168">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 12th <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdo%C4%9Fan" title="Recep Tayyip ErdoÄan">Recep Tayyip ErdoÄan</a>, the winner of the <a href="/wiki/2018_Turkish_presidential_election" title="2018 Turkish presidential election">2018 presidential election</a> and former <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Turkey" title="Prime Minister of Turkey">prime minister</a>, is currently serving as the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>. <a href="/wiki/Kemal_K%C4%B1l%C4%B1%C3%A7daro%C4%9Flu" title="Kemal KÄ±lÄ±Ã§daroÄlu">Kemal KÄ±lÄ±Ã§daroÄlu</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_main_opposition_leaders_of_Turkey" title="List of the main opposition leaders of Turkey">main opposition leader of Turkey</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_%C5%9Eentop" title="Mustafa Åentop">Mustafa Åentop</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Speaker_of_the_Grand_National_Assembly" title="Speaker of the Grand National Assembly">Speaker of the Grand National Assembly</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/27th_Parliament_of_Turkey" title="27th Parliament of Turkey">27th Parliament of Turkey</a> was installed following the <a href="/wiki/2018_Turkish_parliamentary_election" title="2018 Turkish parliamentary election">2018 parliamentary election</a>, with the starting composition of 295 seats for the <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">Justice and Development Party</a> (AKP), 146 seats for the <a href="/wiki/Republican_People%27s_Party" title="Republican People's Party">Republican People's Party</a> (CHP), 67 seats for the <a href="/wiki/Peoples%27_Democratic_Party_(Turkey)" title="Peoples' Democratic Party (Turkey)">Peoples' Democratic Party</a> (HDP), 49 seats for the <a href="/wiki/Nationalist_Movement_Party" title="Nationalist Movement Party">Nationalist Movement Party</a> (MHP) and 49 seats for the <a href="/wiki/Good_Party" title="Good Party">Good Party</a> (Ä°P).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[168]</a></sup> The next parliamentary election is scheduled to take place in 2023.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Turkey" title="Judicial system of Turkey">Judicial system of Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Turkey" title="Law enforcement in Turkey">Law enforcement in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_(1).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2486" data-file-width="3752" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg/240px-PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg/360px-PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg/480px-PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PalaceOfJusticeIstanbul_(1).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_%C3%87a%C4%9Flayan_Justice_Palace" title="Istanbul ÃaÄlayan Justice Palace">Istanbul ÃaÄlayan Justice Palace</a> is a courthouse in the <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli" title="ÅiÅli">ÅiÅli</a> district of <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>With the founding of the Republic, Turkey adopted a <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> legal system, replacing <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a>-derived <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_law" title="Ottoman law">Ottoman law</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_civil_code_(1926)" title="Turkish civil code (1926)">Civil Code</a>, adopted in 1926, was based on the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Civil_Code" title="Swiss Civil Code">Swiss Civil Code</a> of 1907 and the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Code_of_Obligations" title="Swiss Code of Obligations">Swiss Code of Obligations</a> of 1911. Although it underwent a number of changes in 2002, it retains much of the basis of the original Code. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Criminal_Code" title="Criminal Code">Criminal Code</a>, originally based on the <a href="/wiki/Italian_law_codes#Penal_Code" title="Italian law codes">Italian Criminal Code</a>, was replaced in 2005 by a Code with principles similar to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_Penal_Code" title="German Penal Code">German Penal Code</a> and German law generally. <a href="/wiki/Administrative_law" title="Administrative law">Administrative law</a> is based on the French equivalent and <a href="/wiki/Procedural_law" title="Procedural law">procedural law</a> generally shows the influence of the Swiss, German and French legal systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[169]</a></sup> Islamic principles do not play a part in the legal system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[170]</a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey has adopted the principle of the separation of powers. In line with this principle, judicial power is exercised by independent courts on behalf of the Turkish nation. The independence and organisation of the courts, the security of the tenure of judges and public prosecutors, the profession of judges and prosecutors, the supervision of judges and public prosecutors, the military courts and their organisation, and the powers and duties of the high courts are regulated by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" title="Turkish Constitution">Turkish Constitution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr-172">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Article 142 of the Turkish Constitution, the organisation, duties and jurisdiction of the courts, their functions and the trial procedures are regulated by law. In line with the aforementioned article of the Turkish Constitution and related laws, the court system in Turkey can be classified under three main categories; which are the Judicial Courts, Administrative Courts, and Military Courts. Each category includes first instance courts and high courts. In addition, the Court of Jurisdictional Disputes rules on cases that cannot be classified readily as falling within the purview of one court system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr_172-1"><a href="#cite_note-uhdigm.adalet.gov.tr-172">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Turkey" title="Law enforcement in Turkey">Law enforcement in Turkey</a> is carried out by several agencies under the jurisdiction of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of the Interior (Turkey)">Ministry of Internal Affairs</a>. These agencies are the <a href="/wiki/General_Directorate_of_Security_(Turkey)" title="General Directorate of Security (Turkey)">General Directorate of Security</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie_General_Command" title="Gendarmerie General Command">Gendarmerie General Command</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Coast_Guard_Command_(Turkey)" title="Coast Guard Command (Turkey)">Coast Guard Command</a>. Furthermore, there are other law enforcement agencies with specific (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Intelligence_Organization_(Turkey)" title="National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)">National Intelligence Organization</a>, General Directorate of Customs Protection, etc.) or local (Village guards, Municipal Police, etc.) assignments that are under the jurisdiction of the president or different ministries.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>In the years of government by the AKP and ErdoÄan, particularly since 2013, the independence and integrity of the Turkish judiciary has increasingly been said to be in doubt by institutions, parliamentarians and journalists both within and outside of Turkey; due to political interference in the promotion of judges and prosecutors, and in their pursuit of public duty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU2015_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-EU2015-173">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EP2016_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-EP2016-174">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TI2016_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-TI2016-175">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[175]</a></sup> The <i>Turkey 2015 report</i> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a> stated that "the independence of the judiciary and respect of the principle of separation of powers have been undermined and judges and prosecutors have been under strong political pressure."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU2015_173-1"><a href="#cite_note-EU2015-173">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Turkey" title="Foreign relations of Turkey">Foreign relations of Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png/220px-EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png/330px-EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png/440px-EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:EU_and_Turkey_Locator_Map.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>After becoming <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Member states of the Council of Europe">one of the early members</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> in 1950, Turkey became an <a href="/wiki/Ankara_Agreement" title="Ankara Agreement">associate member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">EEC</a> in 1963, joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">EU Customs Union</a> in 1995 and started <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">full membership negotiations</a> with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_EUChrono_146-1"><a href="#cite_note-TR_EUChrono-146">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-barroso_147-1"><a href="#cite_note-barroso-147">[146]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Turkey is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Turkey_and_the_United_Nations" title="Turkey and the United Nations">United Nations</a> (1945),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign3_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign3-177">[176]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> (1961),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign1_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign1-178">[177]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a> (1969),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign4_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign4-179">[178]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a> (1973),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign5_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign5-180">[179]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Economic_Cooperation_Organization" title="Economic Cooperation Organization">ECO</a> (1985),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign6_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign6-181">[180]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_the_Black_Sea_Economic_Cooperation" title="Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation">BSEC</a> (1992),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign7_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign7-182">[181]</a></sup> the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developing_8_Countries" title="Developing 8 Countries">D-8</a> (1997)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign8_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign8-183">[182]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> (1999).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign2_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign2-184">[183]</a></sup> Turkey was a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> in 1951â1952, 1954â1955, 1961 and 2009â2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HÃ¼rriyet_UN_Security_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-HÃ¼rriyet_UN_Security-185">[184]</a></sup> In 2012 Turkey became a dialogue partner of the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">SCO</a>, and in 2013 became a member of the <a href="/wiki/Asia_Cooperation_Dialogue" title="Asia Cooperation Dialogue">ACD</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AFGTUR_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-AFGTUR-186">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkeyjoin_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-turkeyjoin-187">[186]</a></sup>
</p><p>In line with its traditional Western orientation, relations with Europe have always been a central part of Turkish foreign policy. Turkey became <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Member states of the Council of Europe">one of the early members</a> of the Council of Europe in 1950, applied for associate membership of the EEC (predecessor of the European Union) in 1959 and became an associate member in 1963. After decades of political negotiations, Turkey applied for full membership of the EEC in 1987, became an associate member of the <a href="/wiki/Western_European_Union" title="Western European Union">Western European Union</a> in 1992, joined the EU Customs Union in 1995 and has been in formal accession negotiations with the EU since 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_EUChrono_146-2"><a href="#cite_note-TR_EUChrono-146">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-barroso_147-2"><a href="#cite_note-barroso-147">[146]</a></sup> Turkey's support for <a href="/wiki/Northern_Cyprus" title="Northern Cyprus">Northern Cyprus</a> in the Cyprus dispute complicates Turkey's relations with the EU and remains a major stumbling block to the country's EU accession bid.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mardell_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mardell-188">[187]</a></sup>
</p><p>The other defining aspect of Turkey's foreign policy was the country's long-standing strategic alliance with the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-foreignaffairs.com_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-foreignaffairs.com-189">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fas.org_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-fas.org-190">[189]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Truman_Doctrine" title="Truman Doctrine">Truman Doctrine</a> in 1947 enunciated American intentions to guarantee the security of Turkey and Greece during the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, and resulted in large-scale <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkey-United_States_relations" title="Turkey-United States relations">U.S. military and economic support</a>. In 1948 both countries were included in the <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_European_Economic_Co-operation" title="Organisation for European Economic Co-operation">OEEC</a> for rebuilding European economies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Truman_Doctrine_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-Truman_Doctrine-191">[190]</a></sup> The common threat posed by the Soviet Union during the Cold War led to Turkey's membership of NATO in 1952, ensuring close bilateral relations with the US. Subsequently, Turkey benefited from the United States' political, economic and diplomatic support, including in key issues such as the country's bid to join the European Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[191]</a></sup> In the postâCold War environment, Turkey's geostrategic importance shifted towards its proximity to the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> and the Balkans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edoc.hu-berlin.de_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-edoc.hu-berlin.de-193">[192]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9D%D0%90%D0%A2%D0%9E_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82_2021_NATO_Summit_2021_-14.06.2021-_(51246907423).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3196" data-file-width="4802" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/%D0%9D%D0%90%D0%A2%D0%9E_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82_2021_NATO_Summit_2021_-14.06.2021-_%2851246907423%29.jpg/220px-%D0%9D%D0%90%D0%A2%D0%9E_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82_2021_NATO_Summit_2021_-14.06.2021-_%2851246907423%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/%D0%9D%D0%90%D0%A2%D0%9E_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82_2021_NATO_Summit_2021_-14.06.2021-_%2851246907423%29.jpg/330px-%D0%9D%D0%90%D0%A2%D0%9E_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82_2021_NATO_Summit_2021_-14.06.2021-_%2851246907423%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/%D0%9D%D0%90%D0%A2%D0%9E_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82_2021_NATO_Summit_2021_-14.06.2021-_%2851246907423%29.jpg/440px-%D0%9D%D0%90%D0%A2%D0%9E_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82_2021_NATO_Summit_2021_-14.06.2021-_%2851246907423%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9D%D0%90%D0%A2%D0%9E_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82_2021_NATO_Summit_2021_-14.06.2021-_(51246907423).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">Turkish Armed Forces</a> collectively rank as the second-largest standing military force in <a href="/wiki/Turkey_in_NATO" title="Turkey in NATO">NATO</a>, after the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">US Armed Forces</a>. Turkey joined the alliance in <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_NATO#Founding_and_changes_in_membership" title="Member states of NATO">1952</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforeign_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforeign-194">[193]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The independence of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkic_states" title="Turkic states">Turkic states</a> of the Soviet Union in 1991, with which Turkey shares a common cultural and linguistic heritage, allowed Turkey to extend its economic and political relations deep into <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bal2004_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bal2004-195">[194]</a></sup> thus enabling the completion of a multi-billion-dollar oil and natural gas <a href="/wiki/Pipeline_transport" title="Pipeline transport">pipeline</a> from <a href="/wiki/Baku" title="Baku">Baku</a> in <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> to the port of <a href="/wiki/Ceyhan" title="Ceyhan">Ceyhan</a> in Turkey. The <a href="/wiki/Baku%E2%80%93Tbilisi%E2%80%93Ceyhan_pipeline" title="BakuâTbilisiâCeyhan pipeline">BakuâTbilisiâCeyhan pipeline</a> forms part of Turkey's foreign policy strategy to become an energy conduit from the Caspian Sea basin to Europe. However, in 1993, Turkey sealed its land border with Armenia in a gesture of support to Azerbaijan (a Turkic state in the Caucasus region) during the <a href="/wiki/First_Nagorno-Karabakh_War" title="First Nagorno-Karabakh War">First Nagorno-Karabakh War</a>, and it remains closed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[195]</a></sup> Armenia and Turkey started diplomatic talks in order to normalise the relationship between the two countries. The discussions include opening the closed borders and starting trade. Turkey and Armenia have also restarted commercial flights between the two countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under the AKP government, Turkey's influence has grown in the formerly Ottoman territories of the Middle East and the Balkans, based on the "strategic depth" doctrine (a terminology that was coined by <a href="/wiki/Ahmet_Davuto%C4%9Flu" title="Ahmet DavutoÄlu">Ahmet DavutoÄlu</a> for defining Turkey's increased engagement in regional foreign policy issues), also called <a href="/wiki/Neo-Ottomanism" title="Neo-Ottomanism">Neo-Ottomanism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[198]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a> in December 2010, the choices made by the AKP government for supporting certain political opposition groups in the affected countries have led to tensions with some Arab states, such as Turkey's neighbour Syria since the start of the <a href="/wiki/Syrian_civil_war" title="Syrian civil war">Syrian civil war</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> after the <a href="/wiki/2013_Egyptian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="2013 Egyptian coup d'Ã©tat">ousting of President Mohamed Morsi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[199]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[200]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_(Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2490" data-file-width="4227" decoding="async" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg/220px-Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg/330px-Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg/440px-Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_%28Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Participants_at_the_2015_G20_Summit_(Presidencia_de_la_Naci%C3%B3n_Argentina).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/2015_G20_Antalya_summit" title="2015 G20 Antalya summit">2015 G20 Summit</a> held in <a href="/wiki/Antalya" title="Antalya">Antalya</a>, Turkey, a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> (1961) and <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a> (1999).</div></div></div>
<p>As of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Turkey does not have an ambassador in either Syria or Egypt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[201]</a></sup> Diplomatic relations with Israel were also severed after the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_flotilla_raid" title="Gaza flotilla raid">Gaza flotilla raid</a> in 2010, but were normalised following a deal in June 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[202]</a></sup> These political rifts have left Turkey with few allies in the <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">East Mediterranean</a>, where rich <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a> fields have recently been discovered;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[204]</a></sup> in sharp contrast with the original goals that were set by the former Foreign Minister (later Prime Minister) Ahmet DavutoÄlu in his "zero problems with neighbours"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[206]</a></sup> foreign policy doctrine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[207]</a></sup> In 2015, Turkey, <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a> formed a "strategic alliance" against Syrian President <a href="/wiki/Bashar_al-Assad" title="Bashar al-Assad">Bashar al-Assad</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[208]</a></sup> However, following the <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Turkey_relations#Normalisation_of_ties" title="RussiaâTurkey relations">rapprochement with Russia</a> in 2016, Turkey revised its stance regarding the solution of the conflict in Syria.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[210]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[211]</a></sup> In January 2018, the Turkish military and the Turkish-backed forces, including the <a class="mw-redirect"
