href="/wiki/Turkish-backed_Free_Syrian_Army" title="Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army">Free Syrian Army</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ahrar_al-Sham" title="Ahrar al-Sham">Ahrar al-Sham</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[212]</a></sup> began an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_military_operation_in_Afrin" title="Turkish military operation in Afrin">intervention in Syria</a> aimed at ousting U.S.-backed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Protection_Units" title="People's Protection Units">YPG</a> from the enclave of <a href="/wiki/Afrin,_Syria" title="Afrin, Syria">Afrin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[213]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[214]</a></sup> There is a dispute over Turkey's <a href="/wiki/Aegean_dispute" title="Aegean dispute">maritime boundaries with Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cyprus%E2%80%93Turkey_maritime_zones_dispute" title="CyprusâTurkey maritime zones dispute">Cyprus</a> and drilling rights in the eastern Mediterranean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[216]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">Turkish Armed Forces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Defense_industry_of_Turkey" title="Defense industry of Turkey">Defense industry of Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TurkishMilitaryImages.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6426" data-file-width="10145" decoding="async" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/TurkishMilitaryImages.png/310px-TurkishMilitaryImages.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/TurkishMilitaryImages.png/465px-TurkishMilitaryImages.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/TurkishMilitaryImages.png/620px-TurkishMilitaryImages.png 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TurkishMilitaryImages.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Turkish Military's indigenous equipment. Clockwise from top left: An amphibious armoured combat vehicle <a href="/wiki/FNSS_Pars" title="FNSS Pars">FNSS Pars</a>, an unmanned aerial vehicle <a href="/wiki/TAI_Anka" title="TAI Anka">TAI Anka</a>, an air defense system <a href="/wiki/Hisar_(missile_family)" title="Hisar (missile family)">Hisar</a>, an amphibious assault ship/aircraft carrier <a href="/wiki/TCG_Anadolu" title="TCG Anadolu">TCG Anadolu</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="Turkish Armed Forces">Turkish Armed Forces</a> consist of the <a href="/wiki/General_Staff_of_the_Turkish_Armed_Forces" title="General Staff of the Turkish Armed Forces">General Staff</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Land_Forces" title="Turkish Land Forces">Land Forces</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Naval_Forces" title="Turkish Naval Forces">Naval Forces</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Air_Force" title="Turkish Air Force">Air Force</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_the_Turkish_General_Staff" title="Chief of the Turkish General Staff">Chief of the General Staff</a> is appointed by the President. President is responsible to the Parliament for matters of national security and the adequate preparation of the armed forces to defend the country. However, the authority to declare war and to deploy the Turkish Armed Forces to foreign countries or to allow foreign armed forces to be stationed in Turkey rests solely with the Parliament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TSK_Organisation_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-TSK_Organisation-218">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Gendarmerie" title="Turkish Gendarmerie">Gendarmerie General Command</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Coast_Guard" title="Turkish Coast Guard">Coast Guard Command</a> are law enforcement agencies with military organization (ranks, structure, etc.) and under the jurisdiction of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of the Interior (Turkey)">Ministry of the Interior</a>. In wartime, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">president</a> can order certain units of the Gendarmerie General Command and the Coast Guard Command to operate under the Land Forces Command and Naval Forces Commands respectively. The remaining parts of the Gendarmerie and the Coast Guard continue to carry out their law enforcement missions under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Interior.
</p><p>Every fit male Turkish citizen otherwise not barred is required to <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Turkey" title="Conscription in Turkey">serve in the military</a> for a period ranging from three weeks to a year, dependent on education and job location.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[218]</a></sup> Turkey does not recognise <a href="/wiki/Conscientious_objector" title="Conscientious objector">conscientious objection</a> and does not offer a <a href="/wiki/Alternative_civilian_service" title="Alternative civilian service">civilian alternative</a> to military service.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey has the <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_NATO#Military_personnel" title="Member states of NATO">second-largest standing military force</a> in NATO, after the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">United States</a>, with an estimated strength of 890,700 military as of February 2022.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Turkey is one of five NATO member states which are part of the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_sharing" title="Nuclear sharing">nuclear sharing</a> policy of the alliance, together with Belgium, <a href="/wiki/Germany_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Germany and weapons of mass destruction">Germany</a>, Italy, and the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Netherlands and weapons of mass destruction">Netherlands</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[220]</a></sup> A total of 90 <a href="/wiki/B61_nuclear_bomb" title="B61 nuclear bomb">B61 nuclear bombs</a> are hosted at the <a href="/wiki/Incirlik_Air_Base" title="Incirlik Air Base">Incirlik Air Base</a>, 40 of which are allocated for use by the Turkish Air Force in case of a nuclear conflict, but their use requires the approval of NATO.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[221]</a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey has participated in international missions under the United Nations and NATO <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Brigade" title="Turkish Brigade">since the Korean War</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> missions in <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Operation_in_Somalia_I" title="United Nations Operation in Somalia I">Somalia</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Protection_Force" title="United Nations Protection Force">Yugoslavia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Ocean_Shield" title="Operation Ocean Shield">Horn of Africa</a>. It supported <a href="/wiki/Coalition_of_the_Gulf_War" title="Coalition of the Gulf War">coalition forces</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Gulf_War" title="First Gulf War">First Gulf War</a>, contributed military personnel to the <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">International Security Assistance Force</a> in Afghanistan, and remains active in <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Force" title="Kosovo Force">Kosovo Force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurocorps" title="Eurocorps">Eurocorps</a> and <a href="/wiki/EU_Battlegroup" title="EU Battlegroup">EU Battlegroups</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Enter_the_EU_Battle_Groups_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-Enter_the_EU_Battle_Groups-223">[222]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tskpeace_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-tskpeace-224">[223]</a></sup> In recent years, Turkey has assisted <a href="/wiki/Peshmerga" title="Peshmerga">Peshmerga</a> forces in northern <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Somali_Armed_Forces" title="Somali Armed Forces">Somali Armed Forces</a> with security and training.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hurriyetdailynews.comq_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-hurriyetdailynews.comq-225">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reuters.comq_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-reuters.comq-226">[225]</a></sup> Turkish Armed Forces have a relatively substantial military presence abroad,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[226]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_with_overseas_military_bases" title="List of countries with overseas military bases">military bases</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pasha_Liman_Base" title="Pasha Liman Base">Albania</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LarrabeeLesser94_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-LarrabeeLesser94-228">[227]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Iraq%E2%80%93Turkey_relations#Turkish_military_presence_in_Iraq" title="IraqâTurkey relations">Iraq</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[228]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Qatar%E2%80%93Turkey_relations#Turkish_military_presence_in_Qatar" title="QatarâTurkey relations">Qatar</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[229]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Camp_TURKSOM" title="Camp TURKSOM">Somalia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[230]</a></sup> The country also maintains a force of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_military_forces_in_Northern_Cyprus" title="Turkish military forces in Northern Cyprus">36,000 troops</a> in Northern Cyprus since 1974.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Richmond1998_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-Richmond1998-232">[231]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Turkey" title="Human rights in Turkey">Human rights in Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%93present_purges_in_Turkey" title="2016âpresent purges in Turkey">2016âpresent purges in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg/220px-Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg/330px-Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg/440px-Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Feminist_protest_from_Turkey.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Feminist demonstration in KadÄ±kÃ¶y, Istanbul on 29 July 2017</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Turkey" title="Human rights in Turkey">human rights record of Turkey</a> has been the subject of much controversy and international condemnation. Between 1959 and 2011 the <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Human_Rights" title="European Court of Human Rights">European Court of Human Rights</a> made more than 2400 judgements against Turkey for human rights violations on issues such as <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_of_Kurdish_people_in_Turkey" title="Human rights of Kurdish people in Turkey">Kurdish rights</a>, <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Turkey" title="Women in Turkey">women's rights</a>, <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Turkey" title="LGBT rights in Turkey">LGBT rights</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_of_Turkey" title="Media of Turkey">media freedom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ETCHR1_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-ETCHR1-233">[232]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnnualETCHR_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-AnnualETCHR-234">[233]</a></sup> Turkey's human rights record continues to be a significant obstacle to the country's <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">membership of the EU</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[234]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the latter half of the 1970s, Turkey suffered from <a href="/wiki/Political_violence_in_Turkey_(1976%E2%80%931980)" title="Political violence in Turkey (1976â1980)">political violence</a> between <a href="/wiki/Far-left_politics" title="Far-left politics">far-left</a> and <a href="/wiki/Far-right_politics" title="Far-right politics">far-right</a> militant groups, which culminated in the <a href="/wiki/1980_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1980 Turkish coup d'Ã©tat">military coup of 1980</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[235]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kurdistan_Workers%27_Party" title="Kurdistan Workers' Party">Kurdistan Workers' Party</a> - a.k.a. PKK - (designated a <a href="/wiki/List_of_designated_terrorist_groups" title="List of designated terrorist groups">terrorist organisation</a> by Turkey, the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-department-of-state-list_138-2"><a href="#cite_note-department-of-state-list-138">[137]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-european-council-list_139-2"><a href="#cite_note-european-council-list-139">[138]</a></sup>) was founded in 1978 by a group of Kurdish militants led by <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_%C3%96calan" title="Abdullah Ãcalan">Abdullah Ãcalan</a>, seeking the foundation of an independent Kurdish state based on <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">Marxist-Leninist</a> ideology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[236]</a></sup> The initial reason given by the PKK for this was the oppression of Kurds in Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[238]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kurdish%E2%80%93Turkish_conflict_(1978%E2%80%93present)" title="KurdishâTurkish conflict (1978âpresent)">A full-scale insurgency</a> began <a href="/wiki/1984_PKK_attacks" title="1984 PKK attacks">in 1984</a>, when the PKK announced a Kurdish uprising. With time the PKK modified its demands into equal rights for ethnic Kurds and provincial autonomy within Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[242]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1999 the PKK leader Abdullah Ãcalan was captured in Kenya and <a href="/wiki/Imprisonment_of_Abdullah_%C3%96calan" title="Imprisonment of Abdullah Ãcalan">imprisoned on an Island</a> in Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc-29-06-1999_143-1"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-29-06-1999-143">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc-03-10-2002_144-1"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-03-10-2002-144">[143]</a></sup> Since the conflict began, more than 40,000 people have died, most of whom were <a href="/wiki/Kurds_in_Turkey" title="Kurds in Turkey">Turkish Kurds</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[243]</a></sup> The European Court of Human Rights and other international human rights organisations have condemned Turkey for human rights abuses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ETCHR1_233-1"><a href="#cite_note-ETCHR1-233">[232]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnnualETCHR_234-1"><a href="#cite_note-AnnualETCHR-234">[233]</a></sup> Many judgments are related to cases such as civilian deaths in aerial bombardments,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hum1_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-hum1-245">[244]</a></sup> torturing,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tort1_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-tort1-246">[245]</a></sup> forced displacements,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[246]</a></sup> destroyed villages,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[248]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[249]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arbitrary_arrest" title="Arbitrary arrest">arbitrary arrests</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[250]</a></sup> murdered and disappeared Kurdish journalists, activists and politicians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[251]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 20 May 2016, the Turkish parliament stripped almost a quarter of its members of <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_immunity" title="Parliamentary immunity">immunity</a> from prosecution, including 101 deputies from the pro-Kurdish <a href="/wiki/Peoples%27_Democratic_Party_(Turkey)" title="Peoples' Democratic Party (Turkey)">HDP</a> and the main opposition <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republican_People%27s_Party_(Turkey)" title="Republican People's Party (Turkey)">CHP</a> party.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[252]</a></sup> In reaction to the <a href="/wiki/2016_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2016 Turkish coup d'Ã©tat attempt">failed coup attempt</a> on 15 July 2016, over 160,000 judges, teachers, police and civil servants have been suspended or dismissed, 77,000 have been formally arrested,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[254]</a></sup> and 130 media organisations, including 16 television broadcasters and 45 newspapers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[255]</a></sup> have been closed by the government of Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[256]</a></sup> 160 journalists have been imprisoned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[257]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2322" data-file-width="4128" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg/220px-Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg/330px-Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg/440px-Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkish_journalists_protesting_imprisonment_of_their_colleagues_in_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Turkish journalists protesting the <a href="/wiki/Turkey%27s_media_purge_after_the_failed_July_2016_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Turkey's media purge after the failed July 2016 coup d'Ã©tat">imprisonment of their colleagues</a> on <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Day" title="Human Rights Day">Human Rights Day</a> in 2016.</div></div></div>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Committee_to_Protect_Journalists" title="Committee to Protect Journalists">Committee to Protect Journalists</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">AKP</a> government has waged one of the world's biggest crackdowns on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Turkey" title="Media freedom in Turkey">media freedom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPJ_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-CPJ-259">[258]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cpj.org1_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-cpj.org1-260">[259]</a></sup> Many journalists have been arrested using charges of "terrorism" and "anti-state activities" such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ergenekon_(organization)" title="Ergenekon (organization)">Ergenekon</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sledgehammer_(coup_plan)" title="Sledgehammer (coup plan)">Balyoz</a> cases, while thousands have been investigated on charges such as "denigrating Turkishness" or "insulting Islam" in an effort to sow self-censorship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CPJ_259-1"><a href="#cite_note-CPJ-259">[258]</a></sup> In 2017, the CPJ identified 81 jailed journalists in Turkey (including the editorial staff of <i><a href="/wiki/Cumhuriyet" title="Cumhuriyet">Cumhuriyet</a></i>, Turkey's oldest newspaper still in circulation), all directly held for their published work (the country ranked first in the world in that year, with more journalists in prison than in Iran, Eritrea or China);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cpj.org1_260-1"><a href="#cite_note-cpj.org1-260">[259]</a></sup> while in 2015 Freemuse identified nine musicians imprisoned for their work (ranking third after Russia and China).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freemuse_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-freemuse-261">[260]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the October 2019 offensive into Syria, Turkish forces have been accused of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_crimes" title="War crimes">war crimes</a>, such as targeting civilians with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_phosphorus" title="White phosphorus">white phosphorus</a> and various other human rights violations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tfsoa_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-tfsoa-262">[261]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-taowc_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-taowc-263">[262]</a></sup> Turkey has officially rejected the claims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TRT-World-07-11-2019_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-TRT-World-07-11-2019-264">[263]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="LGBT_rights">LGBT rights</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Turkey" title="LGBT rights in Turkey">LGBT rights in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="640" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg/220px-Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg/330px-Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg/440px-Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gay_pride_Istanbul_2013_-_Taksim_Square.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Pride" title="Istanbul Pride">Istanbul Pride</a> organized in 2003 for the first time. Since 2015, parades in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> were denied permission by the government. The denials were based on security concerns, but critics claimed the bans were ideological. Despite the refusal hundreds of people defied the ban each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3-265">[264]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Homosexual" title="Homosexual">Homosexual</a> activity is legal in Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[265]</a></sup> However, LGBT people in Turkey face discrimination, harassment and even violence from their relatives, neighbors, etc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[266]</a></sup> The Turkish authorities have carried out many discriminatory practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[267]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[268]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[269]</a></sup> Despite these, LGBT acceptance in Turkey is growing. In a survey conducted by <a href="/wiki/Kadir_Has_University" title="Kadir Has University">Kadir Has University</a> in Istanbul in 2016, 33% of respondents said that LGBT people should have equal rights, which increased to 45% in 2020. Another survey by Kadir Has University in 2018 found that the proportion of people who would not want a homosexual neighbour decreased from 55% in 2018 to 47% in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[271]</a></sup> A poll by <a href="/wiki/Ipsos" title="Ipsos">Ipsos</a> in 2015 found that 27% of the Turkish public was in favor of legalizing same-sex marriage and 19% supported <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil_unions" title="Civil unions">civil unions</a> instead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ipsos_2015_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ipsos_2015-273">[272]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Pride" title="Istanbul Pride">Istanbul Pride</a> was held for the first time in 2003. Turkey became the first Muslim-majority country to hold a gay pride march.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[273]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Turkey" title="Geography of Turkey">Geography of Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Turkey" title="List of national parks of Turkey">List of national parks of Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_topo.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="752" data-file-width="1400" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Turkey_topo.jpg/290px-Turkey_topo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Turkey_topo.jpg/435px-Turkey_topo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Turkey_topo.jpg/580px-Turkey_topo.jpg 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_topo.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Topographic_map" title="Topographic map">Topographic map</a> of Turkey</div></div></div>
<p>Turkey is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transcontinental_country" title="Transcontinental country">transcontinental country</a> bridging <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southeastern_Europe" title="Southeastern Europe">Southeastern Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a>. Asian Turkey, which includes 97 percent of the country's territory, is separated from <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">European Turkey</a> by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">Bosphorus</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara" title="Sea of Marmara">Sea of Marmara</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">Dardanelles</a>. European Turkey comprises only 3 percent of the country's territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkeygeoth_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-turkeygeoth-275">[274]</a></sup> Turkey covers an area of 783,562 square kilometres (302,535 square miles),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[275]</a></sup> of which 755,688 square kilometres (291,773 square miles) is in Asia and 23,764 square kilometres (9,175 square miles) is in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USLC_TRGeo_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-USLC_TRGeo-277">[276]</a></sup> The country is encircled by seas on three sides: the Aegean Sea to the west, the Black Sea to the north and the Mediterranean Sea to the south. Turkey also contains the Sea of Marmara in the northwest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism-278">[277]</a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey is divided into seven geographical regions: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marmara_Region,_Turkey" title="Marmara Region, Turkey">Marmara</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aegean_Region,_Turkey" title="Aegean Region, Turkey">Aegean</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region,_Turkey" title="Black Sea Region, Turkey">Black Sea</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region,_Turkey" title="Central Anatolia Region, Turkey">Central Anatolia</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_Anatolia_Region,_Turkey" title="East Anatolia Region, Turkey">Eastern Anatolia</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Eastern_Anatolia_Region,_Turkey" title="South Eastern Anatolia Region, Turkey">Southeastern Anatolia</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea_Region,_Turkey" title="Mediterranean Sea Region, Turkey">Mediterranean</a>. The uneven north Anatolian terrain running along the Black Sea resembles a long, narrow belt. This region comprises approximately one-sixth of Turkey's total land area. As a general trend, the inland Anatolian plateau becomes increasingly rugged as it progresses eastward.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism_278-1"><a href="#cite_note-TRGeo_TRMinistryTourism-278">[277]</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Pamukkale" title="Pamukkale">Pamukkale</a> terraces are made of <a href="/wiki/Travertine" title="Travertine">travertine</a>, a sedimentary rock deposited by mineral water from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hot_springs" title="Hot springs">hot springs</a>. The area is famous for a carbonate mineral left by the flowing of thermal spring water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-readers_natural_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-readers_natural-279">[278]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unesco_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-Unesco-280">[279]</a></sup> It is located in Turkey's Inner Aegean region, in the River Menderes valley, which has a temperate climate for most of the year. It was added as a <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a> in 1988 with <a href="/wiki/Hierapolis" title="Hierapolis">Hierapolis</a>.
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:229px;max-width:229px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pamukkale_30.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2675" data-file-width="4881" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Pamukkale_30.jpg/225px-Pamukkale_30.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Pamukkale_30.jpg/338px-Pamukkale_30.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Pamukkale_30.jpg/450px-Pamukkale_30.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Pamukkale" title="Pamukkale">Pamukkale</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:View_of_Cappadocia_edit.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="996" data-file-width="1514" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/View_of_Cappadocia_edit.jpg/225px-View_of_Cappadocia_edit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/View_of_Cappadocia_edit.jpg/338px-View_of_Cappadocia_edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/View_of_Cappadocia_edit.jpg/450px-View_of_Cappadocia_edit.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Cappadocia" title="Cappadocia">Cappadocia</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>East Thrace; the European portion of Turkey, is located at the easternmost edge the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>. It forms the border between Turkey and its neighbours Greece and Bulgaria. The Asian part of the country mostly consists of the peninsula of <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>, which consists of a high central plateau with narrow coastal plains, between the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ro%C4%9Flu_Mountains" title="KÃ¶roÄlu Mountains">KÃ¶roÄlu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Mountains" title="Pontic Mountains">Pontic</a> mountain ranges to the north and the <a href="/wiki/Taurus_Mountains" title="Taurus Mountains">Taurus Mountains</a> to the south.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">Eastern Anatolia Region</a> mostly corresponds to the western part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Armenian_Highlands" title="Armenian Highlands">Armenian Highlands</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">plateau</a> situated between the <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_Plateau" title="Anatolian Plateau">Anatolian Plateau</a> in the west and the <a href="/wiki/Lesser_Caucasus" title="Lesser Caucasus">Lesser Caucasus</a> in the north)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[280]</a></sup> and contains <a href="/wiki/Mount_Ararat" title="Mount Ararat">Mount Ararat</a>, Turkey's highest point at 5,137 metres (16,854 feet),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mararat_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-mararat-282">[281]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Van" title="Lake Van">Lake Van</a>, the largest lake in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lvan_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-lvan-283">[282]</a></sup> Eastern Turkey has a mountainous landscape and is home to the sources of rivers such as the <a href="/wiki/Euphrates" title="Euphrates">Euphrates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tigris" title="Tigris">Tigris</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aras_River" title="Aras River">Aras</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Southeastern Anatolia Region">Southeastern Anatolia Region</a> includes the northern plains of <a href="/wiki/Upper_Mesopotamia" title="Upper Mesopotamia">Upper Mesopotamia</a>.
</p><p>Far from the coast the <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Turkey" title="Climate of Turkey">climate of Turkey</a> tends to be <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental</a> but elsewhere <a href="/wiki/Temperate_climate" title="Temperate climate">temperate</a>, and has <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Turkey" title="Climate change in Turkey">become hotter</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Malatya_Plain" title="Malatya Plain">drier in parts</a>. There are <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Turkey" title="Wildlife of Turkey">many species of plants and animals</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Turkey" title="Wildlife of Turkey">Wildlife of Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Turkey" title="Fauna of Turkey">Fauna of Turkey</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flora_and_vegetation_of_Turkey" title="Flora and vegetation of Turkey">Flora and vegetation of Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Turkey" title="Environmental issues in Turkey">Environmental issues in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG/220px-Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG/330px-Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG/440px-Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sumela_Showing_Location.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sumela_Monastery" title="Sumela Monastery">Sumela Monastery</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Mountains" title="Pontic Mountains">Pontic Mountains</a>, which form an <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">ecoregion</a> with <a href="/wiki/Northern_Anatolian_conifer_and_deciduous_forests" title="Northern Anatolian conifer and deciduous forests">diverse temperate rainforest types</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flora" title="Flora">flora</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">fauna</a> in northern Anatolia.</div></div></div>
<p>Turkey's extraordinary <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystem</a> and habitat diversity has produced considerable species diversity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[283]</a></sup> Anatolia is the homeland of many plants that have been cultivated for food since the advent of <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>, and the wild ancestors of many plants that now provide staples for humankind still grow in Turkey. The diversity of <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Turkey" title="Fauna of Turkey">Turkey's fauna</a> is even greater than that of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flora_and_vegetation_of_Turkey" title="Flora and vegetation of Turkey">its flora</a>. The number of animal species in the whole of Europe is around 60,000, while in Turkey there are over 80,000 (over 100,000 counting the subspecies).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allaboutturkey_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-allaboutturkey-285">[284]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Northern_Anatolian_conifer_and_deciduous_forests" title="Northern Anatolian conifer and deciduous forests">Northern Anatolian conifer and deciduous forests</a> is an <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">ecoregion</a> which covers most of the <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Mountains" title="Pontic Mountains">Pontic Mountains</a> in northern Turkey, while the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_mixed_forests" title="Caucasus mixed forests">Caucasus mixed forests</a> extend across the eastern end of the range. The region is home to <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">Eurasian</a> wildlife such as the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_sparrowhawk" title="Eurasian sparrowhawk">Eurasian sparrowhawk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Golden_eagle" title="Golden eagle">golden eagle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_imperial_eagle" title="Eastern imperial eagle">eastern imperial eagle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lesser_spotted_eagle" title="Lesser spotted eagle">lesser spotted eagle</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caucasian_black_grouse" title="Caucasian black grouse">Caucasian black grouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Red-fronted_serin" title="Red-fronted serin">red-fronted serin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wallcreeper" title="Wallcreeper">wallcreeper</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[285]</a></sup> The narrow coastal strip between the Pontic Mountains and the Black Sea is home to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Euxine-Colchic_deciduous_forests" title="Euxine-Colchic deciduous forests">Euxine-Colchic deciduous forests</a>, which contain some of the world's few <a href="/wiki/Temperate_rainforest" title="Temperate rainforest">temperate rainforests</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[286]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pinus_brutia" title="Pinus brutia">Turkish pine (<i>Pinus brutia</i>)</a> is mostly found in Turkey and other east Mediterranean countries; the other commonly found species of the genus <a href="/wiki/Pine" title="Pine"><i>Pinus</i> (pine)</a> in Turkey include the <i><a href="/wiki/Pinus_nigra" title="Pinus nigra">nigra</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Pinus_sylvestris" title="Pinus sylvestris">sylvestris</a></i>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pinus_pinea" title="Pinus pinea">pinea</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Pinus_halepensis" title="Pinus halepensis">halepensis</a></i>. The <a href="/wiki/Quercus_cerris" title="Quercus cerris">Turkey oak (<i>Quercus cerris</i>)</a> and numerous other species of the genus <a href="/wiki/Oak" title="Oak"><i>Quercus</i> (oak)</a> exist in Turkey. The most commonly found species of the genus <a href="/wiki/Platanus" title="Platanus"><i>Platanus</i> (plane)</a> is the <i><a href="/wiki/Platanus_orientalis" title="Platanus orientalis">orientalis</a></i>. Several wild species of <a href="/wiki/Tulip" title="Tulip">tulip</a> are native to Anatolia, and the flower was first <a href="/wiki/Tulip#Introduction_to_Western_Europe" title="Tulip">introduced to Western Europe</a> with species taken from the Ottoman Empire in the 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blunt_7_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blunt_7-288">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[288]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg/200px-Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg/300px-Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg/400px-Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Odd-eyed_Turkish_Angora_cat_-_20080830.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A white <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Angora" title="Turkish Angora">Turkish Angora</a> cat with <a href="/wiki/Odd-eyed_cat" title="Odd-eyed cat">odd eyes (heterochromia)</a>, which is common among the Angoras.</div></div></div>
<p>There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Turkey" title="List of national parks of Turkey">40 national parks</a>, 189 nature parks, 31 nature preserve areas, 80 wildlife protection areas and 109 nature monuments in Turkey such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallipoli_Peninsula_Historical_National_Park" title="Gallipoli Peninsula Historical National Park">Gallipoli Peninsula Historical National Park</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mount_Nemrut_National_Park" title="Mount Nemrut National Park">Mount Nemrut National Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Troy" title="Troy">Ancient Troy National Park</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%96l%C3%BCdeniz_Nature_Park" title="ÃlÃ¼deniz Nature Park">ÃlÃ¼deniz Nature Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polonezk%C3%B6y_Nature_Park" title="PolonezkÃ¶y Nature Park">PolonezkÃ¶y Nature Park</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ministryofforest_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-ministryofforest-290">[289]</a></sup> In the 21st century, threats to biodiversity include <a href="/wiki/Desertification" title="Desertification">desertification</a> due to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Turkey" title="Climate change in Turkey">climate change in Turkey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[290]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatolian_leopard" title="Anatolian leopard">Anatolian leopard</a> is still found in very small numbers in the northeastern and southeastern regions of Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O.E.Can_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-O.E.Can-292">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[292]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_lynx" title="Eurasian lynx">Eurasian lynx</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_wildcat" title="European wildcat">European wildcat</a> are other <a href="/wiki/Felidae" title="Felidae">felid</a> species which are currently found in the forests of Turkey. The <a href="/wiki/Caspian_tiger" title="Caspian tiger">Caspian tiger</a>, now extinct, lived in the easternmost regions of Turkey until the latter half of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O.E.Can_292-1"><a href="#cite_note-O.E.Can-292">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ãstay_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ãstay-294">[293]</a></sup>
</p><p>Renowned domestic animals from <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a>, the capital of Turkey, include the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Angora" title="Turkish Angora">Angora cat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angora_rabbit" title="Angora rabbit">Angora rabbit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Angora_goat" title="Angora goat">Angora goat</a>; and from <a href="/wiki/Van_Province" title="Van Province">Van Province</a> the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Van" title="Turkish Van">Van cat</a>. The national dog breeds are the <a href="/wiki/Kangal_Shepherd_Dog" title="Kangal Shepherd Dog">Kangal</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatolian_Shepherd" title="Anatolian Shepherd">Anatolian Shepherd</a>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aksaray_Malaklisi_dog" title="Aksaray Malaklisi dog">MalaklÄ±</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Akbash_Dog" title="Akbash Dog">AkbaÅ</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gateofturkey_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-gateofturkey-295">[294]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Turkey" title="Climate of Turkey">Climate of Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Turkey" title="Climate change in Turkey">Climate change in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="850" data-file-width="1816" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg/290px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg/435px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg/580px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_TUR_present.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification">KÃ¶ppen climate classification</a> of Turkey</div></div></div>
<p>The coastal areas of Turkey bordering the Aegean and Mediterranean Seas have a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temperate" title="Temperate">temperate</a> <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a>, with hot, dry summers and mild to cool, wet winters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-296">[295]</a></sup> The coastal areas bordering the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> have a temperate <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a> with warm, wet summers and cool to cold, wet <a href="/wiki/Winter" title="Winter">winters</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_296-1"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-296">[295]</a></sup> The Turkish Black Sea coast receives the most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">precipitation</a> and is the only region of Turkey that receives high precipitation throughout the year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_296-2"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-296">[295]</a></sup> The eastern part of the Black Sea coast averages 2,200 millimetres (87Â in) annually which is the highest precipitation in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_296-3"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-296">[295]</a></sup> The coastal areas bordering the Sea of Marmara, which connects the Aegean Sea and the Black Sea, have a transitional climate between a temperate Mediterranean climate and a temperate oceanic climate with warm to hot, moderately dry <a href="/wiki/Summer" title="Summer">summers</a> and cool to cold, wet winters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_296-4"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-296">[295]</a></sup> Snow falls on the coastal areas of the Sea of Marmara and the Black Sea almost every winter, but usually melts in no more than a few days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_296-5"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-296">[295]</a></sup> However, snow is rare in the coastal areas of the Aegean Sea and very rare in the coastal areas of the Mediterranean Sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_296-6"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-296">[295]</a></sup> Winters on the Anatolian plateau are especially severe. Temperatures of â30Â Â°C to â40Â Â°C (â22Â Â°F to â40Â Â°F) do occur in northeastern Anatolia, and snow may lie on the ground for at least 120 days of the year, and during the entire year on the summits of the highest mountains. In central Anatolia the temperatures can drop below â20Â Â°C ( -4Â Â°F) with the mountains being even colder.
</p><p>Mountains close to the coast prevent Mediterranean influences from extending inland, giving the central Anatolian <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">plateau</a> of the interior of Turkey a <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental climate</a> with sharply contrasting <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seasons" title="Seasons">seasons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteo_296-7"><a href="#cite_note-Meteo-296">[295]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Turkey" title="Economy of Turkey">Economy of Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2044" data-file-width="3633" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg/220px-Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg/330px-Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg/440px-Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> is the largest city and financial centre of Turkey.</div></div></div>
<p>Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/Newly_industrialized_country" title="Newly industrialized country">newly industrialized country</a>, with an upper-middle income economy, which is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">twentythird-largest in the world</a> by nominal GDP, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">eleventh-largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>. Turkey is one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emerging_7" title="Emerging 7">Emerging 7</a> countries. According to <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> estimates, Turkey's GDP per capita by PPP is $32,278 in 2021,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMF-WEO_8-4"><a href="#cite_note-IMF-WEO-8">[8]</a></sup> and approximately 11.7% of Turks are at risk of poverty or social exclusion as of 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[296]</a></sup> Unemployment in Turkey was 13.6% in 2019,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[297]</a></sup> and the middle class population in Turkey rose from 18% to 41% of the population between 1993 and 2010 according to the World Bank.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[298]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The date of the event predicted near this tag has passed. (September 2021)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup> As of SeptemberÂ 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the foreign currency reserves of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey">Turkish Central Bank</a> were $74.9 billion (an 8.1% increase compared to the previous month), its gold reserves were $38.5 billion (a 5.1% decrease compared to the previous month), while its official reserve assets stood at $121.3 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[299]</a></sup> As of OctoberÂ 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the foreign currency deposits of the citizens and residents in <a href="/wiki/List_of_banks_in_Turkey" title="List of banks in Turkey">Turkish banks</a> stood at $234 billion, equivalent to around half of all deposits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[301]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Union_%E2%80%93_Turkey_Customs_Union" title="European Union â Turkey Customs Union">EUâTurkey Customs Union</a> in 1995 led to an extensive liberalisation of tariff rates, and forms one of the most important pillars of Turkey's foreign trade policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[302]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Turkey" title="Automotive industry in Turkey">automotive industry in Turkey</a> is sizeable, and produced over 1.3Â million motor vehicles in 2015, ranking as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_motor_vehicle_production" title="List of countries by motor vehicle production">14th largest producer in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oica_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-oica-304">[303]</a></sup> Turkish automotive companies like <a href="/wiki/TEMSA" title="TEMSA">TEMSA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Otokar" title="Otokar">Otokar</a> and <a href="/wiki/BMC_(Turkey)" title="BMC (Turkey)">BMC</a> are among the world's largest van, bus and truck manufacturers. Turkish <a href="/wiki/Shipyard" title="Shipyard">shipyards</a> are highly regarded both for the production of chemical and <a href="/wiki/Oil_tanker" title="Oil tanker">oil tankers</a> up to 10,000 <a href="/wiki/Deadweight_tonnage" title="Deadweight tonnage">dwt</a> and also for their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mega_yacht" title="Mega yacht">mega yachts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ship-oecd_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-ship-oecd-305">[304]</a></sup> Turkish brands like <a href="/wiki/Beko" title="Beko">Beko</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vestel" title="Vestel">Vestel</a> are among the largest producers of <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">consumer electronics</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Home_appliances" title="Home appliances">home appliances</a> in Europe, and invest a substantial amount of funds for research and development in new technologies related to these fields.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[307]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_Product_Exports_(2019).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Turkey_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/310px-Turkey_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Turkey_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/465px-Turkey_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Turkey_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/620px-Turkey_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_Product_Exports_(2019).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A proportional representation of Turkey's exports, 2019</div></div></div>
<p>Other key sectors of the Turkish economy are <a href="/wiki/List_of_banks_in_Turkey" title="List of banks in Turkey">banking</a>, construction, home appliances, electronics, textiles, oil refining, petrochemical products, food, mining, iron and steel, and <a href="/wiki/Machine_industry" title="Machine industry">machine industry</a>. In 2004, it was estimated that 46 percent of total disposable income was received by the top 20 percent of income earners, while the lowest 20 percent received only 6 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[308]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The date of the event predicted near this tag has passed. (September 2021)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">Foreign direct investment</a> (FDI) in Turkey reached 22.05 billion USD in 2007 and 19.26 billion USD in 2015, but has declined in recent years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[309]</a></sup> In the economic crisis of 2016 it emerged that the huge debts incurred for investment during the AKP government since 2002 had mostly been consumed in construction, rather than invested in sustainable economic growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-how-to-ruin_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-how-to-ruin-311">[310]</a></sup> In 2020, according to <a href="/wiki/Carbon_Tracker" title="Carbon Tracker">Carbon Tracker</a>, money was being wasted constructing more <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_active_coal_fired_power_stations_in_Turkey" title="List of active coal fired power stations in Turkey">coal-fired power stations in Turkey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[311]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/International_Energy_Agency" title="International Energy Agency">International Energy Agency</a> said that <a href="/wiki/Energy_subsidy#Turkey" title="Energy subsidy">fossil fuel subsidies</a> should be redirected, for example to the <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Turkey" title="Health in Turkey">health system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[312]</a></sup> Fossil fuel subsidies were around 0.2% of GDP for the first two decades of the 21st century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[313]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-315">[314]</a></sup> and are higher than clean <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Energy_subsidies" title="Energy subsidies">energy subsidies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[315]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/External_costs" title="External costs">external costs</a> of fossil fuel consumption in 2018 has been estimated as 1.5% of GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[316]</a></sup> In 2020 the <a href="/wiki/European_Bank_for_Reconstruction_and_Development" title="European Bank for Reconstruction and Development">European Bank for Reconstruction and Development</a> offered to support a <a href="/wiki/Just_transition" title="Just transition">just transition</a> away from coal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-318">[317]</a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey has seen a growth in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Video_gaming_industry" title="Video gaming industry">video gaming industry</a> during the recent years. Many game developing companies founded and gained investment from venture capitalists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[318]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/TaleWorlds_Entertainment" title="TaleWorlds Entertainment">TaleWorlds Entertainment</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peak_Games" title="Peak Games">Peak Games</a>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Bigger_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Bigger Games (page does not exist)">Bigger Games</a> and Dream Games are the current leaders in this sector.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[320]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Turkey" title="Tourism in Turkey">Tourism in Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tentative_list_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" title="Tentative list of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">Tentative list of World Heritage Sites in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marmaris_harbor_(aerial_view),_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province,_southwest_Turkey,_Mediterranean.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1738" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg/310px-Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg/465px-Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg/620px-Marmaris_harbor_%28aerial_view%29%2C_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province%2C_southwest_Turkey%2C_Mediterranean.jpg 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Marmaris_harbor_(aerial_view),_Mu%C4%9Fla_Province,_southwest_Turkey,_Mediterranean.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Marmaris" title="Marmaris">Marmaris</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Riviera" title="Turkish Riviera">Turkish Riviera</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Turkey" title="Tourism in Turkey">Tourism in Turkey</a> has increased almost every year in the 21st century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TourismStats2018_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-TourismStats2018-322">[321]</a></sup> and is an important part of the economy. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Ministry_of_Culture_and_Tourism" title="Turkish Ministry of Culture and Tourism">Turkish Ministry of Culture and Tourism</a> currently promotes Turkish tourism under the project <a href="/wiki/Turkey_Home" title="Turkey Home">Turkey Home</a>. Turkey is one of the world's top ten destination countries, with the highest percentage of foreign visitors arriving from Europe; specially Germany and Russia in recent years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TourismStats2018_322-1"><a href="#cite_note-TourismStats2018-322">[321]</a></sup> In 2019, Turkey <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings#Most_visited_destinations_by_international_tourist_arrivals" title="World Tourism rankings">ranked sixth in the world</a> in terms of the number of international tourist arrivals behind <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>, with 51.2 million foreign tourists visiting the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2019_Edition_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-WTO_Tourism_Highlights_2019_Edition-323">[322]</a></sup> Turkey has <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey">19 UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Turkey_(Tentative_list)" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Turkey (Tentative list)">84 World Heritage Sites in tentative list</a>. Turkey is home to 519 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Blue_Flag_beaches" title="Blue Flag beaches">Blue Flag beaches</a>, which makes it in the third place in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[323]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> is the tenth most visited city in the world with 13,433,000 annual visitors as of 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[324]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Antalya" title="Antalya">Antalya</a> is the second most visited city in Turkey, with over 9 million tourists in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[325]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Turkey" title="Transport in Turkey">Transport in Turkey</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communications_in_Turkey" title="Communications in Turkey">Communications in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Turkey" title="Energy in Turkey">Energy in Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Turkey" title="Water supply and sanitation in Turkey">Water supply and sanitation in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbul_Havaliman%C4%B1_Airport_2019_24.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3205" data-file-width="4808" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%C4%B0stanbul_Havaliman%C4%B1_Airport_2019_24.jpg/220px-%C4%B0stanbul_Havaliman%C4%B1_Airport_2019_24.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%C4%B0stanbul_Havaliman%C4%B1_Airport_2019_24.jpg/330px-%C4%B0stanbul_Havaliman%C4%B1_Airport_2019_24.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%C4%B0stanbul_Havaliman%C4%B1_Airport_2019_24.jpg/440px-%C4%B0stanbul_Havaliman%C4%B1_Airport_2019_24.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbul_Havaliman%C4%B1_Airport_2019_24.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Airport" title="Istanbul Airport">Istanbul Airport</a> main terminal building has an annual passenger capacity of 90 million and making it the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Airport_terminal" title="Airport terminal">airport terminal</a> building under a single roof.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-igaconstr_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-igaconstr-327">[326]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In 2013 there were 98 <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Turkey" title="List of airports in Turkey">airports in Turkey</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[327]</a></sup> including 22 <a href="/wiki/International_airport" title="International airport">international airports</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[328]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0stanbul_Airport" title="Ä°stanbul Airport">Ä°stanbul Airport</a> is planned to be the largest airport in the world, with a capacity to serve 150 million passengers a year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dhmi_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-dhmi-330">[329]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[330]</a></sup> As well as <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Airlines" title="Turkish Airlines">Turkish Airlines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a> of Turkey since 1933, <a href="/wiki/List_of_airlines_of_Turkey" title="List of airlines of Turkey">several other airlines operate in the country</a>. It operates scheduled services to 315 destinations in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, making it the <a href="/wiki/Largest_airlines_in_the_world" title="Largest airlines in the world">largest</a> <a href="/wiki/Mainline_(aeronautics)" title="Mainline (aeronautics)">mainline carrier</a> in the world by number of passenger destinations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[331]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-air_profit_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-air_profit-333">[332]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-:4-334">[333]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Airlines" title="Turkish Airlines">Turkish Airlines</a> uses <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Airport" title="Istanbul Airport">Istanbul Airport</a> of 90 million capacity as its main hub.
</p><p>As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the country has a roadway network of over 65,000 kilometres (40,400 miles).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[334]</a></sup> Motorways are controlled-access highways that are officially named <a href="/wiki/Otoyol" title="Otoyol">Otoyol</a>. The network spans 3,523 kilometres (2,189Â mi) as of 2020. The network is expected to expand to 4,773 kilometres (2,966Â mi) by 2023 and to 9,312 kilometres (5,786Â mi) by 2035.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[335]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Railways" title="Turkish State Railways">Turkish State Railways</a> operates both conventional and high speed trains on 12,532 kilometres rail length. The government-owned national railway company started building <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_Turkey" title="High-speed rail in Turkey">high-speed rail</a> lines in 2003. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ankara-Konya_high-speed_railway" title="Ankara-Konya high-speed railway">Ankara-Konya line</a> became operational in 2011, while the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ankara-Istanbul_high-speed_railway" title="Ankara-Istanbul high-speed railway">Ankara-Istanbul line</a> entered service in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hizlitren.tcdd.gov.tr_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-hizlitren.tcdd.gov.tr-337">[336]</a></sup> Konya-Karaman line started its operations in 2022 and 406Â km (252Â mi) long <a href="/wiki/Ankara%E2%80%93Sivas_high-speed_railway" title="AnkaraâSivas high-speed railway">Ankara-Sivas line</a> is to open in 2022.
</p><p>Opened in 2013, the <a href="/wiki/Marmaray" title="Marmaray">Marmaray tunnel</a> under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">Bosphorus</a> connects the railway and <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Metro" title="Istanbul Metro">metro</a> lines of Istanbul's European and Asian sides; while the nearby <a href="/wiki/Eurasia_Tunnel" title="Eurasia Tunnel">Eurasia Tunnel</a> (2016) provides an undersea road connection for motor vehicles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[337]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Metro_Istanbul" title="Metro Istanbul">Metro Istanbul</a> is the largest metro network in the country with 495 million annual ridership.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[338]</a></sup> There are 8 metro lines under service and 5 more under construction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-network_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-network-340">[339]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HT80101.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="853" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/HT80101.jpg/220px-HT80101.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/HT80101.jpg/330px-HT80101.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/HT80101.jpg/440px-HT80101.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HT80101.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Turquoise (from the French turquois, meaning 'Turkish') colored <a href="/wiki/TCDD_HT80000" title="TCDD HT80000">TCDD HT80000</a> <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_Turkey" title="High-speed rail in Turkey">high-speed train</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Railways" title="Turkish State Railways">Turkish State Railways</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SiemensVelaroTR_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-SiemensVelaroTR-341">[340]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus_Bridge" title="Bosphorus Bridge">Bosphorus Bridge</a> (1973), <a href="/wiki/Fatih_Sultan_Mehmet_Bridge" title="Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge">Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge</a> (1988) and <a href="/wiki/Yavuz_Sultan_Selim_Bridge" title="Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge">Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge</a> (2016) are the three suspension bridges connecting the European and Asian shores of the Bosphorus strait. The <a href="/wiki/Osman_Gazi_Bridge" title="Osman Gazi Bridge">Osman Gazi Bridge</a> (2016) connects the northern and southern shores of the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_%C4%B0zmit" title="Gulf of Ä°zmit">Gulf of Ä°zmit</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%87anakkale_1915_Bridge" title="Ãanakkale 1915 Bridge">Ãanakkale 1915 Bridge</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Dardanelles" title="Dardanelles">Dardanelles</a> strait, connecting Europe and Asia, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_longest_suspension_bridge_spans#Bridges_under_construction" title="List of longest suspension bridge spans">longest suspension bridge in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hdn_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-hdn-342">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_gas_in_Turkey" title="Natural gas in Turkey">natural gas</a> pipelines span the country's territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIAFactbookTurkey_158-1"><a href="#cite_note-CIAFactbookTurkey-158">[157]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Blue_Stream" title="Blue Stream">Blue Stream</a>, a major trans-<a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> gas pipeline, delivers natural gas from Russia to Turkey. The undersea pipeline, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Stream" title="Turkish Stream">Turkish Stream</a>, with an annual capacity around 63Â billion cubic metres (2,200Â <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1000000000_(number)" title="1000000000 (number)">billion</a> <a href="/wiki/Cubic_foot" title="Cubic foot">cubic feet</a>), allows Turkey to resell Russian gas to the rest of Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[342]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan_pipeline" title="Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline">Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline</a>, the second longest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oil_pipeline" title="Oil pipeline">oil pipeline</a> in the world, was inaugurated in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-emreozgur.com_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-emreozgur.com-344">[343]</a></sup> As of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> Turkey consumes 1700 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Terawatt" title="Terawatt">terawatt</a> hours (TW/h) of <a href="/wiki/Primary_energy" title="Primary energy">primary energy</a> per year, a little over 20 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Megawatt" title="Megawatt">megawatt</a> hours (MW/h) per person, mostly from imported <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fossil_fuels" title="Fossil fuels">fossil fuels</a>.<sup class="reference"
