id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[344]</a></sup> Although the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_Turkey" title="Energy policy of Turkey">energy policy of Turkey</a> includes reducing fossil-fuel imports, <a href="/wiki/Coal_in_Turkey" title="Coal in Turkey">coal in Turkey</a> is the largest single reason why <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions_by_Turkey" title="Greenhouse gas emissions by Turkey">greenhouse gas emissions by Turkey</a> amount to 1% of the global total. <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_Turkey" title="Renewable energy in Turkey">Renewable energy in Turkey</a> is being increased and <a href="/wiki/Akkuyu_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Akkuyu Nuclear Power Plant">Akkuyu Nuclear Power Plant</a> is being built on the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean</a> coast: but despite <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Turkey" title="Electricity sector in Turkey">national electricity generation</a> overcapacity <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel_subsidies" title="Fossil fuel subsidies">fossil fuels are still subsidized</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[345]</a></sup> Turkey has the fifth-highest direct utilisation and capacity of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geothermal_power_in_Turkey" title="Geothermal power in Turkey">geothermal power</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-look_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-look-347">[346]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2019, Turkey produces 45.6% of its electricity from renewable sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ieaTurkey_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-ieaTurkey-348">[347]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Turkey" title="Science and technology in Turkey">Science and technology in Turkey</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Scientific_and_Technological_Research_Council_of_Turkey" title="Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey">TÃBÄ°TAK</a> is the leading agency for developing <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Turkey" title="Science and technology in Turkey">science, technology and innovation policies in Turkey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[348]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Turkish Academy of Sciences">TÃBA</a> is an autonomous scholarly society acting to promote scientific activities in Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[349]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TAEK" title="TAEK">TAEK</a> is the country's official <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_technology" title="Nuclear technology">nuclear energy</a> institution, focused on academic research and the development and implementation of peaceful nuclear technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[350]</a></sup> It is supervising the construction of Turkey's first nuclear facility, <a href="/wiki/Akkuyu_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Akkuyu Nuclear Power Plant">Akkuyu Nuclear Power Plant</a> in <a href="/wiki/Mersin" title="Mersin">Mersin</a>, at the cost of $20 billion; the plant is expected to be operational in May 2023,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[351]</a></sup> and is projected to meet around 10% of the country's electricity demand.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TaiIDEF2015_(8).JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3696" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG/220px-TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG/330px-TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG/440px-TaiIDEF2015_%288%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TaiIDEF2015_(8).JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-1" title="GÃ¶ktÃ¼rk-1">GÃ¶ktÃ¼rk-1</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-2" title="GÃ¶ktÃ¼rk-2">GÃ¶ktÃ¼rk-2</a> and <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-3" title="GÃ¶ktÃ¼rk-3">GÃ¶ktÃ¼rk-3</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Earth_observation_satellite" title="Earth observation satellite">Earth observation satellites</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defense_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of National Defense (Turkey)">Turkish Ministry of National Defense</a>, while state-owned <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrksat_(company)" title="TÃ¼rksat (company)">TÃ¼rksat</a> operates the <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrksat_(satellite)" title="TÃ¼rksat (satellite)">TÃ¼rksat series</a> of <a href="/wiki/Communications_satellite" title="Communications satellite">communications satellites</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Turkish government invests heavily in <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> of <a href="/wiki/Military_technology" title="Military technology">military technologies</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Aerospace_Industries" title="Turkish Aerospace Industries">Turkish Aerospace Industries</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ASELSAN" title="ASELSAN">ASELSAN</a>, <a href="/wiki/HAVELSAN" title="HAVELSAN">HAVELSAN</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ROKETSAN" title="ROKETSAN">ROKETSAN</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mechanical_and_Chemical_Industry_Corporation" title="Mechanical and Chemical Industry Corporation">MKE</a>. Turkey is a global leader in <a href="/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle" title="Unmanned aerial vehicle">unmanned aerial vehicles</a> (UAV); the <a href="/wiki/Baykar_Bayraktar_TB2" title="Baykar Bayraktar TB2">Bayraktar TB2</a>, manufactured by private defence company <a href="/wiki/Baykar" title="Baykar">Baykar</a>, has been exported to over a dozen countries and played a decisive role in several conflicts, including the <a href="/wiki/2020_Nagorno-Karabakh_war" title="2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war">2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[352]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[353]</a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey has made significant inroads in aerospace technology into the 21st century. In 2013, it initiated the <a href="/wiki/Space_Launch_System_(Turkey)" title="Space Launch System (Turkey)">Turkish Space Launch System</a> (UFS) to develop an independent satellite launch capability, including the construction of a <a href="/wiki/Spaceport" title="Spaceport">spaceport</a>, the development of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Satellite_launch_vehicle" title="Satellite launch vehicle">satellite launch vehicles</a>, and the establishment of remote earth stations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ssm1_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-ssm1-355">[354]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dn1_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-dn1-356">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dn2_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-dn2-357">[356]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrksat_(company)" title="TÃ¼rksat (company)">TÃ¼rksat</a>, the country's sole <a href="/wiki/Communications_satellite" title="Communications satellite">communications satellite</a> operator, has launched a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turksat_(satellite)" title="Turksat (satellite)">series of satellites</a> into orbit; likewise, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Satellite_Assembly,_Integration_and_Test_Center" title="Turkish Satellite Assembly, Integration and Test Center">Turkish Satellite Assembly, Integration and Test Center</a> (UMET)âa spacecraft production and testing facility owned by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defence_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of National Defence (Turkey)">Ministry of National Defence</a> and operated by the TAIâhas launched the <a href="/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrk-1" title="GÃ¶ktÃ¼rk-1">GÃ¶ktÃ¼rk series</a> of <a href="/wiki/Earth_observation_satellite" title="Earth observation satellite">Earth observation satellites</a> for <a href="/wiki/Reconnaissance" title="Reconnaissance">reconnaissance</a>; <a href="/wiki/BILSAT-1" title="BILSAT-1">BILSAT-1</a> and <a href="/wiki/RASAT" title="RASAT">RASAT</a> are the scientific Earth observation satellites operated by the <a href="/wiki/T%C3%9CB%C4%B0TAK_Space_Technologies_Research_Institute" title="TÃBÄ°TAK Space Technologies Research Institute">TÃBÄ°TAK Space Technologies Research Institute</a>.
</p><p>In 2015, <a href="/wiki/Aziz_Sancar" title="Aziz Sancar">Aziz Sancar</a>, a Turkish professor at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_North_Carolina" title="University of North Carolina">University of North Carolina</a>, won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_Chemistry_Prize" title="Nobel Chemistry Prize">Nobel Prize in Chemistry</a> for his work on how cells repair damaged DNA;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[357]</a></sup> he is one of <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country#Turkey" title="List of Nobel laureates by country">two Turkish Nobel laureates</a>, and the first in the sciences. Other prominent Turkish scientists include physician <a href="/wiki/Hulusi_Beh%C3%A7et" title="Hulusi BehÃ§et">Hulusi BehÃ§et</a>, who discovered <a href="/wiki/Beh%C3%A7et%27s_disease" title="BehÃ§et's disease">BehÃ§et's disease</a>; mathematician <a href="/wiki/Cahit_Arf" title="Cahit Arf">Cahit Arf</a>, who defined the <a href="/wiki/Arf_invariant" title="Arf invariant">Arf invariant</a>; and immunologists <a href="/wiki/U%C4%9Fur_%C5%9Eahin" title="UÄur Åahin">UÄur Åahin</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%96zlem_T%C3%BCreci" title="Ãzlem TÃ¼reci">Ãzlem TÃ¼reci</a>, whose German <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotechnology</a> company, <a href="/wiki/BioNTech" title="BioNTech">BioNTech</a>, developed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RNA_vaccine" title="RNA vaccine">one of the first efficacious vaccines</a> against <a href="/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a>.
</p><p>Turkey is among the top fifty most innovative countries in the world, ranking 41st in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021; this represents a considerable increase since 2011, where it was ranked 65th.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[358]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Turkey" title="Demographics of Turkey">Demographics of Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turkish people</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2021.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="677" data-file-width="1579" decoding="async" height="94" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2021.png/220px-Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2021.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2021.png/330px-Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2021.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2021.png/440px-Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2021.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turkey_total_fertility_rate_by_province_2021.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">Total fertility rate</a> in <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependencies_by_total_fertility_rate" title="List of sovereign states and dependencies by total fertility rate">Turkey</a> by <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Turkey" title="Provinces of Turkey">province</a> (2021)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[359]</a></sup> <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffff00; color:black;">Â </span>Â 3â4</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#0cff00; color:black;">Â </span>Â 2â3</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#24e0d9; color:black;">Â </span>Â 1.5-2</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#3aafe0; color:black;">Â </span>Â 1-1.5</div></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kurdistan_of_Turkey_(CIA).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="977" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="107" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png/220px-Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png/330px-Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png/440px-Kurdistan_of_Turkey_%28CIA%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kurdistan_of_Turkey_(CIA).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA" title="CIA">CIA</a> map of areas with a Kurdish majority<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[360]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>According to the <i>Address-Based Population Recording System</i> of Turkey, the country's population was 74.7Â million people in 2011,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011stat_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-2011stat-362">[361]</a></sup> nearly three-quarters of whom lived in <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">towns and cities</a>. According to the 2011 estimate, the population is increasing by 1.35 percent each year. Turkey has an average population density of 97 people per kmÂ². People within the 15â64 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Age_group" title="Age group">age group</a> constitute 67.4 percent of the total population; the 0â14 age group corresponds to 25.3 percent; while senior citizens aged 65 years or older make up 7.3 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[362]</a></sup>
</p><p>Article 66 of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" title="Turkish Constitution">Turkish Constitution</a> defines a "Turk" as "anyone who is bound to the Turkish state through the bond of citizenship"; therefore, the legal use of the term "Turkish" as a <a href="/wiki/Citizenship" title="Citizenship">citizen</a> of Turkey is different from the <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_group" title="Ethnic group">ethnic</a> definition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:02_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-:02-364">[363]</a></sup> However approximately 70 to 80 percent of the country's citizens are ethnic Turks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-konda2_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-konda2-365">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_4-2"><a href="#cite_note-cia-4">[4]</a></sup> It is estimated that there are at least 47 ethnic groups represented in Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mutlu_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-mutlu-366">[365]</a></sup> Reliable data on the ethnic mix of the population is not available, because Turkish census figures do not include statistics on ethnicity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turkey_Ethnic_groups_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-Turkey_Ethnic_groups-367">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Kurds_in_Turkey" title="Kurds in Turkey">Kurds</a> are the largest non-Turkish ethnicity at anywhere from 12â25 per cent of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[367]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kirisci_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-kirisci-369">[368]</a></sup> The exact figure remains a subject of dispute; according to Servet Mutlu, "more often than not, these estimates reflect pro-Kurdish or pro-Turkish sympathies and attitudes rather than scientific facts or erudition".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mutlu_366-1"><a href="#cite_note-mutlu-366">[365]</a></sup> Mutlu's 1990 study estimated Kurds made up around 12 per cent of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[369]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a> make up a majority in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/A%C4%9Fr%C4%B1_Province" title="AÄrÄ± Province">AÄrÄ±</a>, <a href="/wiki/Batman_Province" title="Batman Province">Batman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bing%C3%B6l_Province" title="BingÃ¶l Province">BingÃ¶l</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bitlis_Province" title="Bitlis Province">Bitlis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diyarbak%C4%B1r_Province" title="DiyarbakÄ±r Province">DiyarbakÄ±r</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hakkari_Province" title="Hakkari Province">Hakkari</a>, <a href="/wiki/I%C4%9Fd%C4%B1r_Province" title="IÄdÄ±r Province">IÄdÄ±r</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mardin_Province" title="Mardin Province">Mardin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mu%C5%9F_Province" title="MuÅ Province">MuÅ</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siirt_Province" title="Siirt Province">Siirt</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%9E%C4%B1rnak_Province" title="ÅÄ±rnak Province">ÅÄ±rnak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tunceli_Province" title="Tunceli Province">Tunceli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Van_Province" title="Van Province">Van</a>; a near majority in <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Eanl%C4%B1urfa_Province" title="ÅanlÄ±urfa Province">ÅanlÄ±urfa Province</a> (47%); and a large minority in <a href="/wiki/Kars_Province" title="Kars Province">Kars Province</a> (20%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[370]</a></sup> In addition, due to internal migration, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kurdish_diaspora" title="Kurdish diaspora">Kurdish diaspora</a> communities exist in all of the major cities in central and western Turkey. In Istanbul, there are an estimated three million Kurds, making it the city with the largest Kurdish population in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nachmani2003_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nachmani2003-372">[371]</a></sup> Non-Kurdish minorities are believed to make up an estimated 7â12 percent of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_4-3"><a href="#cite_note-cia-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>The three "<a href="/wiki/Millet_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Millet (Ottoman Empire)">Non-Muslim</a>" minority groups recognised in the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a> were <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_Turkey" title="Armenians in Turkey">Armenians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greeks_in_Turkey" title="Greeks in Turkey">Greeks</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jews_in_Turkey" title="Jews in Turkey">Jews</a>. Other ethnic groups include <a href="/wiki/Albanians_in_Turkey" title="Albanians in Turkey">Albanians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Turkey" title="Arabs in Turkey">Arabs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Assyrians_in_Turkey" title="Assyrians in Turkey">Assyrians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks_in_Turkey" title="Bosniaks in Turkey">Bosniaks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Circassians_in_Turkey" title="Circassians in Turkey">Circassians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgians_in_Turkey" title="Georgians in Turkey">Georgians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laz_people" title="Laz people">Laz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pomaks" title="Pomaks">Pomaks</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Roma</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_4-4"><a href="#cite_note-cia-4">[4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roopnarine2015_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-Roopnarine2015-373">[372]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MedinaHepner2013_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-MedinaHepner2013-374">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[375]</a></sup> Turkey is also home to a Muslim community of <a href="/wiki/Megleno-Romanians" title="Megleno-Romanians">Megleno-Romanians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-megl_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-megl-377">[376]</a></sup>
</p><p>Before the start of the <a href="/wiki/Syrian_civil_war" title="Syrian civil war">Syrian civil war</a> in 2011, the estimated number of <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Turkey" title="Arabs in Turkey">Arabs in Turkey</a> varied from 1 million to more than 2 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[377]</a></sup> As of April 2020, there are 3.6 million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_Civil_War_in_Turkey" title="Refugees of the Syrian Civil War in Turkey">Syrian refugees</a> in Turkey, who are mostly Arabs but also include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syrian_Kurds" title="Syrian Kurds">Syrian Kurds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syrian_Turkmen" title="Syrian Turkmen">Syrian Turkmen</a>, and other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Syria" title="Ethnic groups of Syria">ethnic groups of Syria</a>. The vast majority of these are living in Turkey with temporary residence permits. The Turkish government has granted Turkish citizenship to refugees who have joined the <a href="/wiki/Syrian_National_Army" title="Syrian National Army">Syrian National Army</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unhcr-syrian-refugees_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-unhcr-syrian-refugees-379">[378]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[379]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[380]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>
<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray; background: #f9f9f9">
