<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration">Immigration</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Turkey" title="Immigration to Turkey">Immigration to Turkey</a></div>
<p>Millions of Kurds fled across the mountains to Turkey and Kurdish areas of Iran during the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a> in 1991. <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Turkey" title="Immigration to Turkey">Immigration to Turkey</a> is the process by which people <a href="/wiki/Human_migration" title="Human migration">migrate</a> to Turkey to reside in the country. <a href="/wiki/Turkey%27s_migrant_crisis" title="Turkey's migrant crisis">Turkey's migrant crisis</a> created after an estimated 2.5 percent of the population are <a href="/wiki/Human_migration" title="Human migration">international migrants</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-esa.un.org_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-esa.un.org-382">[381]</a></sup> Turkey hosts the largest number of <a href="/wiki/Refugee" title="Refugee">refugees</a> in the world, including 3.6 million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_Civil_War_in_Turkey" title="Refugees of the Syrian Civil War in Turkey">Syrian refugees</a>, as of April 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unhcr-syrian-refugees_379-1"><a href="#cite_note-unhcr-syrian-refugees-379">[378]</a></sup> As part of <a href="/wiki/Turkey%27s_migrant_crisis" title="Turkey's migrant crisis">Turkey's migrant crisis</a>, according to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNHCR" title="UNHCR">UNHCR</a>, in 2018 Turkey was hosting 63.4% of all the refugees in the world, that is 3,564,919 registered refugees from Africa and the Middle East in total.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[382]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map-TurkicLanguages.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="625" data-file-width="1425" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Map-TurkicLanguages.png/300px-Map-TurkicLanguages.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Map-TurkicLanguages.png/450px-Map-TurkicLanguages.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Map-TurkicLanguages.png/600px-Map-TurkicLanguages.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map-TurkicLanguages.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic languages</a> speaking areas in the world.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Turkey" title="Languages of Turkey">Languages of Turkey</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a> is <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>, which is the most widely spoken <a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic language</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-katzner_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-katzner-384">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-minorityrights.org_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-minorityrights.org-385">[384]</a></sup> It is spoken by 85.54 percent of the population as a <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">first language</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-milliyet-languages_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-milliyet-languages-386">[385]</a></sup> 11.97 percent of the population speaks the <a href="/wiki/Kurmanji" title="Kurmanji">Kurmanji</a> dialect of <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_languages" title="Kurdish languages">Kurdish</a> as their mother tongue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-milliyet-languages_386-1"><a href="#cite_note-milliyet-languages-386">[385]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zaza_language" title="Zaza language">Zaza</a> are the mother tongues of 2.39 percent of the population, and several other languages are the mother tongues of smaller parts of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-milliyet-languages_386-2"><a href="#cite_note-milliyet-languages-386">[385]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Endangered_language" title="Endangered language">Endangered</a> <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Turkey" title="Languages of Turkey">languages in Turkey</a> include <a href="/wiki/Abaza_language" title="Abaza language">Abaza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abkhaz_language" title="Abkhaz language">Abkhaz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adyghe_language" title="Adyghe language">Adyghe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cappadocian_Greek" title="Cappadocian Greek">Cappadocian Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gagauz_language" title="Gagauz language">Gagauz</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%C3%A9rtevin" title="HÃ©rtevin">HÃ©rtevin</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Homshetsma" title="Homshetsma">Homshetsma</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kabard-Cherkes" title="Kabard-Cherkes">Kabard-Cherkes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judaeo-Spanish" title="Judaeo-Spanish">Ladino (Judesmo)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laz_language" title="Laz language">Laz</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mlahso" title="Mlahso">Mlahso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pontic_Greek" title="Pontic Greek">Pontic Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">Romani</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suret" title="Suret">Suret</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turoyo" title="Turoyo">Turoyo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ubykh_language" title="Ubykh language">Ubykh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Western_Armenian" title="Western Armenian">Western Armenian</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-www.unesco.org_index_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-www.unesco.org_index-387">[386]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Megleno-Romanian_language" title="Megleno-Romanian language">Megleno-Romanian</a> is also spoken.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-megl_377-1"><a href="#cite_note-megl-377">[376]</a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/International_Organization_of_Turkic_Culture" title="International Organization of Turkic Culture">International Organization of Turkic Culture</a>, comprising other independent Turkic states, such as Azerbaijan, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyzstan" title="Kyrgyzstan">Kyrgyzstan</a>, Turkey and <a href="/wiki/Uzbekistan" title="Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a>. It is an intergovernmental organization whose overarching aim is promoting comprehensive cultural cooperation among Turkic-speaking states.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Turkey" title="Religion in Turkey">Religion in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Selimiye_Mosque,_Dome.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1800" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Selimiye_Mosque%2C_Dome.jpg/240px-Selimiye_Mosque%2C_Dome.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Selimiye_Mosque%2C_Dome.jpg/360px-Selimiye_Mosque%2C_Dome.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Selimiye_Mosque%2C_Dome.jpg/480px-Selimiye_Mosque%2C_Dome.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Selimiye_Mosque,_Dome.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Selimiye_Mosque,_Edirne" title="Selimiye Mosque, Edirne">Selimiye Mosque</a> was built by the imperial architect <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan" title="Mimar Sinan">Mimar Sinan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-islamic_art_book_p201_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-islamic_art_book_p201-388">[387]</a></sup> The mosque was included on <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Heritage_List" title="World Heritage List">World Heritage List</a> in 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[388]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Turkey is a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a> with no official <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a>; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Constitution" title="Turkish Constitution">Turkish Constitution</a> provides for <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a> and conscience.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[389]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[390]</a></sup> A 2016 survey by <a href="/wiki/Ipsos" title="Ipsos">Ipsos</a>, interviewing 17,180 adults across 22 countries, found that <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> was the dominant religion in Turkey, adhered to by 82% of the total population; religiously unaffiliated people comprised 13% of the population, while 2% were <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ipsos2017_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-ipsos2017-392">[391]</a></sup> According to a religiosity poll conducted in Turkey in 2019 by OPTÄ°MAR, 89.5% of the population identifies as Muslims, 4.5% believed in God but did not belong to any organized religion, 2.7% were <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">agnostics</a>, 1.7% were <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheists</a>, 0.5% were belonged to the other religions, and 1.1% did not answer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hurriyetreligion_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-hurriyetreligion-393">[392]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-t24religion_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-t24religion-394">[393]</a></sup> Another poll conducted by Gezici AraÅtÄ±rma in 2020 interviewed 1,062 people in 12 provinces and found that 28.5% of the <a href="/wiki/Generation_Z" title="Generation Z">Generation Z</a> in Turkey identify as <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Turkey" title="Irreligion in Turkey">irreligious</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[395]</a></sup> 
According to a survey by <a href="/wiki/World_Values_Survey" title="World Values Survey">World Values Survey</a> In 2017 98.0% Identified as Muslims, while 1.2% Identified with no Religion and 0.8 as other.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:8_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-:8-397">[396]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a survey by the pollster KONDA, the percentage of atheists in Turkey has tripled in 10 years and rose from 1% in 2008 to 3% in 2018, the percentage of non-believers or agnostics rose from 1% to 2%, and that 90% of irreligious Turks were under 35 years old. The survey was conducted in Turkey through face-to-face interviews with 5,793 people in their households, in April, 2018 while in 2008 6,482 people were interviewed in face-to-face in Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:9_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-:9-398">[397]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:10_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-:10-399">[398]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[399]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a></i> reports that Islam is the religion of 99.8% of the population, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sunni" title="Sunni">Sunni</a> Muslims as the largest sect, while 0.2% are Christians and Jews.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[400]</a></sup> However, there are no official governmental statistics specifying the religious beliefs of the Turkish people, nor is religious data recorded in the country's census.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[401]</a></sup> Academics suggest the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alevi" title="Alevi">Alevi</a> population may be from 15 to 20 million, while the Alevi-BektaÅi Federation states that there are around 25Â million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-usstate_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-usstate-403">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-refworld.org1_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-refworld.org1-404">[403]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Aksiyon" title="Aksiyon">Aksiyon</a> magazine, the number of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelver" title="Twelver">Twelver</a> <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shias</a> (excluding Alevis) is three million (4.2%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-caferi_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-caferi-405">[404]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5147" data-file-width="4289" decoding="async" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg/200px-Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg/300px-Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg/400px-Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_St._Anthony_of_Padua,_Istanbul" title="Church of St. Anthony of Padua, Istanbul">Church of St. Anthony of Padua</a> on <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stiklal_Avenue" title="Ä°stiklal Avenue">Ä°stiklal Avenue</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Beyo%C4%9Flu" title="BeyoÄlu">BeyoÄlu</a> district of <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>. There are 234 active churches in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-heper2018_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-heper2018-406">[405]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> has a long history in present-day Turkey, which is the birthplace of numerous Christian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelve_apostles" title="Twelve apostles">apostles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint" title="Saint">saints</a>. <a href="/wiki/Antioch" title="Antioch">Antioch</a> (<a href="/wiki/Antakya" title="Antakya">Antakya</a>) is regarded by tradition as the spot where the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gospels" title="Gospels">Gospels</a> were written, and where the followers of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a> were called Christians for the first time. <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> is generally considered to be the center and the "cradle of Orthodox <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_civilization" title="Christian civilization">Christian civilization</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[407]</a></sup> The percentage of Christians in Turkey fell from 17.5% (three million followers) in a population of 16Â million to 2.5% percent in the early 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[408]</a></sup> mainly as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide" title="Armenian genocide">Armenian genocide</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_and_Turkey" title="Population exchange between Greece and Turkey">population exchange between Greece and Turkey</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[409]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Christian_emigration" title="Christian emigration">emigration of Christians</a> that began in the late 19th century and gained pace in the first quarter of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[410]</a></sup> Today, there are more than 120,000â320,000 people of various <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_denominations" title="Christian denominations">Christian denominations</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pew_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pew-412">[411]</a></sup> representing less than 0.2% of Turkey's population,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia-rel_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-cia-rel-413">[412]</a></sup> including an estimated 80,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox" title="Oriental Orthodox">Oriental Orthodox</a>, 35,000 <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Roman Catholics</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-catho_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-catho-414">[413]</a></sup> 18,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antiochian_Greeks" title="Antiochian Greeks">Antiochian Greeks</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[414]</a></sup> 5,000 <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church" title="Greek Orthodox Church">Greek Orthodox</a>, smaller numbers of <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-christiancentury.org_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-christiancentury.org-416">[415]</a></sup> and 512 <a href="/wiki/Mormons" title="Mormons">Mormons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[416]</a></sup> Currently, there are 236 churches open for worship in Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[417]</a></sup>
</p><p>Modern-day Turkey continues to have a small Jewish population;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-science.co.il_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-science.co.il-419">[418]</a></sup> with around 26,000 <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Turkey" title="History of the Jews in Turkey">Jews</a>, the vast majority of whom are <a href="/wiki/Sephardi_Jews" title="Sephardi Jews">Sephardi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[419]</a></sup> Turkey has <a href="/wiki/Jewish_population_by_country" title="Jewish population by country">the biggest Jewish community</a> among the Muslim-majority countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[420]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:11_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-:11-422">[421]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a mid-2010s poll, 2.9% of Turkish respondents identified as atheists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-human.nl_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-human.nl-423">[422]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ateizm_Derne%C4%9Fi" title="Ateizm DerneÄi">Association of Atheism</a>, the first official atheist organisation in the Balkans and the Middle East, was founded in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blogs.lse.ac.uk1_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-blogs.lse.ac.uk1-424">[423]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkishatheist.net1_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-turkishatheist.net1-425">[424]</a></sup> Some religious and secular officials have claimed that <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Deism" title="Deism">deism</a> are growing among Turkish people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[425]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[426]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[427]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[428]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Turkey" title="Education in Turkey">Education in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3656" data-file-width="5849" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg/220px-Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg/330px-Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg/440px-Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">Istanbul Technical University</a> is the world's third-oldest technical university.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[429]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Education_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of National Education (Turkey)">Ministry of National Education</a> is responsible for pre-tertiary education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wesed_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-wesed-431">[430]</a></sup> This is compulsory and lasts twelve years: four years each of primary school, middle school and high school.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt-peg_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-peg-432">[431]</a></sup> All 12 years compulsory education is free of charge in public schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Min-edu_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-Min-edu-433">[432]</a></sup>
</p><p>Basic education in Turkey is said to lag behind other OECD countries, with significant differences between high and low performers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WBedu_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-WBedu-434">[433]</a></sup> Access to high-quality school heavily depends on the performance in the secondary school entrance exams, to the point that some students begin taking private tutoring classes when they are ten years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WBedu_434-1"><a href="#cite_note-WBedu-434">[433]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2017, there are 190 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universities_in_Turkey" title="Universities in Turkey">universities in Turkey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[434]</a></sup> Except for the Open Education Faculties (AÃF) at <a href="/wiki/Anadolu_University" title="Anadolu University">Anadolu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">Istanbul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_University" title="AtatÃ¼rk University">AtatÃ¼rk University</a>; entrance is regulated by the national <a href="/wiki/Student_Selection_and_Placement_System" title="Student Selection and Placement System">Student Selection and Placement System</a> (<a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>: <i lang="tr">ÃÄrenci SeÃ§me ve YerleÅtirme Sistemi</i>, ÃSYS) examination, after which high school graduates are assigned to universities according to their performance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[435]</a></sup> According to the 2012â2013 <a href="/wiki/Times_Higher_Education_World_University_Rankings" title="Times Higher Education World University Rankings">Times Higher Education World University Rankings</a>, the top university in Turkey is <a href="/wiki/Middle_East_Technical_University" title="Middle East Technical University">Middle East Technical University</a>, followed by <a href="/wiki/Bilkent_University" title="Bilkent University">Bilkent University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ko%C3%A7_University" title="KoÃ§ University">KoÃ§ University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">Istanbul Technical University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_University" title="BoÄaziÃ§i University">BoÄaziÃ§i University</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-therank_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-therank-437">[436]</a></sup> All state and private universities are under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Higher_Education_(Turkey)" title="Council of Higher Education (Turkey)">Higher Education Board</a> (<a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>: <i lang="tr">YÃ¼ksekÃ¶Äretim Kurulu</i>, YÃK), whose head is appointed by the President of Turkey; and since 2016 the President directly appoints all rectors of all state and private universities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[437]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IstanUni.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/IstanUni.jpg/220px-IstanUni.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/IstanUni.jpg/330px-IstanUni.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/IstanUni.jpg/440px-IstanUni.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:IstanUni.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">Istanbul University</a> was founded in 1453 as a <i><a href="/wiki/Institute_of_technology" title="Institute of technology">DarÃ¼lfÃ¼nÃ»n</a></i>. On 1 August 1933 it was reorganised and became the Republic's first university.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-istanbuluniversity_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-istanbuluniversity-439">[438]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Turkey is a member of <a href="/wiki/Socrates_programme" title="Socrates programme">Socrates programme</a>, <a href="/wiki/Erasmus_Programme" title="Erasmus Programme">Erasmus Programme</a> and <a href="/wiki/Erasmus%2B" title="Erasmus+">Erasmus+</a> Programmes. These student exchange programmes are organised by the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[439]</a></sup> Also it is a member of <a href="/wiki/Erasmus_Student_Network" title="Erasmus Student Network">Erasmus Student Network</a> which is a Europe-wide student organisation which has more than 15.000 volunteers across the <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[440]</a></sup>
</p><p>Turkey has become a hub for foreign students in recent years. The number of foreign students in Turkey was 795.962 in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[441]</a></sup> The government has announced a vision to draw around 500,000 foreign students at its universities by offering attractive scholarships.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[442]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkiye_Scholarships" title="TÃ¼rkiye Scholarships">TÃ¼rkiye Scholarships</a> is international scholarship program funded by Government of Turkey. In 2021, in response to <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkiye_Scholarships" title="TÃ¼rkiye Scholarships">TÃ¼rkiye Scholarships</a>, that was advertised in January 2021, Turkish Government received 165,000 applications from 178 countries of the World.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TÃRKÄ°YE_SCHOLARSHIPS-TÃRKÄ°YE_FOR_EDUCATION_444-0"><a href="#cite_note-TÃRKÄ°YE_SCHOLARSHIPS-TÃRKÄ°YE_FOR_EDUCATION-444">[443]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TÃ¼rkiye_Scholarships_FAQ_445-0"><a href="#cite_note-TÃ¼rkiye_Scholarships_FAQ-445">[444]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Study_in_Izmir_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-Study_in_Izmir-446">[445]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Turkey" title="Health care in Turkey">Health care in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_(1).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3216" data-file-width="4898" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg/220px-Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg/330px-Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg/440px-Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ac%C4%B1bademHospitalAltunizade_(1).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>AcÄ±badem Hospital in Altunizade neighborhood of ÃskÃ¼dar, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0stanbul" title="Ä°stanbul">Ä°stanbul</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Turkey)" title="Ministry of Health (Turkey)">Ministry of Health</a> has run a universal public healthcare system since 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-njm_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-njm-447">[446]</a></sup> Known as Universal Health Insurance (<span title="Turkish-language text"><i lang="tr">Genel SaÄlÄ±k SigortasÄ±</i></span>), it is funded by a tax surcharge on employers, currently at 5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-njm_447-1"><a href="#cite_note-njm-447">[446]</a></sup> Public-sector funding covers approximately 75.2% of health expenditures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-njm_447-2"><a href="#cite_note-njm-447">[446]</a></sup> Despite the universal health care, total expenditure on health as a share of GDP in 2018 was the lowest among OECD countries at 6.3% of GDP, compared to the OECD average of 9.3%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-njm_447-3"><a href="#cite_note-njm-447">[446]</a></sup> The lower health care expenditure is due to lower median age in Turkey which is 32.4, compared to Italy which is 47.3.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[447]</a></sup> Aging population is the prime reason for higher healthcare expenditure in the developed world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[448]</a></sup>
</p><p>Average life expectancy is 78.6 years (75.9 for males and 81.3 for females), compared with the EU average of 81 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-njm_447-4"><a href="#cite_note-njm-447">[446]</a></sup> Turkey has high rates of <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a>, with 29.5% of its adult population having a <a href="/wiki/Body_mass_index" title="Body mass index">body mass index</a> (BMI) value that is 30 or above.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WHO_Mean_Body_Mass_Index_BMI_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-WHO_Mean_Body_Mass_Index_BMI-450">[449]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution_in_Turkey" title="Air pollution in Turkey">Air pollution in Turkey</a> is a major cause of early death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[450]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are many private hospitals in the country. Turkey benefits from medical tourism in the recent years. Health tourism earns above $1 billion to Turkey in 2019. Some 60% of the income is obtained from plastic surgery and a total of 662,087 patients received service in the country last year within the scope of health tourism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[451]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Turkey" title="Culture of Turkey">Culture of Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arts_in_Turkey" title="Arts in Turkey">Arts in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_folklore" title="Turkish folklore">Turkish folklore</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Festivals_in_Turkey" title="Festivals in Turkey">Festivals in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2020-02_img60_Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6454" data-file-width="5163" decoding="async" height="275" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Istanbul_asv2020-02_img60_Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque.jpg/220px-Istanbul_asv2020-02_img60_Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Istanbul_asv2020-02_img60_Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque.jpg/330px-Istanbul_asv2020-02_img60_Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Istanbul_asv2020-02_img60_Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque.jpg/440px-Istanbul_asv2020-02_img60_Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2020-02_img60_Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque" title="OrtakÃ¶y Mosque">OrtakÃ¶y Mosque</a> is an example of the Westernisation of Islamic-<a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">Ottoman architecture</a>. Many <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">Baroque</a> architecture elements can be seen in it.</div></div></div>
<p>Turkey has a very diverse culture that is a blend of various elements of the <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine_culture" title="Byzantine culture">Byzantine,</a> <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Culture of the Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> (which was itself a continuation of both <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greco-Roman" title="Greco-Roman">Greco-Roman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">Islamic</a> cultures) and <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western culture</a> and traditions, which started with the <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Westernisation of the Ottoman Empire</a> and still continues today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_culture_453-0"><a href="#cite_note-TR_culture-453">[452]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[453]</a></sup> This mix originally began as a result of the encounter of Turks and their culture with those of the peoples who were in their path during <a href="/wiki/Turkic_migration" title="Turkic migration">their migration</a> from Central Asia to the West.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_culture_453-1"><a href="#cite_note-TR_culture-453">[452]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[454]</a></sup> Turkish culture is a product of efforts to be a "modern" Western state, while maintaining traditional religious and historical values.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TR_culture_453-2"><a href="#cite_note-TR_culture-453">[452]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_painting" title="Turkish painting">Turkish painting</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0znik_pottery" title="Ä°znik pottery">Ä°znik pottery</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_carpet" title="Turkish carpet">Turkish carpet</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_miniature" title="Turkish miniature">Turkish miniature</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_illumination" title="Turkish illumination">Turkish illumination</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ottoman_miniature" title="Ottoman miniature">Ottoman miniature</a> is linked to the <a href="/wiki/Persian_miniature" title="Persian miniature">Persian miniature</a> tradition, as well as strong <a href="/wiki/Chinese_painting#Late_imperial_China_(1368â1895)" title="Chinese painting">Chinese</a> artistic influences. The words <i>tasvir</i> or <i>nakÄ±Å</i> were used to define the art of miniature painting in Ottoman Turkish. The studios the artists worked in were called <i>nakkaÅhane</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-miniature1_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-miniature1-456">[455]</a></sup> The miniatures were usually not signed, perhaps because of the rejection of individualism, but also because the works were not created entirely by one person; the head painter designed the composition of the scene, and his apprentices drew the contours (which were called <i>tahrir</i>) with black or colored ink and then painted the miniature without creating an illusion of depth. The head painter, and much more often the scribe of the text, were indeed named and depicted in some of the manuscripts. The understanding of perspective was different from that of the nearby European Renaissance painting tradition, and the scene depicted often included different time periods and spaces in one picture. They followed closely the context of the book they were included in, more illustrations than standalone works of art.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkishculture.org2_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-turkishculture.org2-457">[456]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh" title="MatrakÃ§Ä± Nasuh">MatrakÃ§Ä± Nasuh</a> (1480â1564) is one of the most prominent artists of this era.
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Turkish_painters" title="List of Turkish painters">Turkish painting</a>, in the Western sense, developed actively starting from the mid 19th century. The first painting lessons were scheduled at what is now the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">Istanbul Technical University</a> (then the <i>Imperial Military Engineering School</i>) in 1793, mostly for technical purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HarriOhta1999_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-HarriOhta1999-458">[457]</a></sup> In the late 19th century, human figure in the Western sense was being established in Turkish painting, especially with <a href="/wiki/Osman_Hamdi_Bey" title="Osman Hamdi Bey">Osman Hamdi Bey</a> (1842â1910). <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">Impressionism</a>, among the contemporary trends, appeared later on with <a href="/wiki/Halil_Pasha_(painter)" title="Halil Pasha (painter)">Halil Pasha</a> (c.1857â1939). Other important Turkish painters in the 19th century were <a href="/wiki/Ferik_%C4%B0brahim_Pasha" title="Ferik Ä°brahim Pasha">Ferik Ä°brahim PaÅa</a> (1815â1891), <a href="/wiki/Osman_Nuri_Pasha_(painter)" title="Osman Nuri Pasha (painter)">Osman Nuri PaÅa</a> (c.1839â1906), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C5%9Eeker_Ahmet_Pa%C5%9Fa" title="Åeker Ahmet PaÅa">Åeker Ahmet PaÅa</a> (1841â1907), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hoca_Ali_Riza" title="Hoca Ali Riza">Hoca Ali Riza</a> (1864â1939).
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:338px;max-width:338px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:168px;max-width:168px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2098" data-file-width="1454" decoding="async" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg/166px-Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg/249px-Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg/332px-Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg 2x" width="166"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:166px;max-width:166px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3527" data-file-width="2419" decoding="async" height="239" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/164px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/246px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/328px-Osman_Hamdi_Bey_-_Two_Musician_Girls_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="164"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">16th century map of <a href="/wiki/Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh" title="MatrakÃ§Ä± Nasuh">MatrakÃ§Ä± Nasuh</a> (left) and <i>Two Musician Girls</i> of <a href="/wiki/Osman_Hamdi_Bey" title="Osman Hamdi Bey">Osman Hamdi Bey</a> (right).</div></div></div></div>
<p>The young Turkish artists sent to Europe in 1926 came back inspired by contemporary trends such as <a href="/wiki/Fauvism" title="Fauvism">Fauvism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cubism" title="Cubism">Cubism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Expressionism" title="Expressionism">Expressionism</a>, still very influential in Europe. The later "Group D" of artists led by <a href="/wiki/Abidin_Dino" title="Abidin Dino">Abidin Dino</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cemal_Tollu" title="Cemal Tollu">Cemal Tollu</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fikret_Mualla" title="Fikret Mualla">Fikret Mualla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Princess_Fahrelnissa_Zeid" title="Princess Fahrelnissa Zeid">FahrÃ¼nnisa Zeid</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bedri_Rahmi_Eyuboglu" title="Bedri Rahmi Eyuboglu">Bedri Rahmi EyÃ¼boÄlu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adnan_Coker" title="Adnan Coker">Adnan Ãoker</a> and <a href="/wiki/Burhan_Do%C4%9Fan%C3%A7ay" title="Burhan DoÄanÃ§ay">Burhan DoÄanÃ§ay</a> introduced some trends that had lasted in the West for more than three decades.
</p><p>Other important movements in Turkish painting were the "Yeniler Grubu" (The Newcomers Group) of the late 1930s; the "On'lar Grubu" (Group of Ten) of the 1940s; the "Yeni Dal Grubu" (New Branch Group) of the 1950s; and the "Siyah Kalem Grubu" (Black Pen Group) of the 1960s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkresmi.com_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-turkresmi.com-459">[458]</a></sup>
</p><p>Internationally acclaimed <a href="/wiki/List_of_Turkish_artists" title="List of Turkish artists">Turkish sculptors</a> in the 20th century include <a href="/wiki/Ali_Hadi_Bara" title="Ali Hadi Bara">Ali Hadi Bara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%BCht%C3%BC_M%C3%BCrido%C4%9Flu" title="ZÃ¼htÃ¼ MÃ¼ridoÄlu">ZÃ¼htÃ¼ MÃ¼ridoÄlu</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0lhan_Koman" title="Ä°lhan Koman">Ä°lhan Koman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuzgun_Acar" title="Kuzgun Acar">Kuzgun Acar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ali_Teoman_Germaner" title="Ali Teoman Germaner">Ali Teoman Germaner</a>.
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_carpet" title="Turkish carpet">Carpet (<i>halÄ±</i>)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kilim" title="Kilim">tapestry (<i>kilim</i>)</a> <a href="/wiki/Weaving" title="Weaving">weaving</a> is a traditional Turkish art form with roots in pre-Islamic times. During its long history, the art and craft of weaving carpets and tapestries in Turkey has integrated numerous cultural traditions. Apart from the <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic</a> design patterns that are prevalent, traces of <a href="/wiki/Persian_carpet" title="Persian carpet">Persian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_silk#Tapestry_and_embroidery" title="Byzantine silk">Byzantine</a> patterns can also be detected. There are also similarities with the patterns used in Armenian, Caucasian and Kurdish carpet designs. The arrival of Islam in Central Asia and the development of <a href="/wiki/Islamic_art" title="Islamic art">Islamic art</a> also influenced Turkic patterns in the medieval period. The history of the designs, motifs and ornaments used in Turkish carpets and tapestries thus reflects the political and ethnic history of the Turks and the cultural diversity of <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>. However, scientific attempts were unsuccessful, as yet, to attribute a particular design to a specific ethnic, regional, or even nomadic versus village tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[459]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri,_Turkey,_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2704" data-file-width="4001" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/220px-Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/330px-Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/440px-Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri%2C_Turkey%2C_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Al-Hajj_Hafiz_Muhammad_Nuri,_Turkey,_1801_-_The_Dala%27il_al-Khayrat_of_al-Juzuli_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ottoman_miniature" title="Ottoman miniature">Ottoman miniature</a> which can be linked to the Persian miniature tradition,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[460]</a></sup> as well as strong Chinese artistic influences.</div></div></div>
<p>The earliest examples of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_paper_marbling" title="Turkish paper marbling">Turkish paper marbling</a>, called <i><a href="/wiki/Paper_marbling" title="Paper marbling">ebru</a></i> in Turkish, are said to be a copy of the <i>HÃ¢lnÃ¢me</i> by the poet ArifÃ®. The text of this manuscript was rendered in a delicate cut paper dÃ©coupage calligraphy by Mehmed bin Gazanfer and completed in 1540, and features many marbled and decorative paper borders. One early master by the <a href="/wiki/Pseudonym" title="Pseudonym">pseudonym</a> of <i>Åebek</i> is mentioned posthumously in the earliest Ottoman text on the art known as the <i>Tertib-i RisÃ¢le-i EbrÃ®</i>, which is dated based on internal evidence to after 1615. The instructions for several <i>ebru</i> techniques in the text are accredited to this master. Another famous 18th-century master by the name of Hatip Mehmed Efendi (died 1773) is accredited with developing motifs and perhaps early floral designs, although evidence from India appears to contradict some of these reports. Despite this, marbled motifs are commonly referred to as <i>hatip</i> designs in Turkey today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkishculture.org3_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-turkishculture.org3-462">[461]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature_and_theatre">Literature and theatre</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">Turkish literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_Turkey" title="Theatre of Turkey">Theatre of Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kemalbey.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="589" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Kemalbey.jpg/170px-Kemalbey.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Kemalbey.jpg/255px-Kemalbey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Kemalbey.jpg/340px-Kemalbey.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kemalbey.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Nam%C4%B1k_Kemal" title="NamÄ±k Kemal">NamÄ±k Kemal</a>'s works had a profound influence on <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk">AtatÃ¼rk</a> and other Turkish statesmen who established the Turkish Republic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ÃgostonMasters2009-48_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-ÃgostonMasters2009-48-463">[462]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ShawShaw1977-260-261_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-ShawShaw1977-260-261-464">[463]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">Turkish literature</a> is a mix of cultural influences. Interaction between the Ottoman Empire and the Islamic world along with Europe contributed to a blend of Turkic, Islamic and European traditions in modern-day Turkish music and literary arts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ottomus_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-ottomus-465">[464]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Turkish_literature" title="Turkish literature">Turkish literature</a> was heavily influenced by <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabic_literature" title="Arabic literature">Arabic literature</a> during most of the Ottoman era.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a> reforms of the 19th century introduced previously unknown Western genres, primarily the <a href="/wiki/Novel" title="Novel">novel</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Short_story" title="Short story">short story</a>. Many of the writers in the Tanzimat period wrote in several genres simultaneously: for instance, the poet <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Namik_Kemal" title="Namik Kemal">NÃ¢mÄ±k Kemal</a> also wrote the important 1876 novel <i>Ä°ntibÃ¢h</i> (Awakening), while the journalist <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0brahim_%C5%9Einasi" title="Ä°brahim Åinasi">Åinasi</a> has written, in 1860, the first modern Turkish play, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/One_act_play" title="One act play">one-act</a> comedy "<i>Åair Evlenmesi</i>" (The Poet's Marriage). Most of the roots of modern Turkish literature were formed between the years 1896 and 1923. Broadly, there were three primary literary movements during this period: the <i>Edebiyat-Ä± CedÃ®de</i> (New Literature) movement; the <i>Fecr-i ÃtÃ®</i> (Dawn of the Future) movement; and the <i>MillÃ® Edebiyat</i> (National Literature) movement.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Orhan_Pamuk.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="276" data-file-width="521" decoding="async" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Orhan_Pamuk.jpg/220px-Orhan_Pamuk.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Orhan_Pamuk.jpg/330px-Orhan_Pamuk.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Orhan_Pamuk.jpg/440px-Orhan_Pamuk.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Orhan_Pamuk.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel</a>-laureate Turkish novelist <a href="/wiki/Orhan_Pamuk" title="Orhan Pamuk">Orhan Pamuk</a> and his <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Angora" title="Turkish Angora">Turkish Angora cat</a> at his personal writing space</div></div></div>
<p>The first radical step of innovation in 20th century Turkish poetry was taken by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/N%C3%A2z%C4%B1m_Hikmet_Ran" title="NÃ¢zÄ±m Hikmet Ran">NÃ¢zÄ±m Hikmet</a>, who introduced the <a href="/wiki/Free_verse" title="Free verse">free verse</a> style. Another revolution in Turkish poetry came about in 1941 with the <a href="/wiki/Garip" title="Garip">Garip</a> movement led by <a href="/wiki/Orhan_Veli_Kan%C4%B1k" title="Orhan Veli KanÄ±k">Orhan Veli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oktay_R%C4%B1fat_Horozcu" title="Oktay RÄ±fat Horozcu">Oktay RÄ±fat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Melih_Cevdet_Anday" title="Melih Cevdet Anday">Melih Cevdet</a>. The mix of cultural influences in Turkey is dramatised, for example, in the form of the "new symbols of the clash and interlacing of cultures" enacted in the novels of <a href="/wiki/Orhan_Pamuk" title="Orhan Pamuk">Orhan Pamuk</a>, recipient of the 2006 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[465]</a></sup>
</p><p>The origin of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_theatre" title="Turkish theatre">Turkish theatre</a> dates back to ancient pagan rituals and oral legends. The dances, music and songs performed during the rituals of the inhabitants of Anatolia millennia ago are the elements from which the first shows originated. In time, the ancient rituals, myths, legends and stories evolved into theatrical shows. Starting from the 11th-century, the traditions of the Seljuk Turks blended with those of the indigenous peoples of Anatolia and the interaction between diverse cultures paved the way for new plays.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul,_Turkey.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2861" data-file-width="3951" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg/220px-S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg/330px-S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg/440px-S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul,_Turkey.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House" title="SÃ¼reyya Opera House">SÃ¼reyya Opera House</a> is situated in the Asian side of <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_Cultural_Center" title="AtatÃ¼rk Cultural Center">AtatÃ¼rk Cultural Center</a> is the main Opera House in the European side of the city.</div></div></div>
<p>After the <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a> (Reformation) period in the 19th century, characters in Turkish theatre were modernised and plays were performed on European-style stages, with actors wearing European costumes. Following the <a href="/wiki/Second_Constitutional_Era" title="Second Constitutional Era">restoration of constitutional monarchy</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Young_Turk_Revolution" title="Young Turk Revolution">Young Turk Revolution</a> in 1908, theatrical activities increased and social problems began to be reflected at the theatre as well as in historical plays. A theatrical conservatoire, <a href="/wiki/Dar%C3%BClbedayi" title="DarÃ¼lbedayi">DarÃ¼lbedayi-i Osmani</a> (which became the nucleus of the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_City_Theatres" title="Istanbul City Theatres">Istanbul City Theatres</a>) was established in 1914. During the years of chaos and war, the DarÃ¼lbedayi-i Osmani continued its activities and attracted the younger generation. Numerous Turkish playwrights emerged in this era; some of them wrote on romantic subjects, while others were interested in social problems, and still others dealt with nationalistic themes. The first Turkish musicals were also written in this period. In time, Turkish women began to appear on stage, which was an important development in the late Ottoman society. Until then, female roles had only been played by actresses who were members of Turkey's ethnic minorities. Today there are numerous private theatres in the country, together with those which are subsidised by the government, such as the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Theatres" title="Turkish State Theatres">Turkish State Theatres</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkishculture.org4_467-0"><a href="#cite_note-turkishculture.org4-467">[466]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music_and_dance">Music and dance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_dance" title="Turkish dance">Turkish dance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Turkey" title="Music of Turkey">Music of Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_classical_music" title="Turkish classical music">Turkish classical music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_folk_music" title="Turkish folk music">Turkish folk music</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_music_(style)" title="Turkish music (style)">Turkish music (style)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="736" data-file-width="658" decoding="async" height="246" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg/220px-Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg/330px-Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg/440px-Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ajda_Pekkan_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Referred to as <i>SÃ¼perstar</i> by the Turkish media, <a href="/wiki/Ajda_Pekkan" title="Ajda Pekkan">Ajda Pekkan</a> is a prominent figure of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_pop_music" title="Turkish pop music">Turkish pop music</a>, with a career spanning decades and a repertoire of diverse musical styles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[467]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Music_of_Turkey" title="Music of Turkey">Music of Turkey</a> includes mainly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkic_culture" title="Turkic culture">Turkic</a> elements as well as partial influences ranging from <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Central_Asia" title="Music of Central Asia">Central Asian folk music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_music" title="Arabic music">Arabic music</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greek_music" title="Greek music">Greek music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_music" title="Ottoman music">Ottoman music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_traditional_music" title="Persian traditional music">Persian music</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Music_of_Southeastern_Europe" title="Music of Southeastern Europe">Balkan music</a>, as well as references to more modern European and <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States" title="Music of the United States">American</a> <a href="/wiki/Popular_music" title="Popular music">popular music</a>. The roots of traditional music in Turkey span across centuries to a time when the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seljuk_Turks" title="Seljuk Turks">Seljuk Turks</a> migrated to <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persia" title="Persia">Persia</a> in the 11th century and contains elements of both Turkic and pre-Turkic influences. Much of its modern popular music can trace its roots to the emergence in the early 1930s drive for <a href="/wiki/Westernization" title="Westernization">Westernization</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-soundsofanatolia_469-0"><a href="#cite_note-soundsofanatolia-469">[468]</a></sup>
</p><p>With the assimilation of immigrants from various regions the diversity of musical genres and musical instrumentation also expanded. Turkey has also seen documented folk music and recorded popular music produced in the ethnic styles of <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Greece" title="Music of Greece">Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Armenia" title="Music of Armenia">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Albania" title="Music of Albania">Albanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Poland" title="Music of Poland">Polish</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish">Jewish</a> communities, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lesartsturcs_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-lesartsturcs-470">[469]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many Turkish cities and towns have vibrant local music scenes which, in turn, support a number of regional musical styles. Despite this however, western music styles like <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop music</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kanto_(music)" title="Kanto (music)">kanto</a> lost popularity to <a href="/wiki/Arabesque" title="Arabesque">arabesque</a> in the late 1970s and 1980s. It became popular again by the beginning of the 1990s, as a result of an opening economy and society. With the support of <a href="/wiki/Sezen_Aksu" title="Sezen Aksu">Sezen Aksu</a>, the resurging popularity of pop music gave rise to several international Turkish pop stars such as <a href="/wiki/Ajda_Pekkan" title="Ajda Pekkan">Ajda Pekkan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tarkan_(singer)" title="Tarkan (singer)">Tarkan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sertab_Erener" title="Sertab Erener">Sertab Erener</a>. Internationally acclaimed Turkish <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Blues" title="Blues">blues</a> musicians and composers include <a href="/wiki/Ahmet_Ertegun" title="Ahmet Ertegun">Ahmet Ertegun</a> (founder and president of <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Records" title="Atlantic Records">Atlantic Records</a>), <a href="/wiki/N%C3%BCkhet_Ruacan" title="NÃ¼khet Ruacan">NÃ¼khet Ruacan</a> and Kerem GÃ¶rsev.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Baris_Manco.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="745" data-file-width="1272" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Baris_Manco.jpg/220px-Baris_Manco.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Baris_Manco.jpg/330px-Baris_Manco.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Baris_Manco.jpg/440px-Baris_Manco.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Baris_Manco.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o" title="BarÄ±Å ManÃ§o">BarÄ±Å ManÃ§o</a> was a Turkish rock musician and one of the founders of the <a href="/wiki/Anatolian_rock" title="Anatolian rock">Anatolian rock</a> genre.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Five" title="Turkish Five">Turkish Five</a> is a name used by some authors to identify the five pioneers of Western classical music in Turkey, namely <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ahmed_Adnan_Saygun" title="Ahmed Adnan Saygun">Ahmed Adnan Saygun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ulvi_Cemal_Erkin" title="Ulvi Cemal Erkin">Ulvi Cemal Erkin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cemal_Re%C5%9Fit_Rey" title="Cemal ReÅit Rey">Cemal ReÅit Rey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hasan_Ferit_Alnar" title="Hasan Ferit Alnar">Hasan Ferit Alnar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Necil_Kaz%C4%B1m_Akses" title="Necil KazÄ±m Akses">Necil KazÄ±m Akses</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ä°lyasoÄlu_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ä°lyasoÄlu-471">[470]</a></sup> Internationally acclaimed Turkish musicians of Western classical music include pianists <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0dil_Biret" title="Ä°dil Biret">Ä°dil Biret</a>, <a href="/wiki/Verda_Erman" title="Verda Erman">Verda Erman</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BClsin_Onay" title="GÃ¼lsin Onay">GÃ¼lsin Onay</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pekinel_sisters" title="Pekinel sisters">Pekinel sisters</a> (GÃ¼her and SÃ¼her Pekinel), <a href="/wiki/Ay%C5%9Feg%C3%BCl_Sar%C4%B1ca" title="AyÅegÃ¼l SarÄ±ca">AyÅegÃ¼l SarÄ±ca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Faz%C4%B1l_Say" title="FazÄ±l Say">FazÄ±l Say</a>; violinists <a href="/wiki/Ayla_Erduran" title="Ayla Erduran">Ayla Erduran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Suna_Kan" title="Suna Kan">Suna Kan</a>; opera singers <a href="/wiki/Semiha_Berksoy" title="Semiha Berksoy">Semiha Berksoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leyla_Gencer" title="Leyla Gencer">Leyla Gencer</a> and <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BCne%C5%9F_G%C3%BCrle" title="GÃ¼neÅ GÃ¼rle">GÃ¼neÅ GÃ¼rle</a>; and conductors <a href="/wiki/Emre_Arac%C4%B1" title="Emre AracÄ±">Emre AracÄ±</a>, <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BCrer_Aykal" title="GÃ¼rer Aykal">GÃ¼rer Aykal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Erol_Erdin%C3%A7" title="Erol ErdinÃ§">Erol ErdinÃ§</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rengim_G%C3%B6kmen" title="Rengim GÃ¶kmen">Rengim GÃ¶kmen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hikmet_%C5%9Eim%C5%9Fek" title="Hikmet ÅimÅek">Hikmet ÅimÅek</a>.
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_dance" title="Turkish dance">Turkish folk dance</a> is diverse. <i><a href="/wiki/Hora_(dance)" title="Hora (dance)">Hora</a></i> is performed in <a href="/wiki/East_Thrace" title="East Thrace">East Thrace</a>; <i><a href="/wiki/Zeybek_dance" title="Zeybek dance">Zeybek</a></i> in the <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Region" title="Aegean Region">Aegean Region</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marmara_Region" title="Marmara Region">Southern Marmara</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">East-Central Anatolia Region</a>; <i>Teke</i> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" title="Mediterranean Region">Western Mediterranean Region</a>; <i>KaÅÄ±k OyunlarÄ±</i> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kar%C5%9F%C4%B1lama" title="KarÅÄ±lama">KarÅÄ±lama</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">West-Central Anatolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region" title="Black Sea Region">Western Black Sea Region</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marmara_Region" title="Marmara Region">Southern Marmara Region</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" title="Mediterranean Region">Eastern Mediterranean Region</a>; <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Horon" title="Horon">Horon</a></i> in the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region" title="Black Sea Region">Central and Eastern Black Sea Region</a>; <i><a href="/wiki/Halay" title="Halay">Halay</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">Eastern Anatolia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">Central Anatolia Region</a>; and <i><a href="/wiki/Bar_(dance)" title="Bar (dance)">Bar</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Lezginka" title="Lezginka">Lezginka</a></i> in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">Northeastern Anatolia Region</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-.ncturkishfestival._472-0"><a href="#cite_note-.ncturkishfestival.-472">[471]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Turkey" title="Architecture of Turkey">Architecture of Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_architecture" title="Seljuk architecture">Seljuk architecture</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">Ottoman architecture</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Exterior_of_Sultan_Ahmed_I_Mosque,_(old_name_P1020390.jpg).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Exterior_of_Sultan_Ahmed_I_Mosque%2C_%28old_name_P1020390.jpg%29.jpg/200px-Exterior_of_Sultan_Ahmed_I_Mosque%2C_%28old_name_P1020390.jpg%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Exterior_of_Sultan_Ahmed_I_Mosque%2C_%28old_name_P1020390.jpg%29.jpg/300px-Exterior_of_Sultan_Ahmed_I_Mosque%2C_%28old_name_P1020390.jpg%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Exterior_of_Sultan_Ahmed_I_Mosque%2C_%28old_name_P1020390.jpg%29.jpg/400px-Exterior_of_Sultan_Ahmed_I_Mosque%2C_%28old_name_P1020390.jpg%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Blue_Mosque,_Istanbul" title="Blue Mosque, Istanbul">Blue Mosque</a> (1616) in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="4912" data-file-width="7360" decoding="async" height="133"
