srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG/300px-Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG/400px-Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/%C3%87%C4%B1ra%C4%9Fan_Palace" title="ÃÄ±raÄan Palace">ÃÄ±raÄan Palace</a> (1867) in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2268" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg/200px-Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg/300px-Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg/400px-Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Main_Post_Office" title="Istanbul Main Post Office">Grand Post Office</a> (1909) in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SakirinMosque.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2268" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/SakirinMosque.jpg/200px-SakirinMosque.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/SakirinMosque.jpg/300px-SakirinMosque.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/SakirinMosque.jpg/400px-SakirinMosque.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/%C5%9Eakirin_Mosque" title="Åakirin Mosque">Åakirin Mosque</a> (2009), the first mosque designed by a woman.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Byzantine era is usually dated from 330 AD, when Constantine the Great moved the Roman capital to Byzantium, which became Constantinople, until the fall of the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a> in 1453. Its architecture dramatically influenced the later medieval architecture throughout Europe and the Near East, and became the primary progenitor of the Renaissance and Ottoman architectural traditions that followed its collapse.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[472]</a></sup> When the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> went Christian (as well as Eastwards) with its new capital at <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>, its architecture became more sensuous and more ambitious. This new style would come to be known as Byzantine with increasingly exotic domes and ever-richer mosaics, traveled west to Ravenna and Venice and as far north as Moscow.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[473]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_architecture" title="Seljuk architecture">architecture of the Seljuk Turks</a> combined the elements and characteristics of the <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Central_Asia" title="Architecture of Central Asia">Turkic architecture of Central Asia</a> with those of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_architecture" title="Persian architecture">Persian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_architecture" title="Arab architecture">Arab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenian_architecture" title="Armenian architecture">Armenian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine</a> architecture. The transition from Seljuk architecture to <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">Ottoman architecture</a> is most visible in <a href="/wiki/Bursa" title="Bursa">Bursa</a>, which was the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman State</a> between 1335 and 1413. Following the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">Ottoman conquest of Constantinople (Istanbul)</a> in 1453, Ottoman architecture was significantly influenced by <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>. <a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="TopkapÄ± Palace">TopkapÄ± Palace</a> in Istanbul is one of the most famous examples of <a href="/wiki/Classical_Ottoman_architecture" title="Classical Ottoman architecture">classical Ottoman architecture</a> and was the primary residence of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_Sultan" title="Ottoman Sultan">Ottoman Sultans</a> for approximately 400 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_475-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-475">[474]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan" title="Mimar Sinan">Mimar Sinan</a> (c.1489â1588) was the most important architect of the classical period in Ottoman architecture. He was the chief architect of at least 374 buildings that were constructed in various <a href="/wiki/Eyalet" title="Eyalet">provinces</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> in the 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[475]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sedefkar_Mehmed_Agha" title="Sedefkar Mehmed Agha">Sedefkar Mehmed Agha</a> also known as the architect of the <a href="/wiki/Blue_Mosque,_Istanbul" title="Blue Mosque, Istanbul">Blue Mosque</a> was an Albanian origin <a href="/wiki/Devshirme" title="Devshirme">Devshirme</a>. He became a pupil of architect Mimar Sinan, becoming his first assistant in charge of the office in the absence of Sinan. His work heavily influenced by his teacher <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan" title="Mimar Sinan">Mimar Sinan</a>
</p><p>Since the 18th century, Turkish architecture has been increasingly influenced by European styles, and this can be particularly seen in the <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a> era buildings of Istanbul like the <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="DolmabahÃ§e Palace">DolmabahÃ§e</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%87%C4%B1ra%C4%9Fan_Palace" title="ÃÄ±raÄan Palace">ÃÄ±raÄan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taksim_Military_Barracks" title="Taksim Military Barracks">Taksim Military Barracks</a> (demolished), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feriye_Saraylar%C4%B1" title="Feriye SaraylarÄ±">Feriye</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beylerbeyi_Palace" title="Beylerbeyi Palace">Beylerbeyi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Palace" title="KÃ¼Ã§Ã¼ksu Palace">KÃ¼Ã§Ã¼ksu</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ihlamur_Palace" title="Ihlamur Palace">Ihlamur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1z_Palace" title="YÄ±ldÄ±z Palace">YÄ±ldÄ±z</a> <a href="/wiki/Palace" title="Palace">palaces</a>, which were all designed by members of the <a href="/wiki/Balyan_family" title="Balyan family">Balyan family</a> of Ottoman Armenian court architects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[476]</a></sup> The Ottoman era <a href="/wiki/Yal%C4%B1" title="YalÄ±">waterfront houses (<i>yalÄ±</i>)</a> on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">Bosphorus</a> also reflect the fusion between classical Ottoman and European architectural styles during the aforementioned period. Italian architect, <a href="/wiki/Raimondo_D%27Aronco" title="Raimondo D'Aronco">Raimondo D'Aronco</a> served as the chief palace architect to the Ottoman Sultan AbdÃ¼lhamid II in Istanbul for 16 years. D'Aronco designed and built a large number of buildings of various types in Istanbul. The stylistic features of his works can be classified in three groups: Revivalism, reinterpretation of the Ottoman forms, Art Nouveau and Vienna Secession. Art Nouveau was first introduced to Istanbul by D'Aronco, and his designs reveal that he drew freely on Byzantine and Ottoman decorations. He also mixed Western and Oriental styles in his work.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_National_Architectural_Movement" title="First National Architectural Movement">First National Architectural Movement</a> in the early 20th century sought to create a new architecture, which was based on motifs from Seljuk and Ottoman architecture. The leading architects of this movement were <a href="/wiki/Vedat_Tek" title="Vedat Tek">Vedat Tek</a> (1873â1942), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mimar_Kemaleddin_Bey" title="Mimar Kemaleddin Bey">Mimar Kemaleddin Bey</a> (1870â1927), <a href="/wiki/Arif_Hikmet_Koyuno%C4%9Flu" title="Arif Hikmet KoyunoÄlu">Arif Hikmet KoyunoÄlu</a> (1888â1982) and Giulio Mongeri (1873â1953).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkisharch_478-0"><a href="#cite_note-turkisharch-478">[477]</a></sup> Buildings from this era are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Main_Post_Office" title="Istanbul Main Post Office">Grand Post Office</a> in Istanbul (1905â1909), <a href="/wiki/Tayyare_Apartments" title="Tayyare Apartments">Tayyare Apartments</a> (1919â1922),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tayyare_479-0"><a href="#cite_note-tayyare-479">[478]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_4th_Vak%C4%B1f_Han" title="Istanbul 4th VakÄ±f Han">Istanbul 4th VakÄ±f Han</a> (1911â1926),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[479]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/State_Art_and_Sculpture_Museum" title="State Art and Sculpture Museum">State Art and Sculpture Museum</a> (1927â1930),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stateart_481-0"><a href="#cite_note-stateart-481">[480]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ethnography_Museum_of_Ankara" title="Ethnography Museum of Ankara">Ethnography Museum of Ankara</a> (1925â1928),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnography_482-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnography-482">[481]</a></sup> the first <a href="/wiki/Ziraat_Bank" title="Ziraat Bank">Ziraat Bank</a> headquarters in Ankara (1925â1929),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[482]</a></sup> the first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrkiye_%C4%B0%C5%9F_Bankas%C4%B1" title="TÃ¼rkiye Ä°Å BankasÄ±">TÃ¼rkiye Ä°Å BankasÄ±</a> headquarters in Ankara (1926â1929),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iÅbank_484-0"><a href="#cite_note-iÅbank-484">[483]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bebek,_Istanbul" title="Bebek, Istanbul">Bebek</a> Mosque,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bebek_485-0"><a href="#cite_note-bebek-485">[484]</a></sup> and Kamer Hatun Mosque.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kamer_486-0"><a href="#cite_note-kamer-486">[485]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mass_487-0"><a href="#cite_note-mass-487">[486]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some of the notable contemporary architects of Turkey are <a href="/wiki/Behruz_%C3%87inici" title="Behruz Ãinici">Behruz Ãinici</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emre_Arolat" title="Emre Arolat">Emre Arolat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tabanl%C4%B1o%C4%9Flu_Architects" title="TabanlÄ±oÄlu Architects">Murat TabanlÄ±oÄlu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tabanl%C4%B1o%C4%9Flu_Architects" title="TabanlÄ±oÄlu Architects">Melkan TabanlÄ±oÄlu</a>, Melike AltÄ±nÄ±ÅÄ±k,  <a href="/wiki/Zeynep_Fad%C4%B1ll%C4%B1o%C4%9Flu" title="Zeynep FadÄ±llÄ±oÄlu">Zeynep FadÄ±llÄ±oÄlu</a> and Mehmet KÃ¼tÃ¼kÃ§Ã¼oÄlu
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish cuisine</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">Ottoman cuisine</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1719" data-file-width="2510" decoding="async" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/200px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/300px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg/400px-Turkish_coffee_in_Istanbul.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Turkish_coffee" title="Turkish coffee">Turkish coffee</a> with <a href="/wiki/Turkish_delight" title="Turkish delight">Turkish delight</a>. Turkish coffee is a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">UNESCO-listed intangible cultural heritage</a> of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[487]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[488]</a></sup></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Meze_Lido_Restaurant_Adalar.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="2844" data-file-width="4841" decoding="async" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Meze_Lido_Restaurant_Adalar.JPG/200px-Meze_Lido_Restaurant_Adalar.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Meze_Lido_Restaurant_Adalar.JPG/300px-Meze_Lido_Restaurant_Adalar.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Meze_Lido_Restaurant_Adalar.JPG/400px-Meze_Lido_Restaurant_Adalar.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish cuisine</a> is largely the heritage of <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">Ottoman cuisine</a>, which can be described as a fusion and refinement of <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_cuisine" title="Mediterranean cuisine">Mediterranean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balkan_cuisine" title="Balkan cuisine">Balkan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middle_Eastern_cuisine" title="Middle Eastern cuisine">Middle Eastern</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Asian_cuisine" title="Central Asian cuisine">Central Asian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_European_cuisine" title="Eastern European cuisine">Eastern European</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenian_cuisine" title="Armenian cuisine">Armenian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Georgian_cuisine" title="Georgian cuisine">Georgian cuisines</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[489]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[490]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish cuisine</a> is largely the heritage of <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">Ottoman cuisine</a>. In the early years of the Republic, a few studies were published about regional Anatolian dishes but cuisine did not feature heavily in Turkish folkloric studies until the 1980s, when the fledgling tourism industry encouraged the Turkish state to sponsor two food symposia. The papers submitted at the symposia presented the history of Turkish cuisine on a "historical continuum" that dated back to Turkic origins in Central Asia and continued through the Seljuk and Ottoman periods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-berg_492-0"><a href="#cite_note-berg-492">[491]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many of the papers presented at these first two symposia were unreferenced. Prior to the symposia, the study of Turkish culinary culture was first popularised by the publication of SÃ¼heyl Ãnver's <i>Fifty Dishes in Turkish History</i> in 1948. This book was based on recipes found in an 18th century Ottoman manuscript. His second book was about palace cuisine during the reign of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mehmet_II" title="Mehmet II">Mehmet II</a>. Following the publication of Ãnver's book subsequent studies were published, including a 1978 study by a historian named Bahaettin Ãgel about the <a href="/wiki/Central_Asian_cuisine" title="Central Asian cuisine">Central Asian</a> origins of Turkish cuisine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-berg_492-1"><a href="#cite_note-berg-492">[491]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">Ottoman cuisine</a> contains elements of <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_cuisine" title="Byzantine cuisine">Byzantine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balkan_cuisine" title="Balkan cuisine">Balkan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenian_cuisine" title="Armenian cuisine">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_cuisine" title="Kurdish cuisine">Kurdish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_cuisine" title="Arab cuisine">Arab</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_cuisine" title="Persian cuisine">Persian</a> cuisines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[492]</a></sup> The country's position between Europe, Asia, and the Mediterranean Sea helped the Turks in gaining complete control of the major <a href="/wiki/Trade_route" title="Trade route">trade routes</a>, and an ideal landscape and climate allowed plants and animals to flourish. Turkish cuisine was well established by the mid-1400s, the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>'s 600-year reign. <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">Yogurt</a> salads, fish in <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">olive oil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sharbat" title="Sharbat">sherbet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dolma" title="Dolma">stuffed and wrapped vegetables</a> became Turkish staples. The empire, eventually spanning from Austria and Ukraine to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabia" title="Arabia">Arabia</a> and North Africa, used its land and water routes to import exotic ingredients from all over the world. By the end of the 16th century, the Ottoman court housed over 1,400 live-in cooks and passed laws regulating the freshness of food. Since the fall of the empire in World War I (1914â1918) and the establishment of the Turkish Republic in 1923, foreign food such as French hollandaise sauce and Western fast food have made their way into the modern Turkish diet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-foodbycountry.com_494-0"><a href="#cite_note-foodbycountry.com-494">[493]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sports_in_Turkey" title="Sports in Turkey">Sports in Turkey</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Turkey" title="Football in Turkey">Football in Turkey</a></div>
<p>The most popular <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sports_in_Turkey" title="Sports in Turkey">sport in Turkey</a> is <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[494]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(football)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (football)">Galatasaray</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2000_UEFA_Cup_Final" title="2000 UEFA Cup Final">UEFA Cup</a> and <a href="/wiki/2000_UEFA_Super_Cup" title="2000 UEFA Super Cup">UEFA Super Cup</a> in 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uefa.com_496-0"><a href="#cite_note-uefa.com-496">[495]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_national_football_team" title="Turkish national football team">Turkish national football team</a> won the bronze medal at the <a href="/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2002 FIFA World Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a>, the <a href="/wiki/2003_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2003 FIFA Confederations Cup">2003 FIFA Confederations Cup</a> and <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008" title="UEFA Euro 2008">UEFA Euro 2008</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tff.org1_497-0"><a href="#cite_note-tff.org1-497">[496]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/220px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/330px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg/440px-La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:La_selecci%C3%B3n_turca_de_baloncesto_tras_recibir_la_medalla_de_plata.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkey_national_basketball_team" title="Turkey national basketball team">Turkey</a> won the silver medal at the <a href="/wiki/2010_FIBA_World_Championship" title="2010 FIBA World Championship">2010 FIBA World Championship</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Other mainstream sports such as <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a> are also popular.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkey_national_basketball_team" title="Turkey national basketball team">men's national basketball team</a> won the silver medal at the <a href="/wiki/2010_FIBA_World_Championship" title="2010 FIBA World Championship">2010 FIBA World Championship</a> and at <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2001" title="EuroBasket 2001">EuroBasket 2001</a>, which were both hosted by Turkey; and is one of the most successful at the <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_Mediterranean_Games" title="Basketball at the Mediterranean Games">Mediterranean Games</a>. Turkish basketball club <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Men%27s_Basketball" title="FenerbahÃ§e Men's Basketball">FenerbahÃ§e</a> reached the final of the <a href="/wiki/EuroLeague" title="EuroLeague">EuroLeague</a> in three consecutive seasons (<a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_Euroleague" title="2015â16 Euroleague">2016</a>, <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_EuroLeague" title="2016â17 EuroLeague">2017</a> and <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_EuroLeague" title="2017â18 EuroLeague">2018</a>), becoming the European champions in 2017 and runners-up in 2016 and 2018. Another Turkish basketball club, <a href="/wiki/Anadolu_Efes_S.K." title="Anadolu Efes S.K.">Anadolu Efes S.K.</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2020%E2%80%9321_EuroLeague" title="2020â21 EuroLeague">2020â21 EuroLeague</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_FIBA_Kora%C4%87_Cup" title="1995â96 FIBA KoraÄ Cup">1995â96</a> <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Kora%C4%87_Cup" title="FIBA KoraÄ Cup">FIBA KoraÄ Cup</a>, were the runners-up of the <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_EuroLeague" title="2018â19 EuroLeague">2018â19 EuroLeague</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1992%E2%80%9393_FIBA_European_Cup" title="1992â93 FIBA European Cup">1992â93</a> <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Saporta_Cup" title="FIBA Saporta Cup">FIBA Saporta Cup</a>, and finished third at the <a href="/wiki/1999%E2%80%932000_FIBA_EuroLeague" title="1999â2000 FIBA EuroLeague">1999â2000 EuroLeague</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2000%E2%80%9301_FIBA_SuproLeague" title="2000â01 FIBA SuproLeague">2000â01 SuproLeague</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[497]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[498]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_men%27s_basketball_team" title="BeÅiktaÅ men's basketball team">BeÅiktaÅ</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_FIBA_EuroChallenge" title="2011â12 FIBA EuroChallenge">2011â12</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EuroChallenge" title="EuroChallenge">FIBA EuroChallenge</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fibaeurope.com1_500-0"><a href="#cite_note-fibaeurope.com1-500">[499]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(men%27s_basketball)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (men's basketball)">Galatasaray</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_Eurocup_Basketball" title="2015â16 Eurocup Basketball">2015â16 Eurocup</a>. The Final of the <a href="/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_EuroLeague_Women" title="2013â14 EuroLeague Women">2013â14 EuroLeague Women</a> basketball championship was played between two Turkish teams, <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(women%27s_basketball)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (women's basketball)">Galatasaray</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Women%27s_Basketball" title="FenerbahÃ§e Women's Basketball">FenerbahÃ§e</a>, and won by Galatasaray.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fibaeurope.com2_501-0"><a href="#cite_note-fibaeurope.com2-501">[500]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Turkey_women%27s_national_basketball_team" title="Turkey women's national basketball team">women's national basketball team</a> won the silver medal at the <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_Women_2011" title="EuroBasket Women 2011">EuroBasket Women 2011</a> and the bronze medal at the <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_Women_2013" title="EuroBasket Women 2013">EuroBasket Women 2013</a>. Like the men's team, the women's basketball team is one of the most successful at the <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_Mediterranean_Games" title="Basketball at the Mediterranean Games">Mediterranean Games</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="5472" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg/220px-Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg/330px-Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg/440px-Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vakifbanksk2018cl.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vak%C4%B1fBank_S.K." title="VakÄ±fBank S.K.">VakÄ±fBank S.K.</a> has won the <a href="/wiki/FIVB_Volleyball_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship">FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship</a> in <a href="/wiki/2017_FIVB_Volleyball_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="2017 FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship">2017</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_FIVB_Volleyball_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship">2018</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fenerbahce.org.tr_502-0"><a href="#cite_note-fenerbahce.org.tr-502">[501]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eczacibasisporkulubu.org.tr_503-0"><a href="#cite_note-eczacibasisporkulubu.org.tr-503">[502]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hurriyet.com.tr1_504-0"><a href="#cite_note-hurriyet.com.tr1-504">[503]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_CEV_Women%27s_Champions_League" title="2017â18 CEV Women's Champions League">2017â18 CEV Women's Champions League</a> for the fourth time in their history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_505-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-505">[504]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Turkey_women%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Turkey women's national volleyball team">women's national volleyball team</a> won the gold medal at the <a href="/wiki/2015_European_Games" title="2015 European Games">2015 European Games</a>, the silver medal at the <a href="/wiki/2003_Women%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship" title="2003 Women's European Volleyball Championship">2003 European Championship</a>, the bronze medal at the <a href="/wiki/2011_Women%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship" title="2011 Women's European Volleyball Championship">2011 European Championship</a>, and the bronze medal at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2012_FIVB_World_Grand_Prix" title="2012 FIVB World Grand Prix">2012 FIVB World Grand Prix</a>. They also won multiple medals over multiple decades at the <a href="/wiki/Volleyball_at_the_Mediterranean_Games" title="Volleyball at the Mediterranean Games">Mediterranean Games</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tvf.org.tr_506-0"><a href="#cite_note-tvf.org.tr-506">[505]</a></sup> Women's volleyball clubs, namely <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Women%27s_Volleyball" title="FenerbahÃ§e Women's Volleyball">FenerbahÃ§e</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eczac%C4%B1ba%C5%9F%C4%B1_Istanbul" title="EczacÄ±baÅÄ± Istanbul">EczacÄ±baÅÄ±</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vak%C4%B1fbank_Spor_Kul%C3%BCb%C3%BC" title="VakÄ±fbank Spor KulÃ¼bÃ¼">VakÄ±fbank</a>, have won numerous European championship titles and medals. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Women%27s_Volleyball" title="FenerbahÃ§e Women's Volleyball">FenerbahÃ§e</a> won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2010_FIVB_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="2010 FIVB Women's Club World Championship">2010 FIVB Women's Club World Championship</a> and the <a href="/wiki/CEV_Women%27s_Champions_League" title="CEV Women's Champions League">2012 CEV Women's Champions League</a>. Representing <a href="/wiki/European_Volleyball_Confederation" title="European Volleyball Confederation">Europe</a> as the winner of the <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_CEV_Women%27s_Champions_League" title="2012â13 CEV Women's Champions League">2012â13 CEV Women's Champions League</a>, VakÄ±fbank also became the world champion by winning the <a href="/wiki/2013_FIVB_Volleyball_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="2013 FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship">2013 FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship</a>. Recently VakÄ±fbank has won the <a href="/wiki/FIVB_Volleyball_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship">FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship</a> in <a href="/wiki/2017_FIVB_Volleyball_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="2017 FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship">2017</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_FIVB_Volleyball_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship">2018</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fenerbahce.org.tr_502-1"><a href="#cite_note-fenerbahce.org.tr-502">[501]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eczacibasisporkulubu.org.tr_503-1"><a href="#cite_note-eczacibasisporkulubu.org.tr-503">[502]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hurriyet.com.tr1_504-1"><a href="#cite_note-hurriyet.com.tr1-504">[503]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_CEV_Women%27s_Champions_League" title="2017â18 CEV Women's Champions League">2017â18 CEV Women's Champions League</a> for the fourth time in their history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_505-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-505">[504]</a></sup>
</p><p>The traditional national sport of Turkey has been <a href="/wiki/Oil_wrestling" title="Oil wrestling">yaÄlÄ± gÃ¼reÅ</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">oil</a> <a href="/wiki/Wrestling" title="Wrestling">wrestling</a></i>) since Ottoman times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[506]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Edirne_Province" title="Edirne Province">Edirne Province</a> has hosted the annual <a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1rkp%C4%B1nar" title="KÄ±rkpÄ±nar">KÄ±rkpÄ±nar</a> oil wrestling tournament since 1361, making it the oldest continuously held sporting competition in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[507]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[508]</a></sup> In the 19th and early 20th centuries, Ottoman Turkish oil wrestling champions such as <a href="/wiki/Yusuf_%C4%B0smail" title="Yusuf Ä°smail">Koca Yusuf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nurullah_Hasan" title="Nurullah Hasan">Nurullah Hasan</a> and <a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1z%C4%B1lc%C4%B1kl%C4%B1_Mahmut" title="KÄ±zÄ±lcÄ±klÄ± Mahmut">KÄ±zÄ±lcÄ±klÄ± Mahmut</a> acquired international fame in Europe and North America by winning world heavyweight wrestling championship titles. International wrestling styles governed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Federation_of_Associated_Wrestling_Styles" title="International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles">FILA</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_wrestling" title="Freestyle wrestling">freestyle wrestling</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greco-Roman_wrestling" title="Greco-Roman wrestling">Greco-Roman wrestling</a> are also popular, with many European, World and Olympic championship titles won by Turkish wrestlers both individually and as a national team.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[509]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_cinema">Media and cinema</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_in_Turkey" title="Media in Turkey">Media in Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Turkey" title="Cinema of Turkey">Cinema of Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TRT_World.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="123" data-file-width="930" decoding="async" height="37" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/TRT_World.svg/280px-TRT_World.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/TRT_World.svg/420px-TRT_World.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/TRT_World.svg/560px-TRT_World.svg.png 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TRT_World.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/TRT_World" title="TRT World">TRT World</a> is the international news platform of the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Radio_and_Television_Corporation" title="Turkish Radio and Television Corporation">Turkish Radio and Television Corporation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[510]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Hundreds of television channels, thousands of local and national radio stations, several dozen newspapers, a productive and profitable <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Turkey" title="Cinema of Turkey">national cinema</a> and a rapid growth of <a href="/wiki/Broadband" title="Broadband">broadband</a> Internet use constitute a vibrant media industry in Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tesevmedya_512-0"><a href="#cite_note-tesevmedya-512">[511]</a></sup> The majority of the TV audiences are shared among public broadcaster <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Radio_and_Television_Corporation" title="Turkish Radio and Television Corporation">TRT</a> and the network-style channels such as <a href="/wiki/Kanal_D" title="Kanal D">Kanal D</a>, <a href="/wiki/Show_TV" title="Show TV">Show TV</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ATV_(Turkey)" title="ATV (Turkey)">ATV</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Star_TV_(Turkey)" title="Star TV (Turkey)">Star TV</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Broadcast_media" title="Broadcast media">broadcast media</a> have a very high penetration as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Satellite_dishes" title="Satellite dishes">satellite dishes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cable_television" title="Cable television">cable</a> systems are widely available.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_513-0"><a href="#cite_note-cp-513">[512]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RT%C3%9CK" title="RTÃK">Radio and Television Supreme Council (RTÃK)</a> is the government body overseeing the broadcast media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cp_513-1"><a href="#cite_note-cp-513">[512]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[513]</a></sup> By circulation, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Turkey" title="List of newspapers in Turkey">most popular newspapers</a> are <i><a href="/wiki/Posta_(newspaper)" title="Posta (newspaper)">Posta</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/H%C3%BCrriyet" title="HÃ¼rriyet">HÃ¼rriyet</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/S%C3%B6zc%C3%BC" title="SÃ¶zcÃ¼">SÃ¶zcÃ¼</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sabah_(newspaper)" title="Sabah (newspaper)">Sabah</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Habert%C3%BCrk" title="HabertÃ¼rk">HabertÃ¼rk</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[514]</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/TRT_2" title="TRT 2">TRT 2</a> is the public service channel dedicated to culture and art.
</p><p><br/>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Turkish_television_drama" title="Turkish television drama">Turkish television dramas</a> are increasingly becoming popular beyond Turkey's borders and are among the country's most vital exports, both in terms of profit and public relations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[515]</a></sup> After sweeping the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>'s television market over the past decade, Turkish shows have aired in more than a dozen <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_America" title="Central America">Central American</a> countries in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[516]</a></sup> Turkey is today the world's second largest exporter of television series.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[517]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2832" data-file-width="4256" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg/220px-Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg/330px-Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg/440px-Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aspendos_Amphitheatre.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The closing ceremony of the annual <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Antalya_Golden_Orange_Film_Festival" title="International Antalya Golden Orange Film Festival">International Antalya Golden Orange Film Festival</a> takes place at the <a href="/wiki/Aspendos" title="Aspendos">Aspendos</a> <a href="/wiki/Amphitheatre" title="Amphitheatre">amphitheatre</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ye%C5%9Fil%C3%A7am" title="YeÅilÃ§am">YeÅilÃ§am</a></i> is the <a href="/wiki/Sobriquet" title="Sobriquet">sobriquet</a> that refers to the Turkish film art and industry. The first movie exhibited in the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lumiere_Brothers" title="Lumiere Brothers">Lumiere Brothers</a>' 1895 film, <i><a href="/wiki/L%27Arriv%C3%A9e_d%27un_train_en_gare_de_La_Ciotat" title="L'ArrivÃ©e d'un train en gare de La Ciotat">L'ArrivÃ©e d'un train en gare de La Ciotat</a></i>, which was shown in <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a> in 1896. The first Turkish-made film was a documentary entitled <i><a href="/wiki/Ayastefanos%27taki_Rus_Abidesinin_Y%C4%B1k%C4%B1l%C4%B1%C5%9F%C4%B1" title="Ayastefanos'taki Rus Abidesinin YÄ±kÄ±lÄ±ÅÄ±">Ayastefanos'taki Rus Abidesinin YÄ±kÄ±lÄ±ÅÄ±</a></i> (<i>Demolition of the Russian Monument at <a href="/wiki/Ye%C5%9Filk%C3%B6y" title="YeÅilkÃ¶y">San Stefano</a></i>), directed by <a href="/wiki/Fuat_Uzk%C4%B1nay" title="Fuat UzkÄ±nay">Fuat UzkÄ±nay</a> and completed in 1914. The first narrative film, <a href="/wiki/Sedat_Simavi" title="Sedat Simavi">Sedat Simavi</a>'s <i>The Spy</i>, was released in 1917. Turkey's first sound film was shown in 1931. Turkish directors like <a href="/wiki/Metin_Erksan" title="Metin Erksan">Metin Erksan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuri_Bilge_Ceylan" title="Nuri Bilge Ceylan">Nuri Bilge Ceylan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Y%C4%B1lmaz_G%C3%BCney" title="YÄ±lmaz GÃ¼ney">YÄ±lmaz GÃ¼ney</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zeki_Demirkubuz" title="Zeki Demirkubuz">Zeki Demirkubuz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ferzan_%C3%96zpetek" title="Ferzan Ãzpetek">Ferzan Ãzpetek</a> won numerous international awards such as the <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">Palme d'Or</a> and <a href="/wiki/Golden_Bear" title="Golden Bear">Golden Bear</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkishculture.org5_519-0"><a href="#cite_note-turkishculture.org5-519">[518]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-berlinale_1964_520-0"><a href="#cite_note-berlinale_1964-520">[519]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite legal provisions, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Turkey" title="Media freedom in Turkey">media freedom in Turkey</a> has steadily deteriorated from 2010 onwards, with a precipitous decline following the failed <a href="/wiki/2016_Turkish_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2016 Turkish coup d'Ã©tat attempt">coup attempt</a> on 15 July 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[520]</a></sup> As of December 2016, at least 81 <a href="/wiki/List_of_arrested_journalists_in_Turkey" title="List of arrested journalists in Turkey">journalists were imprisoned</a> in Turkey and more than 100 news outlets were closed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cpj.org1_260-2"><a href="#cite_note-cpj.org1-260">[259]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> lists Turkey's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Turkey" title="Media freedom in Turkey">media</a> as <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_Press_(report)" title="Freedom of the Press (report)"><i>not free</i></a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_522-0"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-522">[521]</a></sup> The media crackdowns also extend to <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship" title="Internet censorship">Internet censorship</a> with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2017_block_of_Wikipedia_in_Turkey" title="2017 block of Wikipedia in Turkey">Wikipedia getting blocked</a> between 29 April 2017 and 15 January 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[522]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[523]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1093669538">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:solid #aaa 1px}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalborder>ul{padding:0.1em;background:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style><div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint plainlist portalbox portalborder tright" role="navigation">
<ul>
<li><span><img alt="flag" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="21" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Flag_of_Turkey.svg/32px-Flag_of_Turkey.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Flag_of_Turkey.svg/48px-Flag_of_Turkey.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Flag_of_Turkey.svg/64px-Flag_of_Turkey.svg.png 2x" width="32"/></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Turkey" title="Portal:Turkey">Turkey portal</a></span></li></ul></div>

<li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Turkey" title="Outline of Turkey">Outline of Turkey</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-two-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-two_25-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has said "Our attitude on the Armenian issue has been clear from the beginning. We will never accept the accusations of genocide".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Scholars give several reasons for Turkey's <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide_denial#Causes" title="Armenian genocide denial">position</a> including the preservation of national identity, the demand for reparations and territorial concerns.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-MET-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-MET_13-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-MET_13-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFCasson1977">Casson, Lionel (1977). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190503015440/https://www.metmuseum.org/pubs/bulletins/1/pdf/3258667.pdf.bannered.pdf" rel="nofollow">"The Thracians"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin</i>. <b>35</b> (1): 2â6. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.2307%2F3258667" rel="nofollow">10.2307/3258667</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a>Â <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/3258667" rel="nofollow">3258667</a>. <li id="cite_note-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-31">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1" id="CITEREFReference-OED-Turkey"><span class="cs1-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a class="external text" href="https://oed.com/search?searchType=dictionary&amp;q=Turkey" rel="nofollow">"Turkey"</a></span>. <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i> (OnlineÂ ed.). <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Turkey&amp;rft.btitle=Oxford+English+Dictionary&amp;rft.edition=Online&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Foed.com%2Fsearch%3FsearchType%3Ddictionary%26q%3DTurkey&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ATurkey"></span>Â <span style="font-size:0.95em; font-size:95%; color:#555">(Subscription or <a class="external text" href="https://www.oed.com/public/login/loggingin#withyourlibrary" rel="nofollow">participating institution membership</a> required.)</span></span>

âJudged by the number of its colonies Miletus was the most prolific of the Greek mother cities. <li id="cite_note-Hout2011-71"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Hout2011_71-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFTheo_van_den_Hout2011">Theo van den Hout (2011). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QDJNg5Nyef0C&amp;pg=PA1" rel="nofollow"><i>The Elements of Hittite</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-93">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBlack2005">Black, Jeremy (2005). <i>The Atlas of World History</i>. <li id="cite_note-barroso-147"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-barroso_147-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-barroso_147-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-barroso_147-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://ec.europa.eu/commission_barroso/president/pdf/interview_20061015_en.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Interview with European Commission President Jose Manuel Barroso on BBC Sunday AM"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a>. 15 October 2006. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20061121143823/http://ec.europa.eu/commission_barroso/president/pdf/interview_20061015_en.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 21 November 2006<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-421"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-421">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jewish-population-of-the-world" rel="nofollow">"Jewish Population of the World"</a>. <i>www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-438"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-438">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFMustafa_Akyol2016">Mustafa Akyol (7 November 2016). <a class="external text" href="http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/11/turkey-erdogan-took-full-control-of-universities.html" rel="nofollow">"Turkish universities latest domino in Erdogan's path"</a>. <li id="cite_note-474"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-474">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFVoyce1957">Voyce, Arthur (1957). </div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><div style="display: inline-block; line-height: 1.2em; padding: .1em 0;"><a href="/wiki/Dependent_territory" title="Dependent territory">Dependent<br/>territories</a></div></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Australia</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><div style="display: inline-block; line-height: 1.2em; padding: .1em 0;"><a href="/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_China" title="Special administrative regions of China">Special administrative<br/>regions of China</a></div></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

<li><a href="/wiki/12th_ECO_Summit" title="12th ECO Summit">Baku 2012</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/13th_ECO_Summit" title="13th ECO Summit">Islamabad 2017</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Member</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
